Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l:
The prologe of the knyghtes tale
¶ O yee so noble and worthi pryncis and princesse
Oþer estatis or degrees · what euer yee beo þᵗat haue
Disposicione or plesaunce · to rede or here þe stories
Of olde tymis Passed to kepe yow frome ydelnesse
And slowþe · mescheuing oþer folies þat might
Be cause of more harome filowyng / vowcheth sauf
I be seche yowe to fynde yowe occupacioıı̄un in þe Reding
Here of þe tales / of Caunterburye wiche beon
Compilid / in þis boke filowing First foundid yma
Genid and made / boþe for disporte and leornyng
Of aƚƚlle þoo that beon gentile of birthe or of cōndicoıı̄uns
By þe laureal and moste famous poete þat euer /
Was to fore him as in þemvelisshing of oure rude
Moders englisshe tonge · clepid Chaucyer a Gavfrede
Of whos soule · god · for his mercy have pitee of his
Grace Amen
¶ Nowe here firste begynnyþe þe prologe of þe
kneytis tale
Whanne þᵗat Aperyll wᵗith his shoures swoote
Þe drowght of marche hathe perced to þᵉ rote
And baþed eủery veyne · / in suche lykoure
Of wiche vertue · engenderid is þe floure
Whanne zepherus eke : / wᵗith his swete brethe
Enspiryd hathe in eủery holt and hethe
The tendre croppys · and þe yownge sonne
Haþe in þe Rame · his halfe cours eronne
And smale foules · maken melodye
Þat slepen al þe night wᵗith open eye
So prickeþe hēm nature / in þayre courages
Þanne longen folkes to gon on pilgrymages
And palmeris eke / to seche straunge strandes
To ferne halowes · kowþe in sundrye landis
And speciallye · frome euery shyres ende
Of England to Cavnterburye þei wende
The hooly blyssfulle martyr · For to seke
Þat hem hathe holpon whanne þᵗat þei were seke
By felle hit in þᵗat saysoun · on a day
In sowthwerke / at þe tabard as I laye
Redy to weonde · vpon my pilgrymage
To Cauntovreburye wᵗith devoute courage
At night was comēn in to þᵗat hostelerye
Wel nyen and twenty on a companye
Of sundry folke · by aventur efalle
In feleship and pylgrymes were þei alle
Þat towarde Caunturburye wolden Ride
Þe chaumberis ⁊and þᵉ stablis werne weyde
And wele were þei eesed · al at þᵉ beste
And shortly whan þe sonne was to reste
So had I spoken wᵗith hem eủerychoon
Þat I was of hir felishippe A noon
And made forwardis eorly for to ryse
To · take oure weye þer as I yow devyse
But naþelesse · wheyle I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or þᵗat I forþer · in þis tale passe
Me thynkithe hit · Acordaunt to Rayson
To tellen yowe / al þe conducioıı̄un
Of yche of hem / so as it semod me
And wiche þei weren and of what degree
And eke in what araye þat þei wer in
Þus at a knyght I wol fyrst be gynne
¶ ¶ A knyght þer was / and þᵗat a worthy man
Þat from þe tyme / þat he firste bigan
To rydin owte he loved chevallerye
Trouth and honowre / Fredam ⁊and crutesie
Full worthy was he / in his lordis werre
And þer to had he riden no man ferrer
As welle in crystendame / as heþennesse
Oueral honnoured for his worthinesse
At Alisaundir he was whanne it was wonne
Ful oftyn tymis he hade þe borde bygonne
Aboven alle þᵉ naciouns in peyne Pruse
In lecto hade he reyssed / and in Ruyce
No cristenman so ofte of his degree
In Garnade at þe seege / eke had he be
Of Algasire · and ryden in belmarye
At lyes was he · / and at Satalie
Whanne þei were wonne / and in gret see
At many a noble armee had he be
At mortell batayles / hade he be fifftene
And Fowghten for oure feythe at Thramassene
Withe in lystis thryse / And aye slayne his foo
Þis ilke worthy kneyght had ben Alsoo
Some tyme wᵗith þe lord of palatee
Ageynst a noþer heþyn in Turkye
And euermore / he had soủereyne pryse
And þaughe þat he was worthy he was wyse
Of al his porte as meke as any mayde
He neuer yit no velanye ne saide
In all his lyve / vn to noman̉er wyght
He was a verray ꝑperfite trewe kneyght
And For to tellen yowe of his Arraye
Hees hors were good / but he was not gay
Of Fustian he werid a Iupoune
Al bysmoteryd wᵗith his haburgeoune
For he was late ecomēn frome his viage
And went þus for to done his pilgrimage
Wᵗith him ther was his son a younge squier͗eA swyer
A lovyer A lusty bachelere
Withe lockis croulle · as þey were leyde in presse
Wel twenty yere of Age / he was I gesse
Of his stature / he was of evene lengthe
And wonderly deliủere / And gret of strenght
For he had ben som tyme in Cheuauchee
In flaundres Arthoys ⁊and in pycardye
And borne him welle / as of so litille space
In hope to stonde in his ladies grace
Enbrowded was he as it were a mede
Al ful of freysche flowris white ⁊and Rede
Synging he was or flytyng al þᵉ day
He was als Fresshe as is þᵉ monthe of may
Short was his goune wᵗith slevis long ⁊and wyde
Wele koude he sitte on horse / And fayre ryde
He coude songes make / And wel endite
Iouste eke and Daunce wel pourtray And evryte
So hote he lovid þat by þe nightertale
He slepte namore / þane doþe A nightyngale
Courteyse he was lowly ⁊and servisable
And kerff by fore his Fader at þe table
¶ A yoman had he And sarvauntꝭes namoo¶ þe yoman
As for that tyme / hym list to Riden soo
Þe wiche was cladde in coote ⁊and hode ⁊and grene
A sheff of pecok arowes withe hedis kene
Vndir his belt he bare full thrifftili
Wel covde he dresse / his takle yomanly
Hees Arowes drowped / nowght wᵗith federis lowe
And in his hande he bare Amytye bowe
A notte hede hadde he wᵗith a browne visage
Of wodocraff · koude he wele Al þusage
Vpon his arme / he bare A gay bracere
And by his syde / A swerd wᵗith a brode bokeler͗e
And on þat oþer syde / a Fyne Daggere
Syluer herneysid / and sharp as poynt on̄ spere
A cristofer on his brest of silver shene
An horne he bare þe bauderike was of grene
Sum Forster was he / soþely as I gesse
Þer was Also / a nonne A prioressea prioresse
Þat of hir smyling / was ful symple ⁊and coye
Her grettest oþe / was but by saynt loye
And she was clepid / madame Eglentyne
Ful wel she sange þe servyse devine
Entunid in her nose / ful semly
And frēnshe she spake / Right fayre and fetlye
Affter þe scole of Stratford of þe bowe
For frēnshe of paryse / was to hir on knowe
At þe mete welle etawght / was she wᵗith alle
She lete no morsell / from hir lippis falle
Ne wette her fyngeris / in her sause depe
Wele covde sheo carye / a morsel ⁊and welle kepe
Þat noo drope ne fel / vpon her bryste
In courtesye / was sette fully her lyste
Hir ouerlippe / wipid sheo so clene
Þat in hir cuppe þer was no ferþing sene
Of grece þat whan sheo had dronken hir draught
Ful semely Aftir hir mete sheo Raught
And sekirly she was of gret desporte
Ryght plesaunt and amyable of porte
And peynid her to countrefete þe chere
Of courte to beon / estatly of manere
And to be holden dingne of Reuerence
But for to spekyn / of hir consience
Sheo was so charitable · And pytowse
Þat sheo wold wepe yf sheo saughe Amouse
Kaught in a trappe · / yf hit were dede or bledde
Of smale houndis had she þat sheo fedde
Withe Rostyd flesshe / or mylke or wastillebred
Leueþe me sheo wepte / Ful sore whan on was dede
Or yf men smote hit / wᵗith A yerde smerte
And al was conciens · and tendre harte
Ful semly hir wimpille epinchid was
Hir nose was streyght / hir eyeghen grey as glas
Her mowthe mesurable / ful soffte ⁊and Rede
But sekurly sheo had A fayre forehede
Hit was Almoste A spane brode I trowe
Ne dowte yowe nought sheo was not vndirgrowe
Ryght Fetyse was hir cloke / as I was ware
Of smale corall Abovte hir arme she bare
A peyr͗e of bedis gaudeed All wᵗith grene
On weche þer hang / A broche of gold ful shene
Wher on was graven firste A crovnid A
And Aftir Amor vincit omnia
A noþer nonne with hir / þoo had she
That was her chapellayne / and prestes three
A monke þer was a Feyre for þe mastryeA monke
An outryder / þat lovid venerie
A manly man / to ben an Abbot Able
Full many a deynte hors had he in stable
And whan he Rode he mythe his bridil here
Gyngeling / in a whistelyng wynde als clere
And eke als lowde as doþe þe Chapelle belle
Þer as this lord was keper of þe Celle
Þe rule of saint Maure or of Seint Benette
By cause þat it was olde and sumdele streyte
Þis ilke monke / leet old thyngꝭes passe
And held Aftir þe · nuwe worlde þe space
He gave not of þe texst a pulled henne
Þat seyþe þat hunteris beon nought hooly menne
Ne that a monke · whan he is Recchelesse
Is likenid til a fishe al watelesse
Þat is to seyne · a monke owte of þᵉ clostre
But thilke texste helde he not worthe an oystre
And I Sayde his opynioune / was good
What shulde he studye and make hym selven woode
Vpon A booke Alwey in cloystre poure
Or swynke wᵗith his hondis or laboure
As austyn bid how shalle þe world be servid
Lete Austyn have / his swinke to hym reservid
Þer for he was a prikasour a right¶noᵃta pShirle
Grehoundis he hade / als swyffte as Fovle of flyte
Of priking and of huntyng for þᵉ hare
Was al his lyfe / For noo coste wold he spare
I seghe his sleves / pourfiled at þᵉ honde
Withe grys and þᵗat þᵉ fynest in a londe
And for to fasten his hode vndir his chynne
He had of golde ewroute A coryovse pynne
A love knotte in þe gret ende graven was
His hede was ballid þᵗat shone as ony glasse
And eke his face / as he had ben anoynte
He was a lorde fulle fatte / and in good poynte
Hees yen stepe / and Roullyng in his hede
Þat steymd as þe fourneys made of lede
Hees boutis souple / his horse in grete estate
Nowe certaynly · he was A feyr͗e prelate
He nas not pale as a forpyned gooste
A fatte swanne loved he best of any Roste
His palfreye was as browne as is burye
A Frere þer was a wantone ⁊and a murye
A Limytoure Right a ful solempne man
In Al þe orderis foure is non þᵗat can
So mochil of dalyaunce and fayr͗e langage
For he hade made ful many mariage
Of yovnge wymmen at his oune coste
Vn to his ordre / he was A noble poste
Ful welbelouid and famulier was he
Wᵗith Frankeleynis ouir al in his cuntree
And wᵗith þe worthy wymmen of þᵉ toune
For he hadde power of Conffescione
And saide hym selfe welmore þan a curat
For of his ordre / he was lysenciate
Fulle swetly hard he / confessioune
And plesaunt was his Absolucioune
He was an Esy man to geve penaunce
Þer as he wyste / to have a good pytaunce
For on to povre ordre / for to gyve
Is gret signe þat a man is wele eshreyve
For yf he gaf / he durst welle make a vaunte
He wyste ther by / a man was Repentaunte
For many Aman is so herde of herte
He may not wepe / al þough hym sore smerte
Þer for in stede of wepyng / And prayers
Men mot gyve silver on to þᵉ pore freres
His typpet was ay farsid ful of knyvis
And of pynnis to gyve þe fayre wyves
And certainly he had a mery noote
Welle coude he syngen and pleyne on a Rote
Of yeddinges he bare vtterly þe pryse
His nekke als white as is þᵉ flore de lysea lylye
Þer to he was als stronge as Chaumpyoune
He knowe þe tavernis welle in every tovne
And everiche hostellier / and Tapistier
Bette þane a lasier / or a begstier
For vn to suche a worthy man as he
Acordid nought / as by his faculte
To have wᵗith such seke laisers acqveyntaunce
It is not honeste it may no thyng Avaunce
As For to dele / wᵗith any suche pouraille
But all wᵗith Riche / and sellers of victayle
And ouer al þer as proufyte shoulde Aryse
Courtese he was And lowly of service
Þer nas noman no wher so vertuous
He was þᵉ best begger / in his house
For þauhe A wedowe nad but oon shoo
So plesaunt was his Inprincipio
Þat he wold have / A ferthyng or he went
His purchas was wele bett̉er þan was his rent
And Rage he kouþe Right as doithe A whelpe
In love dayes þer kouþe he mochel helpe
For þer he Nas not lyche / A Cloystorier
Wᵗith þe thredbare cope / as a poure scolier
But he was liche Amaistre / or A pope
Of dowble worstede / was his semy cope
Þᵗat Rounded as A belle / owte of þe presse
Somwhat he lypsid / for his wantounesse
To make his Englisshe swete / vpon his tong
And in his harpyng whan þᵗat he had songe
Hees eyen twenkelid in his hede aright
As don þeos sterres / in þe Frosty nyght
Þis worthy lemetoure / was cleped hewberd
¶ A marchaunde was þer / with a Fourched berd¶ A marchaunde
In motley and heyghe on hors he satte
Vpon his hede / A Flaundrisshe bever hatte
Hees botys claspid / Fayre and fetysely
And al his Raysonis he speke ful solemply
Shewyng Al weyes þe encresse of his wynnyng
He wold þe see were kepte for Any thyng
Be twyxste · Midilborow ⁊and orwell
Wele coude he by eschaunge sheldis selle
Þis worthy man Ful welle his witte bysette
Ther wist noo wyght þᵗat he was in dette
So estately was he of governaunce
Wᵗith his Bargaynes / and wᵗith his chevissaunce
For soþe he was A worthye man wᵗith al
But soþe to sayn / I not howe men him calle
¶ A Clerke þer was of Oxenford AlsoA clerke
Þat vn to logyke / had he long goo
Als lene was his hors as is a Rake
And he nas nowte fatte I vndirtake
But loked holow / And þer to sobourly
Ful thredbare was is ouerest courtpy
For he nade goton hym / no benefyse
Ne was so worldly to have an office
For him was lever haue / at his beddis hede
Twenty bookes clade / in blake or Rede
Of Aristotle and his phelosophie
Þanne Robes Riche / or Fydille or Savtrie
But al by þᵗat he was Aphilesopher
Yette had he but A litill gold in coffre
For Al þat he myght / of his frendis hent
Vppon his bookꝭes / and lernyng he hit spent
And besyly gane for þe soules pray
Of hem þat fonde him / wherwithe to scoley
Of studye toke he / moost cure an hede
Nought oon word spake he more þan was nede
And þat was sayd / in fourme ⁊and Reuerence
And short and quike / and ful of hye sentence
Sownynge in moral vertu / was his speche
And gladlye wold he lerne / and gladly teche
A Sargeaunt of þe lawe / ful ware ⁊and wyse
Þat often tymes had ben at parvys
Þat was Also fulle riche off excellens
Discret he was / and of gret Reuerence
Him semid suche / heos wordis were so wyse
Iustice Ful oftyn he was / in Assyse
By patente / and by pleyne coumyssion
For his syens and for his hye renoune
Of Fees and roobis had he many oon
So gret a purchassoure / nas noo whernoon
Al was phesymple to him in effecte
His purchasing might not ben infecte bet
No wher so busy a man as he þer nas
And yette hym semyd besyer þan he was
In termes had he / domes And Cases alle
Þat frome þe tyme of kyng William were falle
Þer to he coude Endite / and make a thyng
Þer kowþe no wight pynche as his wreytyng
And euery statute kouþe he playn be Roote
He Rood homly in a medlee Coote
Girt wᵗith a seynte of silke with barres smale
Of his arraye / telle I noo lenger tale
A Frankeleyne was þer in his compaignye
White was his berd as is þe dayessye
Of his compleccion he is sangwyne
Wel loved he by þe morowyn a soppe in weyne
To lyven in delite · euer was his wonne
For he was Epicurus owne sonni deus deliciciȝ
Wiche helde opyneoun þat playn delite
Was werray felicitee / parfyte
An hovseholder / and þᵗat a gret was he
Saynt Iulian · he was in his cuntrey¶i a gode hberger
His bred his Ale was Alweys Aftir oon
A better envyned man · was noo where noon
Wᵗithoute bakemete was nevermore his house
Of fushe of Flesshe and þᵗat so plentivouse
Hit snede in his house mete ⁊and drynke
Of Alle Deyntees · þat man koude ought bethynke
Afftir þe sundery saysonis of þe yeere
So chaunged he his mete and his soupere
Full many A fatte parteriche · had he in muwe
And many A breme / pyke And luce In stue
Woo was his Cooke but yf his sauce ay were
Poynyant and sharpe / and Redy al his gere
His table dormant in his halle Alweye
Stode Redye couerd / al þe long daye
At sessiouns þer was he lord ⁊and syre
Wel offte syþes he was knyght of þe shyre
And Anlase and a Gipsere al of silke
Heng at his girdelle whyte as any mylke
A Shirreff hade he ben And a countour
Was nowher suche a worþy vavassoureAn haburdassher
An haburdassher And A Carpentier
A webbe A dyer and a Tappissier
Wiche were cladde al in on liueree
Of A solempne and grete fraternitee
Ful fresshe and newe / al her gere epiked was
Hir knyves nerenot Tappid withe brasse
But al wᵗith siluer wrought Ful clene And wele
Hir girdelis and hir powches eủerye dele
Wele semed eche of hem / a feyr͗e Burgeys
To sitten in a yeldehalle / on hye deyse
Euerych for þe wisdom þᵗat he can
Was shaply for ben An Alderman
For cateyle had they enoughe and Rent
And eke hir wyves wolde hit welle Assent
Ellys certaynly were they foule to blame
It is ful faire to be clepid madame
And at þe vigylles gone all oþer be fore
To have hir mantell ryallyche ebore
A cooke they hadde wᵗith hem for þe noones
To boyle the chekonis wᵗith þe marybonis
And poudre marchaunt · tarte wᵗith galingale
Welle koude he knowe A drawte of london ale
He kouþe Roste ⁊and boyle and seþe ⁊and freye
Maken mortreaux · and wel bake A pye
But harme hit was gret as thought me
Þat on his shyn / a mormal had he
For blāmmangre þat made he with þᵉ best
A Shipman was þeir͗e wonneng far by west
He Rode vppon a Rouncay / as he kouþe
For ought I wot he was of Dertemouþe
In a goune of falding vn to þe knee
A Dagger honging in a lace hade he
Aboute his necke / vnder his arome downe
Þe hote somer / hade made his huwe Albrovne
And certainly / he was a goode felawe
Ful many A dravght of wyne had he drawe
From Bourdeux wardes whiles þe Chapman sleepe
Of nyce consience · toke he litill kepe
Iff þat he faught and had þe hyer hande
By water he sent hem home / to euery lande
But of his crafte to Reken welle hes tydis
Hes streems and hees daungers him besidis
His herborowe his mony his lodemanage
Þer nas non suche frome hull vn to Cartage
Herdye he was / and wyse to vndir take
Wᵗith many A tempest had his berde be shake
He knew well all þe havens as thei were
Forme Goutland to þe Cape de fynestre
And euery Cricke · in Brettaigne and in spaigne
His Barge eclepid was þe maudeleyne
Wᵗith vs was eke A Doctoure of fysike
In All þis worlde þer was noon him like
To speke of Phisik · and of surgerye
For he was grovndid in Astronomye
He kepte his paciens A ful grete dele
In þe houres by magyk naturelle
Ful welle kouþe he fortune þascendent
Of heos ymages for his paciens
He knewe þe cause of euerye maladye
Were hit of hete of colde moyste or drye
Where of engenderid and off what humer
He was A werray ꝑparfite practisoure
Þe cavse he knewe ⁊and of his harome þᵉ Roote
A noon he gafe þe seke man his boote
Ful Redy had he heos Appoticaryes
To send him draggees and þeyre letwaryes
For yche of hem made oþer for to wynne
Her frenship nas not nuwe for to be gynne
Wele knewe he þe olde Escalapius
And discorides eke and him Ruphus
Wyse ypocrashalye⁊andGalyene
SerapyonRaȝie and Auiyȝene
AueriosDamascien and Constantyne
Bernerd and Gatisdene and Gylbertyne
Of his dyete / mesurable was he
For he vsed no suꝑperfluite
But of gret nereshyng / And degestible
His studye was but litell on þe bible
In Sangwyne and in pers he cladde was al
Lyned wᵗith taffata and withe sendall
And yete he was but esy of dispence
He kepte þat he wanne / in þe pestelence
For gold in phisike / is a cordialle
Þer fore he lovid golde in speciallenᵃotaꝑper Shirle
A goode wyff þer was of besydes bathe¶ the wyff off bathA good wyf of Bathe
But sheoo was sumdele defe ⁊and þᵗat was skaþe
Of clothe makyng sheo hade suche þanne an haunte
Sheo passithe hem / of þrre and of Gaunte
In Al þe parishe wyf þanne was þer noone
That to the offering / to fore her shulde goiþe
And yf þer did certaine þanne wrothe was shee
Þat she hadde lost / al hir hole charitee
Hir kouerchiefis wel fyne were of grounde
I dourst wel swere · þey wer worth x pounde
That on A sonday were vppon her hede
Hir hosyn were of Fyne skarlette Rede
Ful streyte eteyed And shoos ful moyste ⁊and newe
Bolde was hir face ⁊and fayre ⁊and Rede of huwe
Sheo was a worthye woman al hir live
Husbandes at þe chirche dore had shoo had fyve
Withe owtēn oþer cumpanye / in yowþe
But ther of nedithe nought to speke as nowe
And thryes hade sheo beon / at Ierusalem
Sheo had passid many A fulle straunge streme
At Rome sheo had ben and at grate Bouleyne
In galys at saynt Iame · and at couloyne
Sheo kouþe moche on wanderyng by þᵉ weye
Gate toþed was sheo sooþelye to saye
Vppon an Aumbeller Esely she satte
Ewympuled wele / and on her hede An hatte
Als brode as is A bokeler or a targe
A foote mantell Abovte her hippis large
And on her fete / A peyre of sporis sharpe
In pheleshipe wel kouþe sheo / laughe ⁊and carpe
Of Remedyes of love / sheo knewe par chaunce
For sheo kouþe / of þᵗat arte þolde daunce
A good man was þer / of Religioune
And was A poure ꝑparsoune of A tovne
But Riche he was / of holy thought ⁊and werke
He was Also A lernid man A Clerk
Þat cristꝭes gospelle · trvly wolde Aye preche
His parrisshens devoutly wold he teche
Bennigne he was / and wondir deligent
And in Adversyte · ful pacyent
And suche he was preeved ofte sithis
Ful loþe were hym to curssen for his tyþes
But raþer wolde he yeven · owte of dowte
Vn to his poure parisshenis him Aboute
Of heos offeryngꝭes · And of his substaunce
He kouþe in litil thyng / have suffisaunce
Wide was his parishe howses fer A sondre
But he ne leffte neyþer for Reyne ne thundre
In sekenesse ne in mischef to vesite
Þe firþeste in his parische muche ⁊and lyte
Vpon his Fete / And In his hande a staffe
Þis noble Ensample / vn to heos sheope he gaffe
Þat firste he wrought / And Afftirwardis he taught
Ovte of þe gospell he þoo wordis kaught
And this figure / he added eke þer too
Þat yf golde þouste / what shall þanne yren doo
For yf A prest beo foule / on whom we truste
No wondir is þaughe levde men þanne Ruste
Gret shame it is yf A preeste take kepe
A shitten shepard And A clene shepe
Wel aught A prest / ensaumple for to gyve
By his clennes howe þᵗat his sheope shulde lyve
He should nought sette / his benyfise to hire
And lete his sheope / be comberid in þe myre
And Rynne to london · vn to saynt poules
To sechin him a chaunterye for soulis
Or wᵗith a broþerhed · to ben wᵗith holde
But dwelle at home / and kepe welle his folde
So þat þe wolfe make hit not miscarye
He was a sheparde / and not a mercenarye
And þaughe he holy were / and vertuous
He nas not to synfull folke despitouse
Ne of his speche daungerovse ne digne
But in his techyng descrete and benigne
To drawen folke · to hevene by fayrnesse
In good Ensample · was his bessinesse
But it were ony parsone · obstinate
What so he were of heght or lowe estate
Him wolde he snibbe sharply for þᵉ noons
A bett̉er prest I trowe þat nowher non is
He wayted affter no pompe ne Reuerence
Ne maked him A spiced conciens
But crystꝭes love and his Apostelis twelve
He taught but first he felowed it him selve
Wᵗith him þer was a ploughman his owne broþ̉erA plouman
Þᵗat hade eladde of dongge ful many A foþer
A ful gret swynker And a trewe was he
Liuing in pes ay ⁊and in charitee
God louid he beste wᵗith al his hole herte
At Al tymis þaughe he gamed or smerte
And þanne his neghbore · as he dide him selve
He wolde thresshe · And þer to dyke ⁊and delve
For · Crystꝭes sake for every poure wight
Wᵗith outen hire yf hit lay in his myght
Heos tiþes payde · he alle fayre ⁊and welle
Boþe of his propre swynke / and his kataele
In A taberd he Rode vp on a mere
Þer was Also A Ryve ⁊and A Mylner¶A milner
A Sompner And A pardoner Also
A Maunciple · and my selff þ̉er were no moo
The mylner was a stoute carlle for þᵉ noones
Right bigge he was of braune ⁊and eke of bones
Þat proeued welle · for oueral wher he came
At wrastelyng he wold have þᵉ Ram
He was short sholderid a thikke knarre
Þer nas noon dore he wold heve ought of harre
Or breke it at a Rynnygne wᵗith his hede
His berd as any sweyne · or Fox was rede
And þer to brode as þaughe it were Aspade
Vppon þe coppe · Right of his nose he hade
A wrette and þer on stonde A tuffte of heris
Rede as þᵉ Brystelis of A sowes eris
Heos nostrelles blake were ⁊and weyde
A swerd ⁊and A bokeler bare he be his side
His mowthe Als gret as was an huge furneyse
He was A Iangeler / and a golierdeys
And þat was most of synne · and harlotryes
He kouþe stele corne · and tolle it thryes
And yette he hadde A thumbe of golde ꝑpardee
A weyte coote ⁊and A blewe hode werid hee
A Baggpype welle kouþe he blowe ⁊and sowne
And þer wᵗithal he browte vs ovte of toune
A gentil Maunsiple was þer of þe temple
Of whome Achatours mighten take ensaumple
For to be wyse in bying of vitayle
For whethir þᵗat he paid or toke by tayle
Algate he A waytid soo in his Achatee
Þat he was by forne ⁊and in gode state
Now is not þat of god / A ful hy grace
Þᵗat suche A lewde manis witte shalle passe
Þe wysdome of an hepe of lernid men
Of mastirs had he moo þane thryes ten
That wer͗e of lawe · expert and curyous
Of wiche þer were A douszein in þat hovse
Worthye to ben stewardis of Rent ⁊and lande
Of any lordꝭes þat is in Englond
To make him lyve by his ꝓpropre good
In honoure dettelesse but yf he were woode
Or lyve als scarslye · as him list desire
And Able for to helpen All Ashire
In any case þᵗat might falle or happe
And yette þis maunsiple sette þeyre aller cappe
Þe Reve was A sklendir colorike man
Hes berde was shave als neyghe as eủer he can
Hes here was by hes erys ful Rounde shorne
His toppe was tonsured lyche A preost byfore
Full long were heos leggꝭes · and fulle lene
Elyche A staffe þer nas no calffe essene
Welle kouþe he kepe A garnar or a bynne
Þer nas non auditoure · kouþe on him wynne
Wele wist he by þe drought · and by þe Reyne
Þe yeldyng of his sedee · and of his greyne
Hes lordis shepe his nete his dayerye
¶ His sweyne his store his horsse ⁊and his pultrye
Was hooly in this Reuis governinge
And by covenaunt gave his Rekenyng
Sith that his lord was twenty yere of age
Þer kouþe no man bring him in Arerage
Þer nas baylye ne herde ne oþir hyne
Þat he ne knewe · his sleyght and his couvyne
Þei were adradde of him as of þᵉ dethe
Hes wounyng was ful fayr͗e vppon an hethe
Wᵗith grene trees be shadowid was his place
He kouþe welbetter þanne his lorde purchase
Ful Riche he was / Astorid prevelye
His lorde wele kouþe he plesyn suttelye
To geve and lene him of his oune goode
A have A thanke And yitte A cote an hode
In youþe he hadde lerned / a goode mistere
He was A wel good wreyght · a Carpenter

l.hi: Þis Reve satte vpon A Right goode stotte
A long sircote of perse he hadde vppon
And by his side · he bare A Rusty blade

div.l: Of norfolke was þis Reve of wiche I telle
Be sides a towne þᵗat hitaght baldeswell
Tukked he was as is A Frere A boute
And ever he Roode þe hynmast of oure Route
A sumpnour was þer wᵗith vs in placeA sompnonre
Þat hade a fuyry red Cherubyns face
For saucefleme he was / wᵗith yene narowe
Als lecherous he was as is A sparowe
Wᵗith scalled browes blake ⁊and pillid berde
Of his visage chylderne were A ferde
Þer nas qviksiluer · lytarge or brȳmston
Boras or sour ne oyle of tartre noone
Ne oynement þat wold clens and byte
Ne him might helpen of his wheolkes whyte
Nor of þe knobbis sittyng on his cheokes
Wel loved he garlec onyonis and leekys
And for to drynke strong weyne rede as bloode
Þanne wolde he speke and crye as he were woode
And whanne þat he weldronkon had þe wyne
Þanne wolde he speke · no worde but latyne
A fewe termes had he þanne two or three
That he had leorned owte of some decree
No wondir is he harde hit al the daye
And eke yee konwe hit wele howe þᵗat a Iaye
Can clepe watte as wele as can þe pope
But who so kouþe in oþer thinge him grope
Þanne hadde he spent alle his philosophie
Ay qvestio quid Iuris wolde he crye
He was A gentil / harlote and A kuynde
A better felowe / shalle man nowher fynd
He wolde wele souffre · for A quarte of wyne
A good felowe to have his concubyne
A twelvemonþe and excuse him at the fulle
Ful prevelye eke A Fynche kouþe he pulle
And yf he fonde o wher A good felowe
He wold techin him to have non Auve
In suche cas of þerchedeakens course
But yf manis soule were in his purse
For in his poursse he shulde punysshed bee
Pourse is þe Erchedeakonis hele saide he
But wel I wot he hed right indede
Of courssing aught ych giltiman him drede
For corse wol sleo · right as soyling saueþe
And Also wa him · of A significauit
In daungere had he · right at his owne guyse
Þe yong gyrlles of al þat diosice
And knew her counsale / and what was hir Rede
A garland had he sette vppon his hede
Als grete as it were for an Ale stake
A bokeler had he made hym of A cake
Wᵗith him þer rode · A gentil pardoner¶A padonner
Of Rouncivale · his freonde ⁊and his compere
Þat streyte was coume from þe covrte of Rome
Ful lowde he songe come hedir love tome
Þis Sompnour bore to hym a stiffe bourdoun
Was never trompe of vnde ne grete of sown
Þis pardoner hadde here as yelowe as waxsse
But smooþe hit hang / as doþe astrike of flaxsse
By ownces hong þe lookes þᵗat he hadde
And þer wᵗith al hees sholders ouer spradde
But thynne they laye by culponis oon ⁊and oon
And hood for Iolyvetee · ne werid he noon
For hit was trussid vp in his wallette
Him thought he Rode · Al of þᵉ nuwe Iette

l.hi: Suche glaring eyen · had he as and hare

div.l: A vernicle hade he sewed wppon his cappe
And his walet beforne · him in his lappe
Brettfulle of pardoune · comēn frome Rome al hoote
A voyce had he als smal / as any goote
No berd had he · ne neuermore shuld have
Als smoþe it was as it were late shave
I trowe he were A geldyng or a mare
But of his craffte frome Berwike in to ware
Ne was þer suche Anoþ̉er pardoner
For in his wallet he hade Apilowbere
Wich þat he saide · was oure ladies veyle
He saide he hade A gobette · of þe sayle
Þat saint petre hade · whanne þᵗat he went
Vpon þe see · til Ihesus crist him hent
He hade A Croysser of laton ful of stonis
And In a glasse he hadde pigges bonis
But with þoos relikes whanne þᵗat he fonde
A poure persone dwellyng vpon londe
Vppon A day · he gate hym more moneye
Þanne þᵗat þᵉ persone gate · in monthes tweye
And þus wᵗith feyned flateryng and Iapes
He made þe pesone · and þe people heos Apes
But trewly to tellyn at þe laste
He was in cherche A nobele ecclesiate
Wel kouþe he Rede A lesson or A storye
But Alderbest he sang an offratorye
For wel he wist whanne þat song was sunge
He must preche · And wel a file his tonge
To wynne siluer · as þat he wel coude
Þer fore he song so merely and loude
Now have I tolde yowe · sooþely in A clause
Þe state þarraye þe noumbre ⁊and þe cause
Why þᵗat assembled was / þis compaignye
In sothewerke at þis Ientile hostelarye
Þᵗat heght þe taberd fast by þe belle
But now is tyme vn to to yowe to telle
Howe þᵗat wee beeryn vs þᵗat ilke night
Whanne we were in þᵗat hostelarye alight
And afftir wolle I telle yow of oure viage
Wᵗith alle þe Reminavnte · of oure pilgrimage
But first I pray yow of yovre courtesye
Þᵗat ye dyrette it nought · my vilanye
Þoughe þᵗat I speke pleynly in this mater
To tellen yowe þeyre wordes and þeyre chere
Ne þaughe I speke · þeyre wordes propurlye
For þis ye knowen alle / als welle as I
Who so shalle telle atale / Aftir A man
He mote Reherse als nyhe as eủer he can
Eueryche A word yf hit be in his charge
Al speke he neuer / so Rudly ⁊and large
Or ell he mut telle his tale on trewe
Or feyne thynges or fynden wordes newe
He may not spare · al þouhe he were his broþ̉er
He most Als wele · seye · on worde as a noþ̉er
Criste spake him selfe · ful brode in holy wrytte
And welle yee witte · no velany is it
Eke Plato seyþe who so can him Rede
Þe wordis mote nede be cousin to þᵉ dede
Also I pray yowe / þᵗat ye for give hit me
Al have I not / sette folke in hir degree
Here in þis talis / as þat they shulde stande
My witte is short ye may wele vndirstonde
Grete chere made oure hoste vs euerych oon
And to þe souper / sette he vs Anoon
He servid vs wᵗith vitaillꝭes of þe beste
Strong was þe wyne and wele to drinke vs liste
A Semly man · oure host was wᵗithal
Ye for to ben A marchal of An halle
A large man he was wᵗith yen stepe
A Feyrer bourgeys / is þer non in chepe
Bold of his speche · and wyse ⁊and wel etaught
And of manhode him lacked right naught
Eke þer to right a mury man
And Affter soper pleyen þus he gan
And spake of mirthe · a monges oþ̉er thinges
Whanne þᵗat he had made oure Rekeninges
And saide þus nowe lordingis trewely
Ye be to me welcom · right hertlye
For by my trowthe · yf þat I Shal not lye
I sawe not this yere so mury A compeny
At oons in þis harborowe / as is nowe
Fayn wold I do yowe myrth and I wiste howe
And wol yee here what I am nowe be thowghet
To don yowe eese and hit shall cost yow noute
Ye gon to Cavntirbury god yow spede
Þe blissfull martir qvite yow yowre mede
And wel I wote as ye gon by the weye
Yᵉ shapen yow to talen ⁊and to pleye
For trewly coumfort / ne no mirthe is noon
To Riden by the wey · als Doumbe as a stone
And ther fore wolle I Fynde · yow Disport
As I Saed erste and don yow some comforte
For yf yow likeþe all by oon Assent
For to stonde at my Iugement
And for to wirchen as I Shalle yow saye
To morow whan ye Riden by þᵉ weye
Nowe by my fader sowle þᵗat is ded
But yee be mury I wol gyve yow my hede
Holdiþe vp youre handis · wᵗith oute more speche
Oure counsaile was not long for to seche
Vs thought it was not worthe · to make it wys
And grauntid him wᵗith outen more Avise
And prayde him saye his verdight as him liste
Lordingis quod he now herkenith for þᵉ beste
But take hit not I pray yow in þis deyneþe ordenaunce of hooste
Þis is þe poynt to speke short ⁊and pleyn
Þat eche of yowe to shorten oþeos weye
In this wiage shalle telle · tales tweye
To Cauntourebyri I mene it right soo
And homewardis . he shal telle A noþ̉er too
Of Aventouris whylom þat haue be falle
And wiche of yowe þᵗat berithe him beste of Alle
Þat is to seyne / þat tellithe in this caas
Tales of best sentens · And moste solace
Shalle have A souꝑper / at oure Alderscoste
Here in this place sittyng by þis poste
Whanne þᵗat we comen A gayne from Caunt̉erbyri
And for make yow þe more mury
I wolle my selfe · wᵗith yow gladlye Ride
Right at myn owne coste · and beo yoᵘur guyde
And whoo soo wille · my Iugement wᵗith seye
Shalle paye al þᵗat we spende by þe weye
And yf yee vowchensauffe þᵗat it be soo
Telle me anoon / wᵗith owten wordis moo
And I wolle erly shapen me þer fore
Þis thyng was graunted and oure oþes swore
Wᵗith Ful good hert and preyden him Alsoo
Þᵗat he wold wouchesaff so to doo
And þat he wolde be þus oure governoure
And of owre tales · Iuge ⁊and Reportoure
And sette A sopper at A serten pris
For we weel ben at his devisee
In heght and lowe · and þus by oon Assent
We ben A cordid to þis Iugement
And þer vpon þe weyne was fette A noon
We dronke ⁊and to Reste went everiche oon
Withe outen ony lenger tareyng
A morowe · whan þe day be gan to spryng
Vp Roos oure hooste · and was oure Alder cokke
And gaderid vs to gedir · in A Flocke
And forthe we Redyn A feyre esye pase
Vn to þe watering plase of seynt Thomᵃas
And þer ovre hooste · gan his hors A reste
And saide lordyngis · herkenithe yf ye liste
Yee wote yowr͗e forwarde / if I it yowe recorde
Yf evyn song ⁊and morowe song acorde
Lete seo nowe who shall telle þe firste tale
Als euer mot I drynke weyne or Ale
Who soo beo rekkelle to my Iugement
Shal pay for Al þᵗat by þe wey is spent
Now draueþᵉ cutte · or þᵗat we furþer twynne
Loke wiche þat haþe þe shortest shall byginne
¶ Sir knight quod he · my maister ⁊and my lorde
Now drawethe cutte for þat is myn Acorde
Comiþe nere quod he my lady prioresse
And sir Clerke lat be yowre shamefastenesse
Ne studyeþe lay hond to euerye man
Anoon til drawe euery wight bygan
And shortly for to tellen as hit was
Were it by Aventure · or soorte or cas
Þe sooþe is þis þe cutte fel to þᵉ knyght
Of wiche fulle blithe And glad was eủery wight
And tel he mot his tale · as is raysoun
By forwardes pleyne / And Composicioun
As ye have harde what nedeþe wordes moo
And whan þis good man saughe / þᵗat it was soo
As he þᵗat was wys and obedient
To kepe his forward · by his free Assent
And sayde syþen I shalle begynne þe game
What welcom be þe cutte on goddis name
Now late vs Ride · and herkenithe what I saye
And wᵗith þat worde we Riden forthe oure weye
Þus he bygan · wᵗith Right A goodly chere
His tale A noon And sayde / as ye may here

hi.hi: Loo here eondiþe þe prologe of þe Knightes tale / and Folowyng þe knyght be gynnithe to telle his tale

div.l: Wylom was as olde storyes tellyn vs
Þer was a duke þᵗat heyghte theseus
Of Atthens he was lord and gouernoᵘur
And in his tyme such a gret conqueroure
Þat suche oon was þer noon ondir þᵉ son
Fulle manye A Riche countrey had he wonne
What wᵗith his wysdom and his Chivalrye
He conquered al þe regne of femynye
Þat whilome was eclepid loo Cithia
And weddid þe fayre qvene ypolita
And browght hir home wᵗith him in his cuntree
Wᵗith mouche glorie / and grete solempnite
And eke hir Sistre faire Emyly
And thus with victorie / and melodye
Late I this noble duke / to Atthens ryde
And al his hooste · in armes him be side
And certes yf it nere · nought long to here
I wold have told fully þe hoole man̉ere
How wonnen was þe Reingne of Femynye
By Theseus / and by his Chevalrye
And of the grete Bataille for þe noons
ByAvixsse Atthenes and gret Amazones
And how assegged was · ypolita
Þe fayre noble qvene of · Cithia
And of þe feste / þᵗat was at hir weddynge
And of þe tempeste · at hir home comyng
But al þᵗat thynge · I mot as nowe forbere
I haue god wot / a large felde to eyre
Fulle weyke been þe oxsen in my ploughe
Þe Remenaunt of þis tale · is long enought
I wolle not letten eke / noon of þis Route
Lete eủery felowe telle his tale Aboute
And late see nowe · whoo shalle þe soper wynne
For þer I lefte · I wolle Ageyne be gynne
Þis duke of whome I make here mencionhere þe knyght tellith forþe
Whane he was comen / Almoste to þᵉ toune
In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
He was ware as he caste his eyeght Asyde
Where þᵗat þere knelid / in his heygh weye
A compainye of ladies / ay tweye ⁊and tweye
Eche afftir oþer · cloothid in cloothis blake
But suche A noþer crye · ⁊and suche a woo þey make
Þat in this world nys creatowre lyving
Þat herde suche anoþer weymentyng
And of this crye þei nold never stinte
Til thei þe Reins of his bridill hente
What folke been yee / þat at myn home comyng
Partourben so my feste wigh criyng
Quod theseus have yee so gret envye
Of myn honoure þᵗat þus compleyne ⁊and crye
Or who hathe yowe · misboden or offendid
Telle hit me yf it may been Amendid
And why þᵗat ye ben cloþid thus in blakke
Þe Eldeste ladye / of hem alle þan spake
Whanne sheo hade swowned / wᵗith a dedly chere
Þᵗat it was Routhe / for to seen ⁊and here
Sheo saide lord to whome Fortune haþᵉ yiven
Victorye and as A conqueroure to lyven
Noute grevith vs youre glorie ⁊and youre hounore
But we beseche yowe of mercy and socoure
Have mercy on oure woo / and oure distresse
Some drope of mercy thorught yoᵘur gentilnesse
Vppon vs wrecchid wymmen lete yee falle
For certes lorde · þer is noon of vs Alle
Þat she nathe ben a duchesse or a qvene
Nowe be we caytyfis / as it is wel seene
Thanked be fortune and hir fals whele
Þat noon estate assureþe to beo welle
For certeyse lord tabyde yoᵘur presence
Here in this temple / of þe goddesse Clemence
We have beon waytyng al þis fourtenyght
Helpe vs nowe lord / sith hit lithe in þi myght
I wrechche whiche / þat wepe ⁊and weyle thus
Was whylome wyff / of kyng Cappaneus
Þat straff / at Thebes / curssid bee þat Daye
And al we þᵗat beon / in this loo Arraye
Þat maken al · þis lamentacion
We losten alle oure husbondis at þᵗat towne
Whyle þᵗat þassegge / þer Aboutes laye
And yette nowe crien þe olde wellawaye
Þat lord is nowe of Thebese þe Site
Fulfillid of Ire · and of inyqvitee
He for dyspite and for his thyrannye
To done þe deede bodies vilanye
Of alle oure lordes wiche þᵗat beon slawe
Haþe alle þe bodyes vppon an hepe edrawe
And wolle not soufre hem by noon assent
Neyþer to beon eburied / nouþer ebrent
But makeþe houndes to ete them in dispite
And wᵗith þat worde · wᵗithouten more Respite
Þei Fallen grouffe · and cryden pitovselye
Have on vs wrecched wommen some mercy
And lete oure sorowe sinken in thin herte
Þis gentil Duk Downe frome his coursier sterte
Wᵗith herte petouse whanne he hard hem speke
Him thoute þᵗat his hert wold al to breke
Whan he sawhe hem / so pytouse ⁊and so mate
Þᵗat whilome weren of so gret estate
And in his armes · he hem alle vppehente
Comfortyng hem wᵗithalle his hole Intente
And swore his ooþe as he was trewe kneyght
That he wold don so ferforthelye his myght
Vppon that tiraunt Creon hem to wreke
Þat alle þe people of Grece shulden speke
How creon was of · Theseus eservid
As he þat hade his dethe ful wele diseruid
And Right A noon · wᵗithouten more A bode
His banner he desplayed ⁊and forþe Rode
To thebes ward and al his oste besyde
No nerre Athenes · wolde he goo nor Ride
Ne take his Reste fully half A day
But outwardis on his waye þᵗat night he laye
And sent Anoon Ypolita þe Quene
And Emelye hir yownge sistre so shene
Vn to þe tovne of Athenes to dwelle
And forþe he Rideþe / þer nys namore to telle
Þe rede statute / of Mars wᵗith spere and targe
So shynythe in his whyte baner so large
Þat alle þe feld glytterid vp And Doune
And by his banner borne · is his penoune
Of gold ful Riche in wiche ther was ebete
Þe Mynataure / þe wiche he wane in Crete
Þus Ridethe this Duke þus Ridethe þis cōnquerovr͗e
Wᵗithal his hooste · of chevalerye þe floure
Tyl þᵗat he came to · Thebes and Alight
Faire in A felde · þer as he thought fyght
But shortly for to speken of this thyng
Wᵗith Creon wiche wiche þat was of Thebes kyng
He faught ⁊and slowe him manly as A knyght
In playn Battayle / And putte þe folke to flyght
And by assente he wanne þe Citee afftre
And Rente A downe booþe walle ⁊and sparre ⁊and Rafter
And to þᵉ ladyes he Restorid ageyne
The bones of þeire frendis eslyene
To don obsequeus · as was þoo the guyse
But it were al to long for to devise
The gret clamoure · and þe wementyng
Þᵗat þᵉ ladies made at þᵉ brynnyng
Off þe bodies and þe gret honoure
Þat Theseus þe noble cōnqveroure
Dooþe to þe bodies · whanne þey from hym wente
But shortly for to telle is myne entente
Whan þᵗat þis worthy duke þis theseus
Haþe Creon slayn and wonne thebes þus
Stille in þat felde · he toke Al nyght his Reste
And did wᵗithalle þe cuntree as him liste
To Ransake in þee caas þe bodies deede
Hem for to streype · of herneys ⁊and of hem wede
Þe pelouris dyden besynesse And cure
Afftir þe battayle · and þe discounfeteure
And Also befele þat on Caas þey fonde
Thorugh girt withe many a grevous wounde
Twoo yownge knytꝭes ligging þer by ⁊and by
Booþe in on Armes wrought ful Richelye
Of wiche twoo Daun Arcyte heght þe ton
And þat oþ̉er hitegh Dan palaman
Nought fully qwycke ne fully ded þey were
But by their͗e cotarmurs and bi their͗e gere
Þe heraudes knew hem selfe in speciall
Þat thei were of þe blode Royalle
Of thebes and of sustren two eborne
Owte of cas / þe pelours have hem torne
And have hem caried soffte vn to þe tente
Of Theseus / and he ful sone hem sente
To Athenes / to dwellyn in presoune
Parpetuelly / hem nold he nought Raunson
And whanne þis worthi Duk had þus edon
He toke his hooste / and home he Ridithe a noon
Wᵗith laurier corrunde · as a conqveroure
And þer he livithe in Ioy ⁊and honowre
Terme of lyfe / what nedeþe wordes moo
And in A toure in Angvisshe ⁊and in woo
Dwelliþe þis palamon / and eke Arcite
For euermore þer may · no gold him qvite
Þis passiþe yere by yere / ⁊and day by day
Til hit felle oones in a morowe of maye
That Emelye wiche faerer is to seene
Þanne is þe lelye vpon þe stalke grene
And fressher þan þe may / wᵗith flouris newe
For wᵗith þe Roos coloure stroffe hir hewe
I not wiche was þe fayrer of hem twoo
Er it were day as was hir wonte to doo
She was arysen · and al Redy dyght
For may wolle have no slogardy anyght
Þe saysoun prickeþe · euery gentel herte
And makiþe it oute of Slepe to sterte
And seithe aryse and doon may observaunce
Þis makeþe emelye have Rememberaunce
To doon honoure to May and for taryse
Eclooþed was shoo fressh for to devise
Hir yelow here was broyded in A tresse
By hynde her bak A yerde long I gesse
And in A gardyne at þe sunne vpriste
Sheo walkithe vp ⁊and doune ⁊and As hir lyste
Sheo gaderiþe flouris party weyte ⁊and Rede
To make A sotile chappelette · for her hede
And as an anngellle hevenysshelye she songe
¶ The grete toure with was so thike ⁊and stronge
Þat of þe castelle · was þe cheeffe donioune
Þer as þe knyghtꝭes were in presoune
Of wiche I telle yow here ⁊and telle shalle
Was evyn Ioynande vn to þe gardyn wale
Þer as þis Emelye had her pleyng
Bryght was þee sonne ⁊and clere in þᵗat mornyng
And palamān þis wooful prysoner
As was his wonne by leve of his gayoler
Was Risen ⁊and Romed in A Chaumber on hye
In wiche he al þe noble Citee sighe
And eke þe gardyne ful of braunches grene
Þer as þat fresshe · Emelye þe shene
¶ Was in her walke ⁊and Romede vp ⁊and doune
Þis sorowfful prisoner þis palamon
Goþe in þe Chaumbre · Romyng too And froo
And to him selfe · compleynyng of his woo
Þat he was borne ful ofte he seyde ellas
And so befele by Aventoure or case
Þat þorowe a wyndow of many athikke barr͗e
Of Iron gret ⁊and Sqvare as any sparre
He caste his eyehen · on Emelya
And þerwᵗithal he blente / And cryde ha
As þaughe he were stongen to þe harte
And wᵗith þᵗat crye · Arcyte anoon vpsterte
And sayde Cosyn myn · what eylith thee
Þat art so pale and dedly oune to see
Why crydest þone whoo hathe þee doon offence
For godes love take alle in pacience
Oure presoune / for hit may non oþ̉er bee
Fortune haþe gyve vs · þis Adversitee
Some wicke Aspecte / or disposicioune
Of Satourne by som̄e constulacion
Haþe gyve vs þis · al þoughe we had hit sworne
So stode þe hevene · whanne þat we were borne
We mot endure þis is þe short and playn
¶ Þis palamon answerd · and sayde agayne
Cousin for sooþe of þis opynyoune
Þou haste a veyne Imaginacion
Þis p̉resoune cavsed me right novte to crye
But I was hurte Right nowe thorowe oute myn eye
In to myn herte / wiche wolle my bane bee
Þe faiernesse of þᵗat lady wiche I see
Yonde In þe garden Romyng to ⁊and froo
Is cavse of al my crying ⁊and my woo
I not wher sheo beo woman or goddesse
But venus is it sooþely as I gesse
And þer wᵗithal on knees doune he fille
Seyng Venus yf þat hit be þⁱ wylle
Þe in this gardyn þus to transfigure
Byfore me woofulle wrecched creature
Oute of this presoune helpe þᵗat we may scape
And yf so be my destenye be to shape
By eterne word to dyen in presoune
Of oure linage · haue now compassioune
Þᵗat is so low browte by thyrannye
¶ And wᵗith þᵗat worde Arcite by ganne taspie
Wher as þis ladye Romed to and froo
And wᵗith þᵗat syght hir beautee hurt him soo
Þᵗat yf þat palamon was wounded sore
Arcyte is hurte as muche as he or more
And wᵗith A sike he saide petouslye
Þᵉ fressh beaute sleythe me sodeynelye
Of her þᵗat Rometh in þe yonder place
And but I have hir mercy ⁊and hir grace
Þat I may seen hir at þe leste weye
I name but dede þer nys namore to seye
¶ Þis palamon whan he þeos wordes herde
Despytously he loked and Answerid
Wheþer seyste þowe þis in Ernist or in pleye
Nay quod Arcyte · in ernyste be my feye
God helpe me soo me lyst ful Euil pleye
Þoo Palamon gane knytte his browes tweye
It were quod he to þe no grete honoure
For to be fals ne to be traytoure
To me þat am þy cossyn and þi broþ̉er
Esworne ful depe · And yche of vs til oþ̉er
Þat neuer for to dien · ni þe peyne
Til þat þe dethe departe shal vs tweyne
Neyþer in love to hynder neuer oon oþer
Ne in non oþer cas my leff broþer
But þat þou shouldest truly forþer me
In euery cas ⁊and I sholde forþer the
Þis was þyn othe and myn Also certayne
I wot it wel þowe darst hit nowte wᵗithsayne
Þus artowe of my Counsaile · owte of dowte
And nowe þowe woldest falslye been Abowte
To love my ladye · whame I love ⁊and serve
And ever shalle tille þᵗat myn hert sterve
Nowe certes fals Arcyte þou shalt not soo
I lovid hir first and told þe my woo
As to my covnseyle / and my Broþ̉er sworne
To forþer me as I have tolde be forne
For wiche þowe arte ebounde as a knight
To helpin me if it lye in þi myght
Or elles Art thowe fals I dare wel seyne
Þis Arcyte þoo / ful proudely speke A gaynArcyte Answerithe
Þou shalt quod he beo raþer fals þan I
But þow arte fals I telle þe vttirlye
For par Amours I loued her firste þanne þowe
What wilte þowe seyn þow wist it not yet nowe
Wheþer sheo beo A wōmman or goddesse
Þyne is Affeccion of holynesse
And myn is love · as to a creature
For wiche / I toolde þee nowe · myn Aventure
As to my Cosyne / and my broþ̉er sworne
I porpose þᵗat thowe / louedeste hir byforne
Wostowe nought wele þe olde clerks sawe
Þat who shall gyve A louer Any laweQuis legem dat amancibꝫus
Love is A gretter lawe · by my pane
Þane may beo gyven to any eorþely man
Þerfore lawe / positiffe and suche decree
Is broke all daye for love / in eche degree
A man moste neodes love maugrye his hede
He may not chefyn þaughe he shoulde be ded
Al beo sheo mayde wydowe · or ellꝭis wyf
And eke it is not likly / al þi lyfe
To stonden in her grace namore shal I
For weel þowe woste / þi selff verrayli
Þat þou and I be dampned to p̉resoune
Perpetuelly vs gayneþe no Raunsoun
We striven as þe houndes for þe boon
Þey faught aldaye / and yette their͗e part was noon
Þer cam a Crirr / whiles þei were so wrooþᵉ
Þ bare aweye þe boon bytwyxsse hem booþe
¶ And þere fore at þe kynges courte my broþerAd huc noᵃta
Eche man for him selfe þer is noon oþer
Love yf þowe lyste / for I love ⁊and ay shalle
And soþely leve broþer / loo here is Alle
Here in this presoune / moste we nedis endure
And everiche of vs take his Aventoᵘur
¶ Gret was þe stryffe and long bytwene hem tweye
Iff þat I had leysoure · nowe for to seye
But to þeffecte / hit happenid on a day
To telle it yowe / als shortlye as I maye
A worthy Duk þᵗat heght parotheus
Wiche freond was vn to this Duk Theseus
Siþe thilke day þᵗat þei were childern like
Was com to Athenes / him to visite
And for to pleye / as he was wont to doo
For in this worlde / he louid noman soo
And he louid him als tendirly agayn
Þat whanne þat oon was dede sooþely to sayne
Hes felawe went / and sought him doune in helle
So wele þei lovid as old bookꝭes telle
But of that story / lyste me nowte to wreyte
But howe parotheus loued þis sayde Arcyte
And hade him knowe / at Thebes yere by yere
¶ And finallye at Requeste / and prayere
Of parotheus with outen Raunsoun
Duc Theseus lete him oute of prysoune
Freoly to goone · wher him liste oủeralle
In suche a guyse / as I yow tellen shalle
Þis was þe forward pleynly tendyte
Betwixsse duc Theseus and þis Arcyte
Þat yf so were þat Arcite were efounde
Eủer in his lyf / by day or neythe or stounde
In anye countrey / of this theseus
Iff he were Kaught it was cordid thus
Þat wᵗith A swerde / he shoulde leese his hede
Þer nas noon oþ̉er / Remedye ne rede
But takeþe his leve / and hamwarde he him spedde
Lete him by ware / his necke liþe nowe to wedde
¶ Howe grete A sorowe / soufferiþe nowe Arcyte
Þe Dethe he felithe thoroughe his hert smyte
He wepiþe wayliþe creyeþe pytously
To sleon him selff / he wayteþe prevelye
He sayde ellas / þe day þat I was borne
Nowe is my p̉resoune werse þan was beforne
Nowe is me shapen · eternally to dwelle
Noute in purgatorie / but in depe helle
Ellas þat euer I knewe Parotheus
For Ellis hadde I be stylle wᵗith Theseus
Effeterid in his presoune /for everemo
Þanne hadde I been in blisse / and not in woo
Oonly þe syght of her whame þᵗat I serve
Þooughe þᵗat I neuer hir grace may deserve
Wold have souffysed / right enoughe for me
¶ O dere cousyn / Palamon þoo quod he
Þyne is þe Victorie of þis Aventure
Ful blisfully in prysoun maystowe endure
In presoune Certes nay but Paradys
Weel haþe · Fortune / etourned þee þe dys
Þat haste þe sight of hir / and I þabsence
For possible is syght þowe haste hir presence
And art A knyte / A worthie and an Able
Þat by some cas / sith Fortune is chaungeable
Þowe maiste som tyme to þy desire atteyne
But I þᵗat am exyled and barreyne
Of al grace and in so grete dispeyre
Þat neyþer eorþe / water fyre ne ayre
Ne creature / þat of hem maked is
Þat may me helpe or done coumforte in þis
Weel aught I sterue in wanhope ⁊and distresse
Farwel my lyff my loust and my gladnesse
Ellas why pleynen / men so in Comune
Of þe pourveyaunce / of god or of Fortune
Wiche gevithe hem ful ofte in many guyse
Welbette þan þei cane hem selff devise
¶ Some man desierith for to have Richchesse
Which cause is of his mourdre or sekenesse
And sōmmeman wolde / owte of his prysoune fayne
Þat in his house is of heos meynee slayne
Infynite harmes / been in þis mater
We wot nought / what thing þat we preyne here
We fare as he þat dronke is as a mouse¶þe woordis of þis Arcyte
A dronke man wot well þᵗat / he hathe an hovse
But he not wiche / þe right wey is þider
And to A dronken man þe wey is sklyþer
For certes in þis worlde so faren we
We sechen faste / Afftir felicite
But we goon wronge / ful offte trulye
Þus may we seyne alle ⁊and namliche I
Þat wende / and hade A grete opynyoune
Iff I hadde myght / escapen from presoune
Þanne hade I been in Ioye and parfite hele
Þer I am nowe exyled from myn wele
Sithe þᵗat I may nought seo yowe / Emelye
I nam but ded þer nys noo Remedye
Vppon þat oþ̉er syde þis Palamān¶þe lamentacion of palamon
Whan þᵗat he wiste þᵗat Arcyte was Agōnn
Suche sorowe he makde þᵗat þe grete toure
Ressouneþe / of his yolling and clamour
Þe pure fetters vppon heos shenis grete
Were of his bitter salt teres wete
Ellas quod he Arcyta Cousin myn
Of al oure stryff god wot þe fruyt is þyne
Þow walkest nowe in Thebes at þi large
And of my woo / þowe gyvest litil charge
Þowe maiste sithe þow haste wysdom ⁊and manhed
Assemble al þe folk of oure kynrede
And make A werre so sherpe on þis citee
Þat by sōmme Aventure or trayetee
Þow maist have · hir to lady ⁊and to vyve
For whame þat I most neodes leese my lyve
For As by weye of possibilitee
Sith þow arte at þⁱ large / of presoune free
And art A lord gret is þⁱ vauntage
More þan is myne þat sterve here in A cage
¶ For I moot wepe and wayle whiles þᵗat I leve
Wᵗith al þe woo þat prysoun may me gyve
And eke wᵗith peyne þᵗat love me geviþe Also
Wiche doubleþe al / my tourment ⁊and my woo
Þer withe þe fryre of Ialousye vpsterte
Wᵗith Inne his breste / and hent him by þᵉ herte
So woodly þᵗat he like was to be holde
Þe boxstree or þe Asshen ded and colde
¶ Þanne sayde he þus o crewel godesse þᵗat governe
Þis world with bynding / of your word eterne
And wryten in the table of þaþemaunte
Youre parlement and youre eterne gravnted
What is mankynde more / vn to yow byholde
Þanne is þe sheep þᵗat Rowkeþe in þᵉ folde
For slayne is man / right as an oþ̉er beste
And dwelliþe eke in prisowne / ⁊and in A Reeste
And hathe sekenesse / And grete Aduersitee
Welle offte tymis ful gyltlesse pardee
What governaunce is in þi prescyens
Þᵗat þus gyltlesse / tourmentes Innocence
¶ And yette encreseþe þis / al my penaunce
Þᵗat man is bounden to his observaunce
For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
Þer as A beste may Al his luste fulfille
And whanne A beste is dede he haþe noo peyne
But Aftir his deþe man moste wepe ⁊and pleyne
Þoughe in þis worlde he have care ⁊and woo
Wᵗithovten dowte / it may stonden soo
Þanswere of þis / leet I to devynes
But wele I wotte / in þis world grete pyne is
Ellas I see a serpent or A theeff /
