But weyeghe pruyde / ⁊and humblesse affer oon
And shortly whanne his yre was þus a goon
He gane to looken vppe with eyeghen lighet
And spake þos same wordes al on heyþe
¶ Þowe god of love · A benedicite
Howe myghty ⁊and howe grete A lorde is he
Agayinst his myght þer gayniþᵉ non obstacle
He may be clepid a god for his miracle
For he can maken Right at his owne guyse
Off euerych hert as þat him liste devise
Loo here þis Arcyte / and þis Palamon
Þat qweyt boþe were owte of my presovne
And myght have levid in Thebes Ryally
And wyten I am þowe mortal ennemye
And þat þowe deþe is in myght Alsoo
Loo yette haþe loue maugrye þeyre eyeghen twoo
Browte hem heþir boþe for to dye
Now lokeþe / is not þis A grete follye
Loo who may beo A fool / but yf he love
Byhold for godis love / þat sittiþe Above
¶ See howe þei blede / beo þey not evel Arayed
Þus hathe hir lord þe god of love hem payed
Þeyre wages and þeire fe for þeire service
And yette þey wenen / þat þei ben ful wyse
Þat serven love / for ought þat may befalle
But yette is þis þe beste game of alle
Þat she for whome / þey have þis Iolytee
Coneþe hem als mouche thanke As sheo doþᵉ me
Sheo knoweþe namore of al þis hoote fare
By god namore þane woot A cukko of an hare
But Al mot beon Assayed hote ⁊and colde
A man mot ben A foole or yowng or olde
I wot hit be my selve ful yore agoone
For in my tyme A sarvaunt was I oon
And þer fore / sith I knowe of loveis peyne
And wot how sore hit can A man distreyne
As he þᵗat haþe beo offte kaught in his laase
I yowe for gyve hooly / Al þis trespas
At Reqveste of þis qvene þᵗat knelith here
And Eke of Emelye my sister dere
Soo þat yee booþe wolle / on to me swere
Þat neuer more yee shal my contrey dere
¶ Ne make me werre neyþer nyght ne daye
But beon my frendes in al þᵗat ye maye
I yowe for gyve þis trespas euery dele
And þei him sworne / his axing fayre ⁊and welle
And hym of lordshippee ⁊and of mercy prayed
Þus he hem grauntiþe grace þanne ⁊and sayde
¶ To speke of Riall linage / And Richesse
Þowgh þᵗat sheo were a qwene or A pryncesse
Sheo to yowe boþe is / worþi dowtelesse
To wedden whan tyme is but naþelesse
I speke as for my Systir fayre Emelye
For whame yee have þis stryff ⁊and Ialousye
Yee woot youre selve sheo may not weddyn twoo
At oones / þaughe yee fighten euer moo
Þat oon of yowel beo yee looþe or leff
He moste go pypen in An Ivi lefe
Þis is to sey sheo may not now have yow boþe
Ne be yee neuer so Ialovse ne so wroþe
And for þy putte I nowe þis pleyne decree
As him is shape / and herkeithe in d

l.hi: Loo here yowre ende of þᵗat I Shalle devise

div.l: ¶ My wille is þis for platte conclusion
Wᵗithouten anye / Replicacyoune
Yif þat yowe like take it for þe beste
Þat euery of yow shalle goo wher him liste
Frely wᵗithouten Raunsoune or davngere
And þis fyfftye wekꝭes ferre ne neere
Þat eche of yowe shalle bryng / an hounderiþe knightes
Armed for lystes vppe at alle Rightes
Al redy to derrayne · hir by battayle
And þis by heete I yowe wᵗithouten faylle
Vppon my trowþe and as I am A kneyght
Þat wheþer of yowe boþe may have þe myghet
Þis is to seyne þat wheþer he or thowe
May with his hunderþe / as I sayde nowe
Sleo his Aduersse or owte of listes dryve
Til him shalle I gyve / Emelye to wyve
Whome þat Fortune · wol gyve so fayre a grace
Þe lystes shalle I do make here in þis place
And god so wissely vppon my sowle · Rue
As I Shalle evene Iuge / beon and trewe
Yee Shalle noon oþer eonde wᵗith me make
Þat oon of yowe shal beo dede or take
And yf yee thynk þat þis is welle esayde
Sey yowre Avise / ⁊and hold yowe þ̉erwᵗith payde
Þis is youre ende ⁊and youre conclusion
Who lokeþe lytlye nowe but palamon
Who spryngithe vppe for Ioye but Arcyte
Who covde hit telle or who coude it endite
Þe Ioye þᵗat is þanne made in þat place
Whanne Theseus haþe doon so feyre A grace
But downe on knees went eủery man̉er wight
And thanken hym wᵗith al þeire hart ⁊and myght
And namlye þos Thebanes ful many sithe
And þus wᵗith hope / and wᵗith herte bleyþe
Þey take hir leve and homewardes gan þey Ride
To thebes wardis wᵗith olde walles wyde
¶ I trowe þᵗat men wolde deme it necgligence
If I forgeten to tellen þe dispense
Of Theseus þᵗat goythe so beselye
To lete make vppe þe listes Riallye
Þat suche A noble Theatre as it was
I dare welle sayne in all þis worlde þer nas
Þe circuyt welle a myle it was Abowte
Walled wᵗith stone And dyched Alle wᵗithoute
Rounde was it caste in man̉er of compas
Ful of degrees þe heythe of sixti pas
And whanne a man was sette on oon degree
He lette no thyng his felowe for to see
¶ Estwardes þer stode A gate marbolle white
Westwardes þer stode suche a noþ̉er in papposyte
And shortly to conclude suche A plas
Was noon on eorþe / as in so litell space
For in þat londe þer nas no craffty man
Þat Geometrye or ars metrike can
Ne pourtreyour ne kerver of Images
Þat Theseus ne gaff hem mete wages
Ne of entayle þat konde ouryonstee
But he was hadde / wher so þᵗat he be
Þe theatre to make ⁊and to devyse
Þer for to done boþe Ryght ⁊and sacrefyse
¶ He Estewarde haþe / vppon þe gate Above
In worshippe of venus þᵉ goddes of love
Doon make an Auter and an oratorye
And on þe westwardes syde in memorye
Of Mars he hathe maked suche A noþ̉er
Þat coste of fyne gold a foþer
And Northewardis in A touret on þe walle
Of Alabastre wheyte ⁊and Rede coralle
And oratorye · Right Riche for to see
In worshippe of Dyane of Chastitee
Þe goddes hathe Theseus wrought þis wyse
¶ But yette hadde I forgote for to devise
Þe noble kervinyes / and þe pourtyratures
Þe shappe þe covntenauns / And þe figures
Þat weren in þoo oratoryes three
FiTemple of Venus maistowe see
Wrought on þᵉ walle / ful pitous to be holde
Þe brooken sleepes · and þe sykus colde
Þe socred terys / and þe waymentynge
Þe firye strokes / of þe desyring
Þat loues saruantes / in þis lyfe enduren
Þe ooþes / þat hir couenanntes assuren
Plesaunce /and hope / desyre / foolehardinesse
Beaute and thought / Baudrye / ⁊andrichesse
Charmes⁊andForce / lesynge⁊andflaterye
Dispence / Bysynesse / and folye Ialousye
þat werid / of yelowe goldis a garlonnde
And a cuckoo / sittyng on hir . honde
Fests / instrumuents / carolles /daunces
Ioustons and arraye / wᵗith al þe circumstaunces
Of love / wheche I Rekened / and Rekne shalle
By ordre / were epeynted on that walle
And moo / þan I kane maken of mencioune
For sooþely / al þe Mounet of Cytheroun
Þer Venus / hathe hir pryncipalle dwellyng
Was shewed on þat walle / in pourtrayng
of þᵗatRomaunce of þe Roosewᵗith al þe gardyne / and the loustenesse
Nought was fouryeten / þe porter ydilnesse
Ne Narsisus þe faire / of so yoore a goond
Ne yette þe folye / of þe kyng Salamon
Ne yette þe grote strenght of Arcules
Þenchauntments of Medea⁊andCirces
Ne of Thornus wiche hardy fyers courage
Þe riche Cresus kaytyff in servage
Þus may ye seen þat wysdom ne richesse
Beaute ne sleght strongethe ne hardynesse
Ne may wᵗith venus holde no chammepartye
For as hir luste þe worˡde þus may shee guy
Lo alle þees folke so kaute were in her lasse
Tille þei for woo ful often seuye ellasse
Suffiseþe here oon ensammple or twoo
The statue of venus gloriouse to see
Was poyntid naked fleetyng in þe see
And frome þe navel doune al coverde was
Withe wawes grene and bright as any glasse
A Cytole in hir ryght hande hade shee
And on her hede ful semly for to see
A roose garlonde Fresshe ⁊andwel smellyng
Above hir hede whyte dowes ar flateryng
By fore her stode hir sone . Cupido
Uppon his shoulders wynges hadde twoo
And blynde he was as it was offte seen
A bowe he bare and arowes bryghte ⁊and keen
Whi sholde I not eke als wele telle yowe alle
+ þe portraytour of þe oratorie of women wᵗithin wᵗithþe walles þe pourtrature þᵗat was wᵗithinne þe walle
of þat temple of mighty Mars þe reede
So peynted was hit all in lenkeþe ⁊andbrede
Liche to þe eesteris of þat gruselye place
þat heght þe gret temple of Mars in Tharce
In ilke same colde frosty Regyoun
Þer as Mars haþe his soveren mansioune
¶ Firste on þe wal was peynted a foreste
In wiche þer wonneþe neyþer man no beste
wᵗith knotty knarry baureyne trees ⁊and olde
On stobbes sharpe and hydiuus to be holde
In wiche þer was a rombul ⁊and a showe
As þowhe þe storme wolde breste ev̉ery boughe
And downewardes frome an hill vndir a bent
Þer stode þe Temple of Mars Armypotent
Wrovght al of bourned steele of wiche þe entre
Was long and streyte and goostely for to see
And þer oute came arage in suche a wyse
Þat hit made alle þe gates for to a ryse
¶ Þe norþern light in at þe doores shone
For wyndowe on þe walle ne was þ̉er noon
Thorugh wiche men might any lyghte discerne
Þe dourre was al of Adeamande eterne
Yklenched over twart ⁊and endlong
wᵗith Yren tough for to make hit stronge
Euery piller þe temple to susteyne
Was tonne gret of yron bryght ⁊and shene
¶Of felonnye and al þe cumpassyng
+ Þe cruelle yere red as any glede+Marginalia
Þe pukepursse and þe pale drede
Þe smyler wᵗithþe knyff vnder þᵉ clooke
Þe shippe brynnyng wᵗithþe blacke smoke
Þe thraysoun of þe mourþering in þᵉ bedde
Þe opyn werre wᵗith woundis alle bybledde
Contecke with blody knyf ⁊andsharrpe mannasse
Al ful of chirkyng was þat sory place
Þe slere of him selff yette sawe I þer
His hert bloode haþe baþed al his here
Þe nayle edryven in þe shoode at night
wᵗith cold deþe þe mouþe gapyng upright
Amiddes of þe temple soote mischaunce
wᵗith discoumfort⁊and sory countenaunce
¶ Yette saughe I woodnesse laughing in his rage
Armed ComplyauntOoþesa fiers courrage
Þe karoyne in þe busshe with throte ekorve
Þe thiraunt wᵗithþe praye by force erafte
Þe toune destroyed þat no thyng was lefte
yette sawhe I brente þe shippes hoppesters
Þe hunt strangelid wᵗith the wylde bores
Þe Sowe Freting þe chylde right in þe cradle
Þe cooke escallid / for al his long ladille
Nought was forgeten / by thin fortune of marte
Þe carter / oủer riden wᵗith þe Carte
Vnder þe whole fulle lowe he lay a downe
Þer were also / of martes devysionne
Þe barboure / ⁊and þe Bocher ⁊and þe Smythe
Þat forgeþe sharpe swerdes / on þe stythe
And al a bove / depeyntid in a toure
Sawhe I Conqueste sittynng in grete honoᵘur
Hangyng / by a subtyle twynes thrad
wᵗith þe sharpe swerd / a ouẻer his hed
Depeyntid was / þe slaughter of Iulius
Of gret Nero / and/ of Anthonies
Al be / þᵗat thilke tyme / thei were vnborne
Yette was þeire deþe / depeyntid þ̉er beforne
By manassing of Mars / right by figure
So was hit shewed / þer in that pourterature
As is depeyntid / in þe certues aboue
Who shalle bee dede / or ells slayn for love
Suffisuthe oon ensammple / in storyes olde
I may not reken hem al / þowe I wolde
Þe Statute of Mars / vppon a cart stode
Armed / and grymme / lokyng as he were woode
And ouer his hed / þer sheynen two pykturis
Þat oon puella / þat o þer Rubeus
Of stervis / wiche been clepid in figiurs
Þis god of armovses / was arrayed þus
A wolfe þere stoode / by forne him at his feete
wᵗith eyen rede / and of a man he yete
wᵗith sotyle penselle / was depeyntid þis storie
In recordynge of Mars / and of his glorie
Marginalia Now to þe temple / of Dyane þe chaste
As shortly as I can / I wolle me haste
For to telle yowe / al þe discrepcionne
Depeynted was þe walle / uope ⁊and downe
Of huntyng and of shammfaste chastite
Þer sawe I / howe wofulle Calistope
Whane þat diane / a greved was wᵗith here
Was tournd / from a woman / unto a Bere
And aftir was she made / þe loode sterve
Þus was hit peyntid / I can seye no ferve
Hir sone is eke a sterre / as yee maye see
Þer sawhe I Dane / tournued to a tree
I mene not hir þe fayre goddesse Diane
But Penneus dovghter / whech þᵗat heghte Dane
þer sawhe I Atheon an hert emaked
For vengeaunce / þᵗat he saughe Diane al naked
I sawhe / þere howe hess hondes have him caught
And fretid him / for they knew him nought
Þette peynted was / a litil forthermor
Howe Atthelant / hunted þe wylde boore
And Meleagre / and many oþ̉er moo
For wiche Dyane / wrought him care ⁊and woo
Þer sawhe I many a noþer worthie storye
wiche / me list not drauen to memorye
Þis goddes on herte ful / swelle shyee seete
wᵗith smale houndes / al aboute her fete
And ondir nooþe hir fet shee hadde a moone
Wexssing it was / and ful waynyng soone
In gaudy grene / hir statue clooþed was
Withe bowe in hande / ⁊and arowes in a cas
Hir yeughe shee caste / þanne þer fulle low adowne
Þer Pluto / haþe his derkfull Regyoun
¶ A womman travelyng was hir byforne
But for hir childe / was so longe vnborne
Ful pytousely / lucyna gane shee calle
And saide helpe / for þow maiste beste of alle
Welle koude he peynte lyfly / þat it wrought
wᵗith many a floreyne / he þe colours bought
¶ Nowe been þees lystes made / and Theseus
wiche at his gret coste arrayed þus
Þe temples / and þe Theatree euery dele
Whanne it was doon / him liked wonder welle
But stynte I wole / of Theseus aluyte
And spoke I wol of Palamon / and of Arcyte
¶ Þe daye approcheþe / of hir retournynge
Þat iche of hem / an hunderid kneyghts should bryng
Þe batayle to derrame / as I yow tolde
Streyght to Atthene / hir couenaunt to holde
and eche of hem hathe / browght e knyte
Weel armed for þe werre / and al þe rightes
And sikurly / þer trowed many a man
Þat neuere sith / first þat þe world be gan
As for to speke / of kneyghthode wᵗith hir honde
Als fer / as god hathe made see ⁊and londe
Nas of so fewe / so noble a companye
For euery weyght þᵗat loued chevalryee
And wold his thankꝭes / have a passyng name
Haþe sore desired / he myght be of þe game
And weel was him / þat þer to chosin was
For yf þer fille / to morwe suche a cas
Yee knowen welle / þᵗat euery lusti knyte /
Þat loweþe paramoures / ⁊and haþᵉ myght
Were it ⁱⁿ Englond / or Elles where
Thei woolden fayne willen / for to be þere
To Fyght For a ladye / benedicite
Hit were a lustye sighte / soo for to se
And right so / ferden þei wᵗith Palamon
div.note: how palamons feleshippe were armed wᵗith in lyftes
div.l: wᵗith hym þer went / kneytꝭes many son
Some wol be armed / in an habourgeon
And a breste plate / wᵗith a liyte joupon
And some wolle have / a peyre of plates large
And some wolle have a shoold or pouyce targe
Some wolle be / armed on his leges welle
And have an Axsse / and some a mace of steele
Þer nas noon newe guyse þᵗat it nas olde
Armed were þei as I have yowe tolde
Everyche aftir his owne oppinionne
Þer maystowe see comyng wᵗith Palamon
Lygeurge him selff þe gret kyng of TharsePalamon is Feleshippe
Blacke was his wisage / ⁊and manly was his face
Þe cercles of his eyeghen / in his hede
Þei glowden / ay by twyxsse yelowe ⁊and rede
And liche a lyonne / loked he aboute
wᵗith kempe heres / uppon his browes stoute
hees lymmes grete / hees brawnes / wonder stronge
hees shulderis broode / his armes rounde ⁊and longe
And as þe guyse was / in his cuntree
Fulle highe / vppon a chare of golde stode he
wᵗith foure white bolles / in þe trays
In stede of coote / above his riche harnesse
wᵗith nayles / breyght bourned of Fyne golde
he had a beris skynne / colblacke / for olde
his long here / was kempte bihind his backe
As any Ravenis feþer / hit shone for blacke
A wreþe of golde / arme gret of huge weyght
Vppon his hede / sette fulle of stonis bryght
Of Rubeys Fyne / and of diamanntes
A bowte his chare / þer went Alauntes
Twenti and moo / als grete as any stere
To huntyn wᵗith þe lionne / or þe deer
Þat Folowed him / wᵗith mousell faste ebounde
Coliers of golde / of tourrettis fyled rounde
An hunderid lordes / had he in his route
Armed ful welle / wᵗith hertꝭes steerne ⁊and stoute
Þan wᵗith Arcyte / as men in stories fynde
Came Emetrons þe riche / kynge /of ynde
Vppon a stede bay / trappyd wᵗith stele
Crownd wᵗith golde / þᵗat was drapred welle
Came rydyng / lyche þe god of armes Mars
His coote armure / wrought of cloþe of Thars
Couched wᵗith perles rounde white ⁊and grete
His sadil was / of brent golde nuwe bete
A mantelette vppon his shoulder hongyng
Bete ful of Rubys / as fuyre sparkelyng
His crippis here / lyche rynges was eronne
And þat was yelowe / and glyteryng as þe sonne
His nose was heghe / hees eyen bright Cytryne
Hees lippis rounde / his coloure was sangvayn
A fewe frankes / in his face were spreynt
By twyxsse yelowe / and somdele blacke emeynt
And as alionne / he hees eyen caste
Of . xxv. yere / his age I caste
His berde / was welbegonne for to sprynge
His voyce / was as trompet thunderyng
Vppon his hede / he werid a labrier grene
A garlaunde freshe / ⁊and lusty for to seen
Vppon his hande / he bare for his delite
An Egle thame / as any lylly white
An hunderithe lordes / had he wᵗith him þere
Alle armed saufe hire heddis / in al hire gere
Ful richely / in alle maner thyngꝭes
For trusteþe wel / dukes / Eorles /⁊and kynges
Were gaderid / in þis noble compayne
For love / and for encresse of chevallerye
Aboute þis kyng þer rane on every parte
Ful many a tame lionne and leoparde
And in this wyse / thes lordes al ⁊and summe
Been on þe Sonnday / vn to þe citee comme
A boute þe prime / and in þe towne a light
Þis Theseus / þis duke þis worþy kneyght
Whanne he had browte hem / in to his Citee
And longed hem / afftre euerich þeybe degree
He Festiþe hem / and doþe so gret laboure
Til easen hem / and doon hem al honoure
Þat yette men wenen / þat nomanes witte
Of noon estitte ne koude mendyn hit /
Þe Mynstralsye / þe service / ⁊and þe feste
Þe grete gyfftis / to þe meste ⁊and to þe leste
Þe riche aray / of Theseus Pallays
Ne whoo satte Firste or laste vppon þe deys
what ladyes fayerste been / and best daunsyng
Or wiche of hem / kan kausse beste and synge
Ne whoo mooste felingly /can speke of love
What hawkes siten / on þe perche above
What houndes liggen / on þe floore adowne
Of al þis nowe / make I no mencionne
Of al þeffecte / what thynkethe me þe best
Nowe comeþe þe poynte herkenyþe yf yowe lyste
¶ Þe Sondaye nyght er day beganne to sprynge
Whan palamon / herde þe larke synge
Alþoughe it ner not day / by oures twoo
Yette sang þe larke / and Palamon right þoo
Withe holy herte / and wᵗith an hye courage
He roose him uppe / to weende on pilgrimage
Vn to þe blisful / Citherea benyugne
I mene Venus / so honurable ⁊and digne
And in hir houre / he walkiþe forþe a pase
Vn to þe lystꝭes / þer þe temple was
Adowne he knelithe / and wᵗith humble chere
And hert sore / he sayde as ye shal here
Fayrest of Fayre / so lady myne Venus
Doughter to Iove / and spouse to Vlcanus
Þow glader / of þe mounte of Citheron
For þilke love / þowe hadeste vn to Adon
Have pitee / of my bitt̉re teers smerte
And take myn h̄u mble prayere a þyn hert
Ellas I nave no langage to telle
Þeffect. ne þe tourmente of myne helle
Myne hert / may not alle myn armes be wreye
I am so confuse / þat I can not seye
But mercy ladye bryght þat wotest wele
My thowight and seest what harmes þᵗat I feele
Considre al þis / and rewe on my soore
As wyselye / as I shalle for eủermore
Enenforthe my myght þy servaunt ever be
And hesly werre / al weye withe chastitee
Þat make I myne avowe / so ye me helpe
I keepe nowte of armes for to yelpe
Ne I ne axsse not to morowe / to have victorie
Ne renoune in this cas / ne veynglorie
Of prys of armous / blowen vp ⁊and doune
But I wolde have / fully possesseonne
Of Emele / ⁊and dye in hir service
Fynd in þis mater / howe / ⁊and in what wyse
I rechche nought so hit may bett̉erbe
To have victorye of hem / or þey of me
So þat I have / my ladye in my armes
For þow þat so bee / Mars is god of armes
youre vertu is so grete in hevene above
Þat yf þo liste I shalle wele have my love
Þy temple / shal I worshipe eủer mo
And on thyn Awter / wher I ride or goo
I wolle do sacrefyse / and Fyres bete
And yf ye wol not soo / my lady swete
Þane praye I ewe / to morw wᵗith a spere
þᵗat he Arcyte / may me thorowe þe herte bere
Þanne reeke I nowte whane I have loste my lyffe
Þaughe þat Arcyte / to wynne Emylis to wyffe
Þis is þeffecte and eende of my prayere
Giff me my ladye / þowe blesffull wemin dere
¶ Whan þe orysonn was doon / of Palamon
His sacrefyse he did / ⁊and þᵗat anoon
Ful pytousely / wᵗith alle þe circumstaunces
Al telle I not as nowe / hees observaunces
But at þe laste / þe Statute of Venus shooke
And made a signe / wherby þat he toke
Þat his prayere / was accepted þat day

l.hi: For þaughe þe signe wherby þat he tooke
Þat his prayere was accepte þat day

div.l: For þowe þe signe / shewed þanne a delay
Þette wyste he wel / þat graunted was his boone
And withe gladde herte / he went away fulsone
¶ Þe thirde oure in Eq̄uale / þat Palamon
By ganne / to Venus temple / for to goon
Vppe rose þe sonne / ⁊and vp rose Emelye
Shee to þe temple of Dyane / can hye
Hire maydens / wheche shee thider with hire ladde
Ful redely with / þe fuyre withe hem þey hadde
Þensens / þe clooþes / and þe remenant al
Þat to þe sacryfice / to longen shalle
Þe hornes ful of Methe / as was guyse
Þer lacked nowte to don hir sacrefice
Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
Þis Emelye / wᵗith her right debonnayre
Hir body wesshe / wᵗith wat̉er of a welle
But how shee did hir rite I dare not telle
But it be / any thyng in generalle
And yette it were agame / to here it al
To him þat menyth welle / it were noo charge
But hit is gode / a man bee at his large
Hir brighte herye were kempte / vntressed alle
A coronne / of a greene ooke seryalle
Vppon hir hede was sette ful fayre ⁊and mete
Two fuyres / on þe Awter cane shee beete
And did hir thyngꝭes / as men may be holde
In State of Thebes / as þees bookes olde
Whan kendelede was þe Fuyre / wᵗith pytous chere
Vn to diane / shee spake / as ye may here
¶ O chaste goddesse / of þe woodes grene
To whame / boþe hevene / and eerþe / and See is seene
Quene of þe regne of Pluto / so derk ⁊and lowe
Goddesse of maydens / þat myn hert haste knowe
Fulle many a yere / and woste what I desire
As kepe me / fro þⁱ vengeauns and þyn yre
þᵗat Atheoun / abought Ful cruellye
Chaaste goddesse / wel wostowe þat I
Desire / to been a mayden / al my live
No never wolle I be / love / ne wyffe
I am þowe woste yette of þ i compayne
(base) A mayde / ⁊and love huntyng ⁊and venerye
And for to walke / in þe woodes wylde
And nowght to bee a wyff / ⁊and be wᵗith chylde
Noughte wolle I knowe / company of man
Noughe helpe me ladye / sithe ye may ⁊and can
For þalke three fourmes / þat þou haste in þee
¶ And Palamon / þat hathe suche love to me
And Eke Arcyte / þat lovethe me so sore
Þis grace I praye þe / wᵗithowten moore
As send booþe love ⁊and pes / by twene hem twoo
And from me / tourne away / hir hertꝭes soo
þᵗat al þeyze hoote love / and þeyze desire
And al þeyre besy tourment and þeyre fuyre
Be qweynte ⁊and tourned in to a noþ ̉er place
And yf so bee / þow wilt do me no grace
Or yf so bee my destenye / be shape soo
Þat I shalle needes / have oon of hem twoo
Þow send me him / þat moste desire me
By holde goddes / of clenneste chastite
Þe bitt̉re teeres / þat on my chekes Falle
Suhe þow art made / and keper of vs alle
My maydinhoode þow keepe / and welle conserve
And while I lyve / a mayde I welle þee serue
Þe fuyres brenne / vppon þe aucter clere
Whiles Emelye / was þus in hir prayere
But sodenly / shee seghe a thyng qweynte
For right a noon / oon of þe fuyres qweynte
And qwikkened a gayn / and after that anon
Þat oþer fuyre was qweynte and al a goon
And as hit qweynte / hit made a whistelyng
And doon thes wete brondes / in her brynnyng
¶ And at þe brondes end / þer ran a noon
As hit were / blodye dropes ful many oon
For wiche / so sore agaste was Emelye
Þat shee was welnyghe madde / ⁊and gan to crye
For shee ne wiste / what hit signeffied
But oonlye for þe feere / þus shee cryed
And wepte / þat hit was pitee for to here
And þer withe al / Dyane gan tappere
wᵗith bowe an hande / right as an hunteresse
And sayde dowter / stynte yoʳ hevynesse
¶ A monge þe goddes on heyghe / it is affermed
And By Eterne worde / wrote ⁊and confermed
Þowe shalt be wedded / vn til oon of þoo
Þat have for þee / soo muchil care ⁊and woo
But vn til wiche of hem / I may not telle
Goo fare welle / on I may noo lenger dwelle
Þe Fuyres / wiche on myne avter brynne
Shalle þe declaren / er þᵗat þow goo henne
Þyne aventure of love / as in þis case
And wᵗith þat word / þarowes in þe case
Of þe goddes / clateryn faste eke rnig
And foorþe shee went / and made a vanysshyng
For whiche / þis Emelye a stonyed was
And saide / what mounteþe nowe al þis ellas
I putte me hoole / in þy proteccyoun
Dynne / ⁊and in þi disposicionne
And home shee goyþe / þus þe next wey
Þis is þeffect þer nis namore to saye
¶ Þe nexst oure of Mars / nowe filowyng þis
Arcyte / vn to þe Temple ewalked is
To fiers Mars / til done his sacrefyce
wᵗith al þe Rightes / of his paynyme wyse
wᵗith pitouse herte / and heghe dewcioune
Right þus to Mars / he did his oryson
¶ O strong god / wich in þe regnes colde
Of thars / honoured art and lorde eholde
And haste in Eủer y regne / and euery lande
Of armes / al þe bridelle in þyn hande
And hem fortunest as þe lyste devyse
Accepte of me / my petouse sacrefyse
yf soo be / that my thoute may deserve
And þᵗat my myght bee worthye for to serve
Þy godhede / þᵗat I may bee oon of thyne
Þanne pray I þee / to rewe vppon my pyne
For þilke pyne / and þat hoote Fuyre
In wiche / þowe brendest whilom for desyre
whanne þat þowe vsedest þe beaute
Of fayre freshe yonge Venus free
And hadeste hir / in armes at þy wille
Al þoughe þee oonys / on a tyme mysffelle
Whanne Vlcanus / hade kaught þee in his laasse
And fonde þe lyggynge by his wyf ellas
For þilke sorowe / þat was in þyne herte
have routhe als wele / vppon my peynis smerte
I am younge / and vnkonnyng as þow wooste /
And as I trowe / withe love offendid mooste
Þat eủer was / any lyves creature
For shee þᵗat dooþe me / al þis woo endure
Ne rechcheþe neuere / wherþer I synke or fleete
And wel I woot or shee me mercy heete
I mot wᵗ strenkethethe / wynne hire in þis place
And wel I woot wᵗithouten helpe or grace
Of the / ne maye my strenkeþe nought avayle
Þanne helpe me lorde / to morowe in my batayle
For þilke fuyre / þat whilom brent þee
Als wele as þat fuyre / nowe brynneþe me
And do to morowe / þat I have victorye
Myne bee þe travayle / ⁊and þine bee þe glorye
Þy souerayn temple / wol I most honouren
Of any place / and alle wey moste labouren
In þi plesaunce / ⁊and in þi crafftis stronge
And in þi temple / I wolle my ban honge
And al þe armes / of my companye
And euermor / vn to þat day I dye
Eterne fuyre / I wolle before þee fynde
And eke to this a vowe / I wol me bynde
My berd / myne here / þat / hangeþe lowe adovne
þat neuer yette ne felt offencioune
Of Rasour / ne of Sheere / I wolle þe gyve
And bee þi trewe sarvaunt whilest I lyve
Nowe lord have rowthe / vppon my sorowes soore
Gyve me þe victorye / I ne axsse no more
þe prayer stinte of Arcyta stronge
Þe rynges / on þe temple dore þᵗat honge
And eke þe doores / clatereden ful Faste
Of wiche Arcita / sumwhat him agaste
Þe fuyres brynon / vppon þᵉ auctor bryght
Þat hit gave al þe temple for to lyght
And sweet smelle / anoon þe grounde vp yaf
Withe þat Arcyte / uppe right his hand he haff
And more ensence / in fuyre he caste
wᵗith oþer ryghtes moo / and atte þᵉ laste
þe statue of Mars / bygane his hawberk ryng
And wᵗith þat soune / he herde a murmuryng
Ful lowe ⁊and dymme / wiche saydes þin is / victorie
For wiche / he gaffe to Mars / honoure⁊and glorie
And þus with ioye / and hoope / wel to fare
Arcyte aros / and forthe gan he for to fare
Als fayne as Fowle / is of þe bright sonne
And ryght a noon / suche stryffe þ̉er is be gonne
For þat graunte in þe hevene above
Bytwyixsse Venus / ⁊and þe god of love
And Mars / þe steerne þe god armypotente
Þat Iubiter / was busye it to stente
Til þat þe pale / Satourne þe coolde
Þat knewe so many / of aventures olde
Fonde in his olde exparyence and / art
Þat he ful sone / hathe plesid euerye parte
And sooþe is sayde / olde hathe grete a vanntage
In elde / is booþe wysdam and gret vsage
Men may þe olde at renne / and not at rede
Satourne a noon / to stynten stryff and drede
Albee þat hit is agenyst his kynde
Of al this stryff / he kan remedye Fynde
My dere douhteʳ Venus / quod than Satourne
My course / þat hathe so wyde for to tourne
haþe more povere / þan woot any man
Myne is þe drenchyng in þe See so wanne
Myn is þe pⁱrisonne / in þe derke cote
Myn is þe strangelyng ⁊and hanginge by þᵉ throte
Þe mourmur / and þe cheerlles rebellyng
Þe gooynynge ⁊and þe prevye eupresonyng
I do vengeannce / and pleyne correccioune
While I dwelle / In þe siugne of þe lyoune
Myne is þe unwyne / of þe heghe hallis
Þe Fallyng of þe towres / and þe walles
Vppon þe mynoure / or þe carpenter
I slowhe Samson / shakyng þe peloure
And myne ben / alle þe maladyse so colde
Þe derke traysounes / and þe castes olde
My lokyng is þe fadre of pestilence
Nowe wepe namore / I shal do diligence
Þat Palamon / whiche is þyne owne knyght
Shalle have his lady / as þowe hast him hyte
Þaughe Mars shal helpe / his knight yette naþelesse
Betwexsse yowe / tweyne / þer mot be som tyme pes
Al be yee nought of oon complexcioune
Þat causithe alday / suche devisioune
I am thyne owiredy / at þi wille
Nowe wepe namore / I wolle þi lust Fulfille
Nowe wol I stynte / of þees goddes above
Of Mars / and of Venus / goddes of love
And pleynly I wolle / telle yowe as I can
Þe grete effecte for wiche þat I beganne
Gret was þe Feste / in Athene þᵗat day
And eke þat lusty saysoune / þanne of May
Made euerye wyght to bee in suche plesaunce
Þat al þᵗat days / Iusten they and daunce
And spenteden it in Venus hie service
But by þe cause / þat þei sholden Rise
Eorly / for to seen þe gret Fyght
Vnto hir rest / went þey by tyme at nyght
And on þe morowe / whanne daye ganne spryng
Of hors ⁊and harneyse /þe noyse ⁊and clateryng
Þer was In hostelaries þe tovne / aboute
And to þe pallays / rode þer many a route
Of lordes / vppon steedis and palfrayes
Þer maiste þowe seen / devising of harneyse
So vnkouþe / ⁊and soo riche / and wrought so welle
Of Goldsmytherye / of enbroudyng and steele
Of sheldes bryght / testyerys / and trappures
Gold hewen helmes / hauberkys / ⁊and cootearmures
Lordes in paremoutꝭes / on þeire coursiers
Knyghtꝭes of þeyre retenue / with squiers
Nayling þe speris / and the helmes bokelynge
Gyginges of sheeldes / with lanyeres lasing
Þer as nede is / For they were not ydel
Þe Fomye stedes /upon þe goldyn brydelle
Gnawyng / faste and the Armurers also
wᵗith Fyle ⁊and hamoure / ryding to ⁊and Froo
Yemen on foote / and comunes many oon
Withe short staues / als thyk as þey may goon
Pypes / Trompes / nakers ⁊and / Clariouns
whiche in þe batayle / blowen blodye sownes
Þe palleys full of peple / boþe vppe ⁊and dovne
here three / here ten / holdyng þeyre questioune
Devunnge / on thes theban knightes twoo
Some saide þis / some saide it is no thyng soo
Some hoolde wᵗith him / wᵗith þe blake berde
Some wᵗith þe balled / some wᵗith þe thike herid
Some saide / he lokyd gryme / and he wolde Fyght
He hathe a Sparth / of twenty pounde of wight
Þus was þe halle / Fulle of þe devyning
Long or þe / sonne ganne uppe for to sprynge
¶ The grete Theseus /of his slepe gan wake
wᵗith mynstralsye / and þe noyse þey make
heldyng his chamboure / wᵗith iune þe palays riche
Til þat theban kneyghtes / booþe aliche
Honoured /were and in to þe place Fette
Duke Theseus / þane is at þe wyndowe sette
Arrayed / right as a god in his Throone
Þe people pressed / þedirwardes ful soone
him for to seen / and doone high reủer ence
And eke / to here his heste / and his sentence
An harowde uppon a Skaffolde / made an Oo.
Til at þe noyse / of þe people was doo
And whanne he seghe þe people / of noyse al stille
Þus sheved he / the myty dukes wille
Þe lord hathe / of his hie discressioune
Considerid / þat it were distruccioune
Off gentil bloode / to feyghten in þis wyse
In mortalle Batayle / nowe in þis Emprise
Wher for / to shapen / þat þey shalle not dye
He wolle / his Firste purpose þan modefye
¶ Noman þer fore / onpeyne / of losse of lyffe
Nomaner shotte pollax / ne shorte kneyff
In to þe lystes sent / or thedir bryng
Ne short swerd for stooke / withe poynt byting
Noman ne drawe / ne bere hit by his syde
Ne noman / shalle vn to his felawe ride
But oon course / wᵗith sharpe grounden spere
Foyne gybe him liste on foote / him selff to were
And he þat is at mesteffe / shal be take
And noute eslayne / but browte vn to a stake
Þat shal bee ordeynid / þer For eyþ̉er syde
But þedir he shalle by forse / ⁊and þer abyde
And yf so fal / þe chevetayn bee take
On oyþer syde / or ellys sleen his make
No lenger / shalle þat tourmout þan laste
God spede yowe / nowe goo ley on eche man faste
wᵗith long swerdes / and maces /to feyght yowr fille
Goo nowe youre weye / þis is þe lordes wille
Þe voyce of þe people / touched þe hevene
So loude þei cried alle / wᵗith mury stevene
God save suche a lorde / þᵗat is soo goode
He wille eneþe noon / effusion of blood
Vppon goon þe trompouꝭes / and þe melodye
And to lystes / rydeþe eche cumpanye
By ordenannce / þorowe owte þe Cittee large
Honged wᵗith clooþes of goolde / of grete charge
¶ Ful liche a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
These twoo Thebanes / on eyþer eche a syde
And afftur rode the qwene / and Emelye
And affter hem a noþ̉er companye
Of oon ⁊and other / afftir hir degree
(base) And after hem of comunes aft̉er here degre
And þus þei passen / thorughe onto þᵉ citee
And to þe thestree / cam theye be tyme
¶ hit nas not of þe day / yet fully pryme
Whanne sette was Theseus / Ful Riche an hyee
Ypolita þe Qwene / and Emelye
And oþer ladies / in degrees aboute
Vn to þeyre seetꝭes / preseþe al þe rowte
And westward / thorughe þe gate vnder Marte
Arcyte / ⁊and eke þe hundereþe of his partee
wᵗith ban̉er rede / is enterid right a noon
Right In þat same moment daun Palamon
Is vnder Venus Estwardes in þat place
Withe banner wheyght / hardye of chere ⁊and of face
Soo in þis world / to sechen vp ⁊and downe
So even / in al with outen varyacion
þer nere / suche compaygnyes noner tweyne
For þer was noon soo wyse / þᵗat coude yette saye
What anye had / of oþer a vauntage
Of worthynesse / ne of estate ne age
So even were þey chosyn For to gesse
And in to rengys / fayre þey hem dresse
¶ Whanne þᵗat þeyre names / red were everich oon
Þat in þeyre nommbre / guyle were þer noon
Þoo were þoo gates shutte and cruyde was loude
Dooþe nowe youre devoyre / yownge knytꝭes proude
Þe herandes / leffte þeyre prykyng vppe ⁊and downe
Nowe Ryngen trompes lowde / ⁊and clariowne
Þer nys namore to sayn / but Este ⁊and weste
In gooþ þe sharpe speers / in to pareste
And oke þe sharpe spore / in to þe herse syde
Þer seen men / who can Iovste / ⁊and whoo can ride
Þer sheveren shafftꝭes / vppon sheldes thykke
He feeleþe / thorouge þe hert spoone þe prikke
Vppe sprengen speeris / twenty foote on heyght
Owte goon þe swerdes / as silver whyght ⁊and bryght
Þe helmes þey to hewen / and to shredde
Owte bresteþe þe blood / wᵗith sterne stremes rede
wᵗith myghtye maces / þe boonys þey to breste
He thorughe þe thikke of þe througge gan threste
Þer stomblen steedis stronge / and downe goþᵉ al
He rolleþe ondyr foote as doþe aballe
He foyneþe on his Fete wᵗith a tronchoune
And he hym hurtelleþe / wᵗith his hors adowne
He þorowe þe bodye is borne ⁊and sithe is take
Maugrye his hede / and browte on to þᵉ stake
As Forwardes was /For þer he moste abyde
A noþer / ladde is on þat oþer syde
And som tyme / dooþe hem Theseus to reste
hem to reffresshe / and drunken yf hem lyste
Ful ofte þᵗat daye / have þess Thebanes twoo
To gedre mette ⁊and wrovght eche oþ̉er woo
Vnhorsid haþe eche oþer / of hem tweye
þer nas no Tygre / in þe vale of Galgophye
Whanne hir whelpe is stollen / while it is luyte
So crewell on the hunte / as is Arcyte
For jalowse herte / vppon þis Palamon
Nen belmarye / noon so ffiers a lioune
Þat him bisies / For his hurgre woode
Ne of his preye / desyreþe soo his bloode
As Palamon / to slee his Foo Arcyte
Þe Ialous strook ꝭes / upon hir helmes byte
Owte Rennythe þᵉ bloode / on boþe hir sides rede
Some tyme an ende þer is / of eủer ye dede
For er þe sonne / vn to þe reste wente
þe strong kyng Emetreus / haþe þee hente
þis Palamon / as he faught wᵗithArcyte
And made his swerde / depe in his fleshe to byte
And by þe forse of twenty / is he take
But al for nowte he browght was to þe stake
His hardye herte / may hym helpe right nought
He moste abyde / whan þat he is kaute
By Force / ⁊and eke by compossyssionne
Whoo soroweþe nowe / but woofulle Palamon
Þat mot nomore / goo a gayne to feyght
¶ And whanne þᵗat Theseus / he perseyvid wel þᵗat syte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
Ne shalle no leng̉er to his felawe goone
He cried / hoo nomore / for it is doone
I wolle bee trewe Iuge / and nowte partye
Arcyte of Thebes / shalle have Emelye
Þat by his Fortune / haþe hir fayre wonne
A noon þᵉʳ is a voyce of peple be gonne
For ioye of þis / so hie and loudewᵗith al
hit semed / þat þe lystes shoulde Falle
What can Feyre venus / doon aboue
What seyþe shee now / what doþe þis quene of love
But wepithe soo / for wantyng of hir wille
Til þat hir teers / in þe lystes Felle

And Emelye / hym lovethe so tendyrlye
And he / hir serveþe agayne so gentillye
Þat nas never word hem bytwene
Of Ialousie / or any oþ̉er teene
Þus Endithe Palamon / ⁊and Emelye
And god save nowe / althis compainye
Loo þus here eondiþe þe Kyntꝭes tale

l.hi: and nexste here folowyng / be gynnithe here þe ꝓprologe of the Milners tale

div.l: Whan þat þe knyght had þus his tale etold
In al þe companye . nas þer yong ner old
But þat þey sayde it was a noble storye
And worþy to bee drawen in memorye
And namlye þe gentelis eueryche oon
Oure hooste loughe . ⁊and sword by saynt Iohan
Þis gooþe aright . vnbokelde his þe male
Lette see whoo shalle telle nowe A noþ̉er tale
For sekurlye þis game is welle by gonne
Now telliþe yee sir monke yf þᵗat ye konne
Somwhat to qwite wᵗith þe knight his tale
Þe Milner for dronke . was al woron pale
So þat ouneoþes vppon his horse he satte
He wold avale . neyþ̉er hoode ne hatte
Nabyd noman for al his covrtasie
But pylates voyse . he gan to crye
And swore by Armes bloode ⁊and by boonys
I can a noble tale nowe for þe noons
Wᵗith wiche I wolle nowe qweyght þᵉ knyght his tale
¶ Oure hoost ꝑperceyvid / he was dronke of alle
And sayde Abyde Robyn my leve broþ̉er
Some bett̉er man shall telle vs First a noþ̉er
Abyde ⁊and lete vs wyrche . nowe thryfftelye
By goddis soule ꝙquod he þat wylle I noute
For I wolle speke . or ellꝭes nowe goo my weye
Oure hoste Aunswerd what go Adevelisweye
Þowe arte A foole þi witte is ouer come
¶ Nowe herkeniche quod þis Miller Alle ⁊and some
But First I make A protestacion
Þat I am dronke I knowe it be my soune
And þer fore yff I mys speke or saye
Wyte it þe Ale of Souþewerke I yowe praye
For I wolle telle A legende ⁊and A lyff
Booþe of A carpenter ⁊and of his wyf
Howe þat þe Clerke sette þe wreyght cappe
¶ Þe Reve Answerd Robyn now stynte þi clappe
Lat beo þei levde dronken harlotye
Hit is booþe synne / and eke greete folye
Tappeyrin Any man / or him deffame
And eke to bryng wyves / in suche A name
Þowe mayest enowghe of oþ̉er thynges seyn
Þis dronken Miller / speke ful sone A gayne
¶ And sayd leve broþer / O leve oswold
Whoo naþe noo wyf / he nys noo Cukwolde
But I sey not þer fore þat þow art oon
Þer been ful good wyves . right many oon
Whi art þow Angery wᵗith my tale nowe
I have A wyf pardee / als wel a stowe
Þette nold I For þe oxssen in my plowhe
To take vppon me more þan I nowhe
As demen of my selff þat I wer won
I wol beleven Ay þat I am noon
¶ An husband shoulde not be in qvesetyf
Off godes previtee . ne of his wyff
So he maye Fynde godes foysou þeer
Of þe remenaunt . needeþe nought tenqvere
What shoulde I sayn but þᵗat þis lewde Milner
He nil his wordes for noman forbere
But telle his chorles tale in his manere
Me For thynkeþᵉ I shal Reherse hit here
¶ And þ̉erfore eủery gentil wight I praye
Demeþe it not . For goddes love þᵗat I seye
Of euyl entente / but for I mot Reherse
Hir tales Alle . beo þey bett̉er or wersse
Or ellꝭes fayled sōmme of my matere
And þer fore who so liste not here
Tourne ouer þe lef / and chese some oþ̉er tale
For ye shalle fynde enowe gret ⁊and smale
Historial þyngꝭes touchyng gentillesse
Some Mora litee and som holynesse
Blameþe not me give þat yee chese A mysse
Þe Milner is a chorle ye knowe welle þis
So was þe Reve Eke / and soo þer were moo
And harlotʳye þey spak booþe twoo
Avyseþe yowe / and put me owte of blame
And eke men shalle not maken eornste of game

l.hi:
Loo nowe here eondiþe þe prologgꝭus of þe
milneris tale/

and nexte Folouyng bygynneþe
þe milners tale .

div.l: Whilom þer was dwellyng at Oxenford
A Riche knoffe þat held gestes to borde
Þe wiche of his craffte he was A carpent̉er
Wᵗith him þer was dwellyng a poure scoler
Þat had lerned arte / but Al his fantasye
Was tourned / For to lerne Astrologye
And coude A certayne of concluciones
To deme by / Interrogaciounes
If þat men axsed him in certayne houres
Wher men shoulde have drought ellꝭes shoures
Or yf men Aske hem / what þᵗat shoulde be falle
Of euery thyng I may not Reken Alle
¶ Þis Clerke was clepid / heond Nicholas
He koude of derne love / And prevye solas
And þ̉erto he ʷᵃˢ slye / ⁊and Ful pryue
And liche A mayde / meke For to see
¶ A chaumbre had he in þᵗat hostelarye
Allone wᵗith outen any companye
Ful Fetisly Dyte / withe erbes swoote
And he him selfe Als swete as is þe rote
Of likoris or elles of setwale
His Almageste / And bookes gret or smale
His Astrologye . longyng for his Arte
Heos augryme stoonys / liing ful feyre A parte
On shelves couched at hees beddes hede
His presse Ecoủered wᵗith A faldyng Rede
And al above þer lay A gay savtree
On wiche he made an nyghtes melodye
So swetlye off þᵗat al þe chaumb̉er Ronge
And Aungelous ad Virgenem was þoo his songe
And Aftir þᵗat he song þe kyngꝭes note
Ful offte Eblessid was his mury throte
And þus þis swete clerke his tyme spente
Afftir his freondes fyndyng ⁊and his Rente
¶ Þis Carpenter had E wedded newe awyffe
Whome þᵗat he loved / as his owen lyfe
Of eghteeneþe yeere shee was I gesse of Age
Ialous he was / and kepte hir streyte in cage
For shee was wylde and yong and he was olde
And demed him selffe / wel liche a Cukkewolde
He knew not Catoune For his witte was Rude
Þat bad men to wedde þeyre symilitude
Men shoulde wedde / Affter þeyre de gree
Wheþer hit happon / it be he or sheo
Or elleꝭes loo Afftir þeyre owne estate
For yowþe and elde ben offt at debate
But sithe þe wreyte was falle in þe snare
He moste enduren as oþer folke his care
¶ Fayre was þis younge wyf And þ̉er wᵗith alle
As Any wesell hir bodye gente ⁊and smal
A sceynte she wered barred Al wᵗith silke
A barmecloþe as wheyte as morowe mylke
Vppon hir leondes ful of many A goore
White was hir smokke ⁊and enbrowdered by fore
And eke be hynde on her coler A bowte
Of colblak silke . wᵗith Inne ⁊and eke wᵗith owte
Þe tapes of hir whyte fayre wolupere
Were of þe same sute of hir colere
Hir Filette brode of silke ⁊and sette fulle hie
And sekourly shee hadde A lekerovs eye
Ful smale epulled were her browes twoo
And þoo were bente and blac as any sloo
Shee was moore blissful / vppon for to see
Þanne is newe blossemed / Ienettes tree
And sofftre þanne þe wolle is of A weddre
And by hir gurdell þer hang a purse of leþer
Tasselde wᵗith silke ⁊and perled wᵗith latoune
In al þis worlde to seche vppe ⁊and downe
Þer is noman so weyse / þat kouþe thenche
So gaye a popelotte or ellꝭes a wēnche
Ful brighte was þe shyning of hir hew
Þanne in þe toure / þe noble forged newe
But of hir song hit was als loude and yerne
As any swalou sittyng on A berne
Þer to shee kouþe skyppe and maken men game
Arte Any kidde or kalfe Filowyng hir dame
Hir mowthe was swete as is bragote or meþe
Or horde of Apples liging in Any hethe
Wynsyng shee was as is A younge colte
Long as a maste and vprite as A bolte
A brooche shee bare vppon hir lowe collere
As broode as is þe boose of a bokelere
Hir shoon were lassed vppon hir legges hye
Shee was a prymerolle / A pygges nyee
For Any lorde to lyen in his bed
Or yette for any yoman for to wedde
¶ Nowe sir ⁊and effte sir þus be felle þe cas
Þat on A day þis good hende Nicholas
Fel wᵗith þis younge wyf to Rage ⁊and pleye
While þᵗat hir husbond was þanne at Osneye
As Clerkes been Ful sotyle ⁊and ful qveynte
And prevely he kaught hir by þᵉ qweynte
And saide I wisse but yf I have my wille
For deorne love of þee lemman I spille
And held hir Faste by þe haunche boones
And saide hir leman / love me wele at oones
Or I wolle deye so god my soule mot save
And shee spronge þanne as A colt doþe in A thrave
And wᵗith hir hede shee wreyed faste A weye
Shee saide I wolle not kysse þee be my Feye
Whey lette bee qd ych . late be swete Nicholas
Or I wolle crye . owte harrowe and ellas
Doþe wey yowr handes for youre courtesye
Þis Nicholas ganne mercye for to crye
And spake so fayre and proferd him so faste
Þat shee hir love hym graunte at þe laste
And swore hir ooþe by saynt Thomᵃs of kente
Þat shee wold ben at his comaundement
Whanne þat shee may her leysoure wele espye
Myn husband is so fulle of Ialowsye
But yf yee wayte wele / and bee prevye
I wot right wele I name but ded qd shee
¶ For yee mote be ful derne as in þis cas
Nay þer of care yee nowte quod Nicholas
A Clerke had Full lewdelye be sette his wylle
But yf he kouþe A carpenter be gyle
And þus þer were A corded ⁊and sworne
To wayten A tyme As I sayde yow be forne
Whanne Nicholas had doon þus eủerye deele
And thakked her Aboute þe leondes weele
He kyssethe her swete And takeþe his saute
And playeþe þer on ⁊and makeþe melodye
¶ Þanne felle it þus þᵗat to þᵉ pariche chorche
Cristes oune werkes þanne . þer to worche
Þis goode wyf went vppon an halydaye
Hir forehede shone / als lyght as anye daye
So was it wasshe . whan þᵗat shee leffte werke
¶ Nowe was þer of chirch a parishe clerke
Þe wiche þat was clepid þer Absolou
Croulle was his here / and as þe gold hit shon
And strouted as a Fane / large ⁊and broode
Ful streyte ⁊and even laye his Iolye swoode
His rod was rede / hees / eyen grey as goos
Wᵗith poules wyndowes corven on his shoes
In hosyn Rede . he went ful fetovselye
Ecloþed he was Ful smalle ⁊and propurlye
Al in A kirtil of light wachchette
Ful fayre ⁊and thykke been þe poyntes sette
Aboven þat he hadde A gay surplise
Als wheyte as is þe blossom on þe Ryse
A mury chylde he was so god me save
Full well koude he . lete bloode clippe ⁊and shave
And make Achartre of lond and acquitaunce
In twentye manes coude he trippe ⁊and davnce
Affter þe scole of Oxenford yoo
And wᵗith his leggꝭes casten too ⁊and Froo
And pleyne songes vppon A smal Rubibe
And som tymes he song a loude qvenyble
He kouthe some tyme pleyne on a Geterne
In the towne þer nas no brewhouse ne taverne
Þat he ne vesited / withe his solas
Þer þat any gaye tapester was
But sooþe to seyne / he was somwhat sqweymous
Of krackyng ⁊and of speche Ful daıı̄ungerouse
¶ Þis Absolon þᵗat was þus Ioly ⁊and gaye
Gooþe wᵗith a sensoure / vppon þe sonondaye
Sensyng þe wyves / of þe parishe Faste
And many A lovelye loke on hem caste
To loke on hem him thoute A mury lyffe
And namlye vppon þe carpent̉eris wyff
Shee was so propre and swete ⁊and lekerows
¶ I Dare welle seyne and shee had ben A movse
And he A catte / he wold her hent A noon
Þis Parishe Clerke þis Ialye Absolon
Hathe In his herte / suche A love longyng
Þat of noo wyff wold he take offeryng
For courtesye he saide þᵗat he wold noon
Þe moone whanne it was night Ful bryght shone
¶ And Absolon haþe his geterne etake
For paramours . he thoughte For wake
And Forþe he gooþe Iolye ⁊and Amerows
Til þat he cam to þe Carpenters howse
A litelle to fore þe Cokke þenne hade crowe
And dressyd hym vndir a shoppe wyndowe
Wich þat was vppon þe carpent̉ers walle
He singithe in his voyce so gentil ⁊and smal
Nowe dere ladye / yf þat þi wille be
I pray yowe þᵗat yee wolle Rewe on Me
Ful welle Acordyng in his geternyng
Þis Carpenter A wooke ⁊and herd hym syng
And spake vnto his wyf / and sayde a noon
What Alisou herestow nowght Absolon

l.hi: So woweþe her þat him was woo bygon

div.l: He wakeþe Al þe nyght ⁊and al þe daye
He kembed hees lokkes / and made him wondir gay
He woweþe her by menys and brocage
And swore he wold been hir owne page .
He syngeþe and brockeþe as doþe þe nyghtingale
He sent her pyement booþe ⁊and spiced Ale
And wafforis piping hote / owte of þe glede
And For þat he wold spede he proferd mede
For some folkes wolle be wonne . for Richesse
And some for strookes / ⁊and some for gentilesse
¶ And For to shewe his lyghtnesse ⁊and his mastrye
Some tyme he playd Erawde ou skaffold hye
But what awaylethe him as in þis cas
So loveþe she him this Fayre Nicholas
Þᵗat Absolon may blowe þe buckes horne
He had For his laboure nought but A scorne
And þus shee makeþe Absolon hir Ape
And Al his Eornste torniþe but to A Iape
¶ For sooþe it is þis proverbe may not lye
Men seyn Al weyes þat þe nyght sley
Makeþe þe Fer love / For to be looþe
For þowe þᵗat Absolon bee woode or wroþe
By cause þat he was fer from her syght
Þis neghe Nicholas stoode aye in his lyght
¶ Nowe bere þee wele / I rede hende Nicholas
For Absolon may wepe ⁊and singe ellas
And soo byfelle . þat on A saturdaye
Þis Carpent̉er was goone til Osnaye
And Nicholas ⁊and oure dame Alesoıı̄un
A cordid were to þis conclusion
Þat Nicholas shoulde shapen him A wyle
Þis cely Ialous husband / For to be gyle
And yf so bee þat þe game went A ryght
Shee shoulde slepe in his Armes at nyght
For þat was his desire ⁊and hers Alsoo
And Right anoon . wᵗith outen wordes Moo
Þis Nicholas wolle noo longer tarye
But tille his Chaumbre doþe ful Faste carie
Booþe mete ⁊and drynke For a day or tweye
And to hir husband bad hir for to seye
Yf þat he axsed Afftre þis Nicholas
She shoulde seye shee nist wher her was
Off al þat day she seyhe hym not wᵗith yee
She trowed he was Fallen in sum maledye
For For noo crye þᵗat hir mayde kouþe calle
He nold Aunswere for ought þat myght be falle
¶ Þis passithe forþe al þe Saturday
Þat Nicholas stille in his bed laye
And ete ⁊and slepe ⁊and did what him liste
Til on þe sonday þat þe sonne gane Reste
Þis cely carpenter . haþe grete marvayle
Of Nicholas or what thyng might him eyle
And sayde I am A drede . by saynt . Thomᵃs
Hit stondiþe not Al A Right wᵗith Nicholas
God shild hit / þat he deye ought sodaynelye
Þis world is Ful ferful . nowhe sekurlye
I Sawhe to day a corpus borne on to þᵉ chorche
Þat nowe on monday laste I sawhe him wirche
¶ Goo vp quod he vn to his man A noon .
Cleepe at his doore . or knokke wᵗith sum stoone
Looke howe it is and telle me boldlye
His knave sterte him vppe þanne Ful stordelye
And at þe chaumbre dore wheyle þat he stoode
He cryed ⁊and knokked at þat he were woode
What how what do yee my mastre Nicholaye
Howe may ye slepen þus all þis longe daye
But al for nought . herde he neuer a worde
An hoole he fonde . right lowe vppon ye bord
Þer as þe catte was wont i to crepe
And at þe hole he loked ondir deope
So at þe laste he had of him a syght
Þis Nicholas seete gapyng aye vpright
As he had keked vppon þe newmoone
A doune he gooþe ⁊and told his mastre sone
In what Aray he sawhe þis ilke man
¶ Þis Carpenter to blessen him biganne
And saide ladye helpen vs nowe Frydesswyde
A man wot litille what shalle him be tyde
Þat man is Fallen wᵗith his Astronomye
Wᵗith some woodnesse or some Agonye
I thought welle howe þᵗat hit wold bee
Men shoulde not knowen of goddes pvitee
Ye blessid bee Alwey þe lewed man
Þat nought oonlye . but his byleeve can
So ferde A noþ̉er clerke wᵗith Astronomye
He walked in to þe feldes for to prye
Vppon þe sterris to wit what shoulde be falle
Til he was In a marble pitte efall
He saughe nowte þer but yette be seynt Thomᵃs
Me Rueþe soore / For þis heend Nicholas
He shalle be Ratid of his studeyng
Yif þat I may by Ihesus hevene kyng
¶ Get me a staffe / whiles þou mayst vndersparre
Wheyles þat þowe Robyn heve þe dore of harre
He shal oute of his stondyng as I gesse
And to þe chaumbre dore he ganne him dresse
His knave was a strong chorle For þe Noons
And by þᵉ haspe he have þe dore at oones
Þᵗat in to þe floore . þe doore felle A noon
Þis Nicholas sette stille as anye stoone
And euer gapeþe opwardes in to þayre
Þis Carpenter wende he were in dispayre
And hente him by þe shoulderes myghtlye
And shooke him herde / and cryde dispetouslye
What Nicholas howe what loke A downe
A wake and thinke on crystes passioune
I crowche þee froom elves ⁊and frome wighes
And god in þis house bee to nyghtes
On foure halves here loo vs Abowte
And on þe thresswolde of þe dorre wᵗith outen
Ihesus cryste and eke þe saynt benedyte
Nowe blesse þis howse from everye wyked wyght
For þe . nightes warye þe wight Pater Noster
Where wentestowe where þowe petris sustre
And at þe laste þis heend Nicholas
Ganne for ᵗᵒ seken soore / and seyde ellas
Shal al þe world be loste affte soones nowhe .
Þis Carpenter aunswered man what saystowe
What thynke on god as we doon men þᵗat swynke
Þis Nicholas Answerd Faste Feche me drynke
And afftir ward wolle I speke in previtee
Of certayne thyng þat toucheþe þe ⁊and mee
I wolle telle hit þee / noon oþir man certayne
Þis Carpent̉er gooþe doune / and comthe A gayne
And browte of myti Ale A quarte
And whanne þᵗat eche of hem had dronke his parte
Þis Nicholas his doore þoo faste he shete
¶ And doune by hym þe Carpent̉er he sette
And sayde Iohan myn hoste . so leve and dere
Þou shalt vppon þi trowþe ensure me here
Þat to no wyght þowe shalt þis counsaile wire
For it is cristes counceyle þat I seye
And yf þow telle it man þow art For lore
For þis vengeaunce þowe shalt have þer Fore
Þat yf þow be wreye me þowe shalte Rynne woode
Nay crist for bede hit for his hoolye bloode
Quod þoo þis cely man I name noo labbe
Ne þauhe I sey hit I nam nat leffe to gabbe
Seye what þowe wolte I shalle it never telle
To wyf ne chylde by him þᵗat harowed helle
¶ Nowe Iohan quod Nicholas I wolle not lyee
I have efounden in myn Astrologye
As I have looked in þe moone so bryght
Þat nowe on monday nexst at quarter night
Shalle falle a Rayne / and þᵗat soo wyld ⁊and woode
Þat halfe so greete nas neuer Noyes floode
Þis world he sayde in lasse þanne in an oure
Shal Al be dreynt so hydous is þe shoure
Þus shall man kynde drenche and leesse his lyf
Þis Carpenter Answerd / ellas my wyff
And shal shee drenche ellas myn Alesoune
For fere of þis he felle Almoste A doune
And saide is þer no Remedye in þis cas
Yisse yisse ful good quod þoo heende Nicholas
Yf þᵗat þowe wolt worche After loore ⁊and Rede
Þou maiste not worche Afftir þin oune hede
¶ For þus saithe Salamon so wyse ⁊and trewe
Wirche al by counsayle ⁊and þowe shalt not Rewe
And yf þowe wylt nowe wirche by trew counsayle
I vndretake hit wᵗith outen maste or sayle
Yette shalle I save hir boþe þee ⁊and mee
Haste þowe not herde / howe þᵗat saved was Noe
Whanne þᵗat oure lorde had warned him byforne
Þat al þe worlde wt þat Floode shoulde beo for lorne
¶ Yisse quod þis Carpenter ful yeere A goo
Haste towe not harde quod Nicholas Alsoo
Þe sorowe of Noe withe his Feleshippe
Er þat he myght gete his wyff to shippe
Him had wele lever . I dare vnder take
At þilke tyme þanne al hees oxen blake
Þat shee hadde had a shippe þer hir selfe A loone
¶ And þer fore wotyste þowe what is best to doone
Þis Axsithe haste . and of an hastye thyng
Men may not preche and maken tareyng
Anoon goo gete vs faste in to þis Inne
A knedyng trowhe or ellꝭes A kemelyne
For eche of vs but looke þᵗat þey bee large
In wiche men may wel Rowen as In a barge
And have þeyre vetayles wᵗith hem suffisaunt
But for oon daye . fye on þe Remnaunt
Þe wat̉er shalle A slake . and goon A weye
A boute prime on þe nexst daye
But Robyn may nat wit of þis þi knave
Ne nought þⁱ mayde Gylle I may not save
Axsse þen not whey / For þowhe þowe axsse it me
I wolle not telle þe goddis previte
Siffiseþe þe but gyff / þⁱ wyttes be madde
To have als grete a gras as þat Noe had
Þy wyf I shalle wel saven have þowe no dovte
Goo nowe þy wey ⁊and spede þee here Aboute
¶ But whanne þowe hast for hir ⁊and þee ⁊and me
E goton vs þeos knedyng tubbes three
Þan shalt þowe hang hem in þe Rooffe an hye
Þat noman of oure purviaunse espie
And whanne þowe haste doone þus / as I have saide
And haste oure wetayle in hem welle I layde
And eke an axsse to smyte þe corde a twoo
Whanne þᵗat þe wat̉er comythe þᵗat we may goo
And breke an hoole on hye vppe on þe gable
Vn to þe gardyn wardes towardes þe stable
Þat we may Freely passen forþe oure waye
Whanne þᵗat þe grete shoure is paste A weye
Þanne shalt þowe swymme as mury I vndirtake
As dooþe þᵉ wheyte ducke / Afftir þe drake
Þanne wolle I Clepe howe Alison howe Iohan
Bee mury for þe floode wol passe A noon
And þowe wolt sayn hayle maiste Nicholay
Goode morowe I see þe weele / For it is daye
And þanne we shulle bee lordes al owre lyve
Of alþis world as Noye was ⁊and his wyff
¶ But þat of on thyng I warne þe ful Right
Bee wel A wysid on þᵗat yche nyght
Þat we been enterid wᵗith sune þᵉ shippes borde
Þat noon of vs ne speke nought a worde
Ne clepe ne creye but bydden þeyre prayere
For it is goddes owne hestes so deere
Þy wyff ⁊and þowe moste honge Fer A twynne
For þat be twyxste yowe þer bee noo synne
Namore In lokyng / þanne þer shalle in dede
Þis ordenaunce is sayde goo god þe spede
¶ To morowe at night / whanne men ben al on slepe
In to oure knedyng tubbes wol we crepe
And sitte þer stille Abydyng þer godes grace
Go þowe þy wey I have noo lenger space
To make of þis no lenger sermonyng
¶ Men sayn sende þe wyse ⁊and say noo thyng
Þowe art so wyse it needeþe not þe teche
Goo save oure lyves and þᵗat I þe beseche
Þis cely Carpent̉er gooþe forþe his wey
Ful offte he sayde ellas ⁊and wellawaye
And to his wyff he told his pvitee
¶And shee was ware and knew hit bett̉er þan he
What al þis qweynte caste / was for to meene
Shee ferd for fere as shee wold dede been
And sayde alas man goo þy wey A Noon
Helpe vs to scape or we be dede echoone
I am þy trewe werray wedded wyff
Goo nowe dere spouse / and helpe to sauve oure lyff
Loo wiche thyng is nowe gret Affeccioune
Men may deye of suche ymagenacioune
Soo deepe loo impressioun may be take
Þis cely Carpent̉er bygynnythe to qwake
Him semithe verraylye / þᵗat he may see
To drenchyn Alesoune his oune dere
+Noyes flood cometh rennyng as þᵉ se
He wepithe waylethe ⁊and makeþe sory chere
He sykeþe soore . wᵗith many an hevy thovte
He gooþe and getiþe him A knedyng trowhe
And eke A tubbe ⁊and A large kymlyne
Ful prevelye he sent hem to his Inne
And hang hem vppe in þe Rooff wᵗith prevyte
Hes owne handes he made ladderis þree
To clymben by þe ronges and by þe stalkes
Vn to þe tvbbes honging by þe balkes
And hem haþe vetayled boþe trowhe ⁊and tobbe
Wᵗith brede ⁊and chese . and good ale in A Iubbe
Sufficeaunt e noughe as For A daye
But or he had made al þis Arraye
He sent his knave ⁊and his wenche Alsoo
Vppon his erond to lond For til goo
¶ And on þe monday whanne it drowe to nyght
He shitte his dorre / withe outen candel light
And dressyd al thyng as it shoulde be
And shortly clomben þey vppe alle three
Þey setten stille wele A fourlong weye
Nowe Pater Noster clome / saide / Nicholaye
And clome quod Iohan / and clome qd Alysoune
Þis Carpenter saide his devocioune
And stille he sittiþe and biddiþe his prayere
A wayting on þe Rayne gyf he might hit here
Þe dede slepe for wereye bysines
Fel on þis carpent̉er right I Gesse
Abowte couerfen tyme / or lytel moore
For travaylling of his gooste he groneþe sore
And gynneþe to Rowte for his hede mislaye
Downe of þe laddre stalkeþe Nicholaye
And Alisoune ful soffte A downe hir spedde
Wᵗith outen wordes moo þey goon to bedde
Þer nas but Revelle ⁊and gret melodye
And þus lyen Alison / and Nicholas
In besynesse in mirthe and in solase
Til þat þe belle of lavdes gane to Rynge
And Freres in þeyre chaunselle ganne to syng
Þis parishe clerke . þis Amerowse Absolo
Þat is For love allweye so woo by goone
Vppon þe monday / he was Osnaye
Wᵗith coumpanye him to disporte and playe
And Asked of A Chanoune cloysterere
Ful prevelye / affter Iohan Carpentere
And he drowhe him A parte owte of þe chyrche
And sayde I saughe him noute þis day here wirche
¶ Sythe saturday I leve þᵗat he be wente
For tymbre þer oure / Abbot haþe him sente
For he is wonte . For tymbre for to goo
And dwellyng atte þe graunge a day or twoo
Or ellꝭes he is at his house certayne
Wher þᵗat he bee I can not sooþelye seyne
¶ Þis Absolon was ful Iolye þanne ⁊and lyght
And thought now is tyme to wake Al nyght
For sikurlye I sawe him not storynge
A boute his dore sythe day by ganne to spryng
So mote I thryve I shalle at cokkes crowe
Ful prevely knocken at his wyndowe
Þat stante so lowe vppon hir boures walle
To Alisoune nowe wolle I tellen al
My love longing . at hardest I shalle not misse
But at þe leeste weye I shalle hir kisse
Some maner counforte shal I have ꝑpar Faye
My mouþe haþe eched / Al þis long daye
Whan þᵗat þᵉ Firste Cocke haþe crowe A noone
Vpryste þis Iolye lover þis Absolon
And him arrayethe gaye at poynt devise
But Firste he cheveþe greynes and licouryse
To smellen soote or he had kempte his here
Vndir his tonge a trew love grasse he bere
For þer bye he wende for to bee graciouse
¶ He Romeþe to þe Carpenters howse
And stille he stoode vnder þe shoppe wyndowe
Vn to his breste it Raught it was so lowe
And soffte he knokkeþe . wᵗith a semy sowne
What do ye nowhe honycombe . myn Alesoun
My fayre brid my swette synamome loo
A wake lemon myn . and speke me too
Wel lytelle thynke yee vppon my wo
Þat for yoᵘur love I swelt nowe as I goo
No wondre is þoughe I mowrne and swete
Right as þe lambe afftir þe modres teete
I wysse leman I have suche love longyng
Þᵗat liche A turtille trewe is my mornyng
I may nowte ete namoore þan may a mayde
Go frome þe wyndowe / Iacke fole shee sayde
I love bette oþ̉er and ellꝭes I were to blame
Welle more þan þe by Ihesu ⁊and his dame
Go forþe thy weye or ellꝭes I wille caste Astoone
Go lette me slepe A twenty devilweye
Ellas quod Absolon and wellaweye
Þat trewloue was evyr so evil bysette
Þanne kisse me swete sithe I may be no bette
For Ihesus love / and for þe love of me
Wiltowe þan goo . þy wey quod shee
Yee serteyse lemman quod þis Absolon
Þanne make Redye quod shee I come A noon
¶ Þis Absolon doune sette him on his kenes
Derke was þe nyght as pyche or any cole
And at þe wyndow shee put owte hir hole
Þis Absolon him selfe ne better ne wersse
But wᵗith his mowthe he kyste hir naked ers
Ful sauourely / or he were ware of þis
A backe he sterte ⁊and þowte hit was amisse
For wel he wyste a womman had noo berd
He felte a thyng Al Rowhe and long herid
And saide fye ellas what have I doo
Tehe quod shee and clapte þe wyndowe too
And Absolon gooþe forþe a sory pas
A berde A berde thought heonde Nicholas
By goddes Corpus þis gooþe fayre ⁊and welle
Þis Cely Absolon hard eueryche deele
And on his lippe he ganne angre for to byte
And to him selffe he sayde I shalle qveyte
Whoo Rubbithe nowe whoo Frotiþe nowe his lippis
Wᵗith douste wᵗith strawe wᵗith clooþes and wᵗith chyppes
But Absolon þᵗat seythe ful offete ellas
My soule y be take to þe Satanasse
But I had lever þan Alle þis towne qd he
Of þis despite A wroken for to bee
Ellas qd he ellas I nade ebleynte
His hoote love is colde / and al eqveynte
For frome the tyme þᵗat he had kyste her ers
Of peramours / he sette nought at A cresse
For he was heled of his maladye
Ful often paramours he can þer deffye
And wepte as dooþe a chylde þᵗat is ebeete
¶ A soffte paas he wente ouer þe strete
Vn to a smythe men callen daun Gervyse
Þᵗat in his Forge smyþed plough herneyse
He sharpithe shares ⁊and covlters . besylye
Þis Absolon knokkeþe al eselye
And sayde vn to Gerveyse and þᵗat a noon
What who art towe it am I Absolon
What Absolon what criest swete oreete
Whi Rise yee soo raþe . O benedicitee
What eyliþe yowe some gaye gyrle god it woot
Haþe browte yowe þus in þe veritote
Be saynt Note ye woote welle what I mene
This Absolou ne wrought not abene
Of all his play no worde agein him gaf
He had more towe . on his distaf .
Than absolon answerd and seid frend so dere
The hote cultre in þe Chymney here
As lene hit me . I haue þ̉erwith to don
And I shal bring hit the agein full sone
Gerveis answerd / a certes ⁊and hit were gold
Or in a poke nobles all vntold
¶ Thou shuldest it haue as I am true Smyth
Ey cristis fote / what woll ye do therwith
Therof qd Absolon / be as be may
I shal wele telle þe to morow day
And caught the cultre by the hote stele
Ful softly oute Atte the dore gan he stele
And wente vnto þe Carpenters Walle
He coughed first and knokked þ̉erwith all
Vpon þe wyndow right as he did er
This Alisoun Answerd . hey who is ther
That knokkith so . I warant it is a theof .
See nay quod he . god wote my swete lyf .
I am thyne Absolou : thi dere derlyng
Of gold quod he . I haue the brought A Ryng
My moder gaf hit me . so god me save .
Full fyne hit is . and þ̉erto wele I grave
This woll I geve you ⁊and ye woll me kysse
This Nicholas was risen vp to pisse
And thought he wold amenden all all þᵗat iape
That he shuld kysse his taille er þᵗat he scape
And vp þe wyndow he did he hastely
And leid his taill ende oute ful pryvily
Over the buttok vnto þe haunche bon
Therwith speke / this clerk this Absolou
Speke þᵘ faire swete bird . I note wheþ̉er þᵘ Art
This Nicholas let flie a cherlissh fart
As grete as hit had ben a thondir dynte
And wᵗith the stroke . he was almoste blynt
And Absolou was redy wᵗith Iren hote
And Nicholas in þe Ars he smote .
Of goth the skyn an hondfull brode abowte
The hote cultre brent so þ̉ere his foule toute
That for the smert ; he wēnt for to dye .
As he were wode . he gan for to crie .
How . water . water . help for goddis hert
This Carpent̉er oute of his slombre stert
And herd oon crie . water as he were wood
And thought here comyth now ; nowels flode
And sette him vp . wᵗithouten wordis mo .
And with an Axe . he smote the cordis atwo
And doune goth all he founde neither to selle
Brede ner Ale / tyll he come to þe celle
Vpon þe flore and þ̉ere a swou he laye
Vpstert then Alisou and Nicholaie .
And criden oute and harowe in þe strete
The neighbours þ̉ere . bothe the smale and grete
In ran for to gawren vpon þis man
That astonyed lay both pale and wan
For with that fall to broste is his Arme .
But stonden he moste vnto his owne harme
For whan he spake he was anon borne doune
Wᵗith hende Nicholas and feire Alisou .
Thei told eủery man ; þat he was wode
He was so agast . of þat nowels flode
Thorugh fantasie ; that of his vanyte .
He had so bought kneding tubbes thre .
And had ehongid hem hy in the Roof
And how he preid him for goddis love
To sitten in the Roof par companye .
The folkes gan laughen At his fantasye .
And to the Roof þei keyken ⁊and þei gape
And turned all his harme vnto iape
For what so euer this Carpenter answerd
Hit was for nought / noman his resou herd
With othes grete he was so borne adoun
That he was holden wode thurgh the toun
For eủery Clerk anon thei held wᵗith othir
Thei seid the man is wode hit is non oþ̉er
And eủery man gan laughen at þis stryf .
Thus ʆserued was the Carpenters wif
For all his keping / and his Ielousie
And Absolou had kist her nethir eye
And Nicholas is brent sore in to þe toute
This tale is don . god saue all this rowte
¶ And thus here endith · the mylners tale ·

And next folowyng now begynneth the
Prolog of the Reves Tale ·
Whan folkes had laughen̄ at þⁱˢ nyce cas
Of Absolon ⁊and of hende Nicholas
Diuers folkes diủersly thei seid
But for the more part thei lough and pleid
Ne at this tale I saw noman̄ him greve
But hit were oonly · now Osewold þe Reve
Because he was of Carpenters crafte
A litell yre is · in his hert ylafte
He gan to grucche · ⁊and blamed hit alite
Sothly quod he · ful wele coude I þe quyte
With þe blering of a proude mylners eye
If þat me list to speke of ribaudrye
But I am old me lyst not pley for age
Grasse tyme is don̄ my foder is for age
This white toppe writeth my eld yeres
Men may wele seen̄ by my old heres
freyte cleped medil · But if I fare as doth a openarsse
That ilke fruyt is euer leng̉er þe wers
Til hit be roten̄ in mullok or in stre
¶ We old men now I drede so fare we
Til we roten̄ / can̄ not we be ripe
Who hoppen̄ alwey whiles þe world wol pipe
For in oure will ther͗e stikkith eủer a naile
To haue an hore hede and a grene taile
As hath a leek · for though oure myght be gone
Oure wille desireth foly euer in oone
For whan we may not doon̄ þan̄ wol we speke
Yit in oure asshen̄ old · is fyre ereke
¶ Foure gleedes haue we  whiche I shal devise
Avauntyng lyyng angre ⁊and coueitise
Thes foure sparkils longith vnto eld
Oure old lymes / wel yvell we may byweld
But will ne shall not failen̄ þᵗat is soth
For yette have I all weyes a coltꝭes toþe
Als mony yeeres as it is passid henne
¶ i lochasis Sith that my tappe of lyfe be ganne to rynne
For sykurly whanne I was borne a noone
Deth droughe þe tappe of lyf ⁊and lette hit goone
And euer sith haþᵉ so þe tappe ronne
Til þat wel nyghe al empty is þᵉ tonne
Þe streme of lyff / nowe droppithe on̄ þᵉ chymbe
Þe cely tonge may weele ring and chymbe
Of wrecchednesse þat passid is ful yeore
e ⁊et credatꝭis Wᵗith old folkꝭes sauve dottage nys namore
Whan þᵗat oure hooste had herde þis sermonyng
He ganne to speke · als lordly as a kyng
What mounteþe he saide · al þis grete wytte
What shalle we speke · alday of holy wrytte
Þe devele made a Reve here for to preche
Or of a Sowter a Shipman or a leche
Seye forþe þⁱ tale ⁊and tary not þe tyme
Lo here depford / it drawithe half weyes pryme
See Grenwich here where many a shrew is Inne
Hit were hy tyme / þy tale a noon by gynne
¶ Now sirs quod this Oswald þe Reve
I pray yow all / þat nowte yow greve
Þoughe I aunswere / and somedele sette his howse
For leefful it is wᵗith force force over shove
Þis dronkyn̄ mylnere / haþe etold vs here
How þat begylid was a Carpentier͗e
Paraventure in skorne for I am oon
And by yowre leve I shalle hym̄ qvite a noon
Right in hees cheorlishe termis so wol I speke
I Pray to god his necke mot sone to breke
He cane wele in myn̄e eye fynde a stalke
eccl̄esia suis sui But in his owne he cannot fynde a balke
Þus Eondiþᵉ here þe Prologe / of þe Revis tale and ·
Nowe begynnythe here nexte þe Revis tale
AT Thorpyngtoıı̄un not fer from Caumb—
Þer gooþe a brooke ⁊and ouer þᵗat a brugge
Vppon the wiche broke þer standithe now a mylle
And þis is werray sooþe þᵗat I yow telle
A myller was þer dwellyng many a day
As any pecok he was proude ⁊and gaye
Pypin he couþe / and nettes beete
And towrne cuppis he cowþe wele wrastel ⁊and sheete
And by his belt he bare a long /panade
For of a swerde ful trenchaunte was þᵉ blade
A Iolye poppere bare he in his powche
Þer was noman for parayle dourste him towche
A shefeld thwytle bare he in his hose
Rounde was his face ⁊and camused was his noose
Als pilled as any ape was his skulle
He was a markeþe bett̉er at þe fulle
Þer nas no wight þat dovrste hande on̄ him legge
For yf þer did he swore / he showlde a bygge
A theeffe he was For sooþe / of corne ⁊and mele
And þᵗat he sleghe and vsand for to steele
His name was deynouse ⁊and ful provde symkyn̄
A wyf hadde commen of noble kyn̄
Þe swonne herde of þe towne hir fadre was
With hir he gave booþe yron̄ ⁊and brasse
For Symkyn̄ shoulde in his blode alye
She was efosterde wel in a dayrye
For Symkyn̄ wolde / no wyf as he sayde
But shee were wel enorished ⁊and a mayde
To saven his estate of yomanrye
And shee was provde / and pert as is a pye
And ful fayre seyght it was vppon̄ hem two
On̄ halydayes by forne her wold he goo
Wᵗith his typpette / ewounde a bowte his hede
And shee cam afftre in a Guyde of Rede

div.l: Was noon so hardye þat went by þᵉ way
Þat wᵗith hir durste Rage / or ones pleye
But yf he wolle be slayne of prowde Symkyn̄
Wᵗith panade or wᵗith kneyf or wᵗith bottekyn̄
For Ialowse folke been paraylowse euer moo
Algate þei wolden þᵗat theyre wyffes wende soo
And eke for shee was somdele smotterlyche
She was als digne as wat̉er in a diche
Als ful of hokoure / lyke to a bysmare
Hir þowght þat alady shovlde hir spare
What for hir kynrede / and hir norterye
Þat she was tavght sōmme sōmme in a nonnerye
¶ A dowghter hadden they by twene hem two
div.note: ¶ þe descryvingᵉ of þᵉ Mylners dowter
div.l: Of twenty yeere of age / wᵗith owten moo
Saving a chyld þᵗat was / but half yeere of ag
In cradle it laye · lyche a propre page
Þis wenche welle egrowe and thykke shee was
With Camuse noose and eyen grey as glasse
Buttokkes right broode and brestes rownde an̄ hye
And Ryght fayre here had shee / I kepe not lye
Eke for hir͗e fadre / thowte þat shee was fayre
Her Her He was in purpos / to make her his eyre
Booþe of cattayle ⁊and of his messuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
¶ His Entente was to bee stowe hir hye
In to some worþye bloode of Auncestrye
For wel egoton goode / most beon despendid
In worthi bloode wher it is descendid
Þer fore he wole his oune bloode honour͗e
Þoughe þᵗat men þer of speke / harome ⁊and loure
¶ Gret sooken hathe this Milner / owte of dowte
Withe whete ⁊and malte / of alle þᵉ sheyre abovte
And namly of a fayre a grete collage
Þat men clepe þe soler halle at Chaumberyng
Þer was þeyre whete / and eke hir malte egrounde
Vppon̄ a day hit happid soo in a stounde
Seke lay þᵉ mauncyple / on̄ a maladye
Men demen wisselye þᵗat he shovlde dye
For soþe this myln̉er stale boþᵉ meele ⁊and corne
An hunderithe tymis more þan̄ he did byfore
For here before he stale but curteyselye
But nowe he was a theff owtrageowselye
For wiche þe wardeyne · chidde ⁊and made fare
But ther by sette þis Milner nowght a tare
He craked booste / and swoore it nas not soo
Þenne were þer yong poure scolers twoo
Þat dwellid in that halle / of wiche I saye
Testyff þey wer͗e / and lousty For to playe
And oonly For þeir͗e myrthe and Reuelrye
Vppon̄ þeyre warden · ryght beselye they crye
¶ Nowe geve vs leve sir but a litill stounde
To goo to ther ther the mylne and see oure corne egrounde
And hardelye þey dourste ley wedde þeyr͗e necke
Þe Miln̉er should not stele hem halfe a pekke
Of corne ne by force no sleyght hem be reve
So atte þe laste þe wardeyne gaff hem leve
Iohon hight þᵗat oon / and Aleyne hyght þᵗat oþ̉er
Of a towne were they borne / þᵗat hyght þᵉ strooþer
Far in þe northe I can not tellyn̄ where
Þis Aleyne makethe al Redy his gere
Vppon̄ an̄ horse þe sacke he caste a noon
For þe gooþe Aleyne þe clerke / and eke Iohan
Wᵗith good swerde / and bockeler by theyre syde
Johanne knew þe waye him neodithe lesse a guyde
¶ And atte þe millene / þe sacke a downe he leyþe
Aleyne spake Firste / al haylle Symkyn̄ in feythe
How faren they they yowr͗e dovter ⁊and yowr͗e wyff
Aleyne wel com qduod symkyn by my lyffe
And Iohan alsoo howe nowe / what doo ye her͗e
By god quod Iohan to symkyn̄ / nede naþᵉ noo per͗e
Hym by hovethe serve himselff þᵗat naþe noo swayne
Or ellꝭes he is a foole as clerkis sayn̄
Oure mancyple I hope þᵗat he wolle bee dede
Swa werkꝭes ay þe wanges in his hede
And þer fore am I cōmmen / eke ⁊and Aleyne
To grynde oure corne / and carye hit home A gayne
Spede vs I pray yowe / als soone as yee may
Hit shall bee doon quod Symkyn̄ by þⁱˢ day
¶ What wolle ye doon / whyles corne is in hande
By god by þᵉ hoꝑper ryght þᵉʳ welle I stonde
Quod Iohan to see / howe þᵉ corn ganges Inne
Yette sawe I never be my fader kynne
Howe þᵉ hopper wagges til ⁊and fra
Alayne answerid ⁊and answerid ⁊and saide Iohan wilttowe swa
Þanne wolle I byde be nethe her͗e wᵗith my corne
To see howe þe meele is in Eborne
In til þe trowhe þat shalle bee my disporte
Quod Iohan In feythe / I may bee of yowre sorte
I am als euil a myller as er yee
¶ Þis mylner smeylid of theyre neycetee
And thowte al nys not / but for a wyle
Þey wene no man can hem booþe be gyle
But by my thryffte yette shalle I bler͗e þeir͗e eye
For alle theyre sleythe / in their philosophie
Þe moore qveynte crookꝭes þat þey make
Þe more corne wolle I stele / whan þᵗat I take
¶ In stede of flour͗e þey shull have all wey branne
The gretteste clerke is nowte wiseste man
As whilom the wolphe / speke on to þᵉ mare
Off al theyr͗e arte counte I nowght a tare
Oute of þe dorre he gooþe ful pryuelye
When þᵗat he sawe his tyme / and sofftylye
He lokeþe vppe and downe / til he hath founde
Þe Clerkꝭes hors / þer as he stood ebounde
Be hynde þe mylne / vnder a leeffcyle
And to þᵉ horse he gooþe hym fayre ⁊and wele
He strypethe of þe brydell Ryght a noon
So whanne þe horse was loose / he gynneþe to gon
To ward þe mareyse where wylde marys ranne
Wᵗith we hee trout thorowhe thykke ⁊and thynne
¶ The mylner gooþe a gayne / no word he saide
But doþe his note and wᵗith þe clerkꝭes playde
Til þat theyre corne / was feyre ⁊and wel egrounde
And whan þe mele is sacked and ebounde
Þis Iohan gooþe owte ⁊and fyndeþᵉ þᵉ horse aweye
¶ And ganne ganne to crye harowe ⁊and welawey
div.note: "Mon [heart symbol] est vostre du tout" written vertically in left margin, apparently after trimming; not the main scribe.
div.l: Oure hors is loste / Aleyne For goddes banes
Steppe on̄ thi feete / come of man al at anes
Ellas oure wardeyne / haþe his palfrey lorn
Þis Aleyne al forgate boþe mele ⁊and corne
Al was oute of mynde his husbandrye
What whilke way is he goon / he gan to crye
Þe wyff come lepyng owtwardes at a rynne
Sho saide lo yondir he gooþᵉ in to þᵉ fenne
Wᵗith wyld maris / als faste as he may goo
Vnthanke come on̄ his hande þat bond him soo
And he that better should a knytte the Reyne
Ellas quod Iohan to Aleyne for crystes peyne
Laye downe thy swerde / and I wolle myn̄ alswa
I is als wyght god wat as is a Ra
Be goddys hert he shalle not scape vs baþᵉ
Whye naddest thow putte þe caple in þᵉ laþe
Yl hayle Aleyne / by god þowe is a Fonne
Þees two clerkes haue ful faste eronne
To wardes þe fennes / boþe Aleyne ⁊and eke Iohan
And whanne þe Myln̉er sawe þᵗat þey were goon
He halff a boschell of theyre floure hathe take
And bad his wyf goo knede hit in a cake
He saide I trowe þᵉ clerkis were a ferde
Yette can a myln̉er make booþe þeyr͗e berde
For al hir arte lete hem goo thir weye
Loo wher they Rynne / yee lette þᵉ chylder pleye
They gete him not so lyghtly be my crowne
Þees wery clerkes chasen vp ⁊and downe
With · keepe kepe whoo standetowe Iostey warder̉ere
Ga wyghtly þow ⁊and I shall kepe him̄ here
But shortly til þat it was verreye nyght
Þey kouþᵉ not for al boþee hir myght
Þe caple cacche he ran a wey sofaste
Til In a diche they caute hym̄ at þᵉ laste
¶ Wery ⁊and wete · as beste is in þe Rayne
Comyþe Iohan þe clerke ⁊and wᵗith him comythe Alayne
Ellas quod Iohan þe day þᵗat I was borne
Nowe ar we drevyin̄ to heþing ⁊and to scorne
Oure corne is stolne men wolle vs fals calle
Booþe þe wardeyne ⁊and oure felawes alle
And namelye þe myln̉er for shame wellawaye
Þus pleyneþe Iohan as he gooþe by þe waye

Aleyne leggeth
a nyghtÞe mylner by þe fuyre syttyng they fonde
Whan they cam ther wᵗith bayard in theyre hande
For hit was nyght ⁊and Fyrþ̉er myght they notte
But for þe love of god / þey him be sowght
Of harbarowe ⁊and of ease as for þeyre peny
Þe Mylner answerde hem yf þer be eny
Suche as it is yee shoule wele have yoᵘur yoᵘur parte
Myn̄ howse is streyte / but yee have lernid arte
Þat cōnne by argument make a large place
A myle brode in twenty Fete of space
¶ Lete see nowe yf þis place may suffice
Or makeþᵉ hit rowme wᵗith speche as is yowre guyse
Nowe symond said this Iohan by saint cutberd
Ay is thowe towe thowe mury and þat is fayre answerd
I have herde seye þᵗat men should of two thyngꝭes
Take suche as he fynt or suche as he bryngꝭes
But speciallye I pray þee hooste dere
Gete vs sum mete or drynke ⁊and make vs chiere
For we wolle pay trewlye here at þᵉ fulle
Wᵗith empty hand men may noon haukes tulle
Loo here owre silủer redy for to spende

rdg.seg: + We prey yᵉ hertly to þᵉ ton send

app.rdg: We prey yᵉ hertly to þᵉ ton send

l.note: "+" used to place the omitted line.

div.l: For ale ⁊and bred and Rosted hem a goos
And teyed thayre hors he shoulde nomore goo louse
¶ And in his owne chambre · made hem a bedde
Wᵗith sheetꝭes · and wᵗith chalouns feyre espredde
Nowte from his bedde but ten foote or twelve
His dowter hadde a bedde al by her͗e selve
Right in þᵉ same chaumbre by and by
Hit myght bee no bette and cause loo whye
Þer was no no Rommer harbarowe in þᵗat place
