¶ Þey souped ⁊and speken hem to solace
And dronk ay a monge stronge ale at þᵉ beste
Abowtes mydnyght wenten þey to Reste
Welle hathe þis milner vernyshid his pillid hede
Ful pale he was for dronke ⁊and not Rede
He youghxseþe / and spekithe þorowe þᵉ noose
As he were on̄ þᵉ qwacke or on̄ the poose
¶ To bedde he gooþe / and wᵗith him gooþᵉ his wyf
As any Iaye she lyght was ⁊and Iolyff
So was her Ioly whistel wel I wette
Þe cradell at his beddis fete was sette
To rocken and eke to gyve þe chylde sowke
And whan þat dronken donken dronken was al in þᵉ crowke
To bedde gooþe Alayne to bedde Eke gooþᵉ Iohan
To bedde went þe dowter þanne a noon
¶ Þer nas namore / For hem neodethe no dwale
Þis mylner haþe / so wyselye bibbed ale
Þat as an horsse / he sowreþe in his slepe
Ne of tayleonde he toke þer noo kepe
His wyf bare hym þer wᵗith a bourdowne stronge
Men myght weele here hem rowte a large fourlonge
Þe wenche rowted eke fast / ꝑpar coumpanye
¶ Aleyne þe clerke þᵗat herd þis melodye
He powked Iohan and sayde what slepes þowe
Herdestowe eủer slyke a song or nowe
Loo slyke a coupellyng / is by twene hem alle
A wyld fuyre / motte on̄ hir bodyes be falle
Who hard eủer suche a ferly thyng
Ye they shulle have þe flowr͗e of evil endyng
Þis long nyght / þer tydde me here na reste
But yette na force al shalle be for þᵉ beste
For Iohan saide þanne als haue I reste to nyght
Yf that I may · þe wenche here wolle I dyght
Some easement haþe þe lawe eshapen vs
For Iohan þer is a lawe · þat sayþe þus
Þat if a man in oon poynt been a grevid
Þat in a noþ̉er he shal beo relevid
Oure corne Is stolne sooþely þᵉʳ is noo nay
And we have hadde and eville fitte to daye
And sithen I shalle haue noon amendement
A geynst my losse I moste shape Easement
By goddis sowle it shalle non oth̉er beo
Þis Iohan answerd Aleyne / a vise þow þee
Þe miln̉er is a parelowse man he saide
And if þat he owte of his slepe abrayde
He myght þanne doon vs booþᵉ a vilany
Aleyne answerd I count him̄ nowte a pye
And vp he ryste ⁊and by þe wenche he crepte
Þis mayde laye vp Righte and faste eslepte
Til he so neyghe was / er sheo myght a spye
Þat hit had beo to late for to crye
But shortly for to sey / þey were at on̄
¶ Nowe pley Aleyne for I wolle speke of Iohn
Þis Iohan lyþe stylle a Furlong wey or two
And to him selfe / he makithe rowthe ⁊and woo
Ellas quod he þis is a wikked Iape
Nowe may I sayne / þat I is but an̄ ape
Yette hathe my Felawe somwhat For his harme
He hathe þe myllers dowt̉er in his arme
He aunterid him ⁊and hathe his his nedes spedde
And I lye as a draff sacke in my bedde
For whanne þis Iape · is told a noþir day
I shalle be holden a daffed nyse cokeney
I wolle aryse ⁊and aventure it by my feythe
Vnhardy vncelye loo þus men saithe
And vppe he Rosse ⁊and sofftlye forthe he went
Vn to the cradle / and in̄ his arms hit hent
And bare hit soffte vn̄ to his beddes Fete
¶ Soone afftir this the wyf her rowtyng leete
And ganne a wake and went her for to pisse
And came a geyne ⁊and ganne hir cradle for to misse
And gropid here ⁊and þer / but sheo fonde noon
Ellas quod sheo I hadde almoste mys I gon̄
Þus myght I have goon on̄ to þᵉ clerkes bedde
Eye benedicitee þanne hadde I fayre spedde
And Forthe sheo gooþe til sheo þᵉ cradle Fonde
Sheo gropeþe alweyes Further wᵗith hir honde
And Fond þᵉ bedde ⁊and demid noo thyng but good
By cause þᵗat þe cradle by his bedde stoode
And nyste wher sheo was for it was derke
But fayre ⁊and welle sheo crepte hir downe by þᵉ clerke
And lyeþe hir stille ⁊and wold have kavte a sleepe
Wᵗith Inne a whyle þis Iohan þᵉ clerke vppe lepe
And on̄ this good wyf he layþe on̄ soore
So mury a Fytte ne hadde sheo ful yeore
He prykeþᵉ harde and depe as he were madde
Þis Iolye lyffe have þes two clerkes hadde
Til that þe þrede Cook by gan to crowe
Aleyne wexsse wery by þat tyme I trowe
For he hadde swonken al þe long nyght
And saide fare wele Malyn̄ my swete wyght
Þe day Is commyn̄ I dare no leng̉er byde
But eủermore wher so I goo or Ryde
I am þin oune clerke so have I zele
Nowe dere lemman quod he goo fare wele
But or þowe goo / oon thyng I wolle þe telle
Whan þᵗat þowe weondeste homeward by þᵉ mille
Ryght at þᵉ Entree / of þe door͗e be hynde
Þowe shalt a Cake of half a busshell Fynd
Þᵗat was Emade nowe of þyne oune mele
Wiche þᵗat I helpe my Fadre For to stele
And goode lemman god þᵉ save ⁊and kepe
And withe þᵗat worde almoste sheo gan to wepe
¶ Aleyne vpperyste / and thoughte er þᵗat I dawe
I wolle goo creepen Inne be my felawe
And fonde þᵉ cradel wᵗith his hande a noon
By godde quod he al wrang have I mysgon̄
Myn̄ hede is toty of myn̄ swynke to nyght
Þat makeþᵉ me þᵗat I goo not aryght
I wate hit wele / þat I have al mys ga
He lyeþe þe miller ⁊and his wyf alswa
And foorþe he gooþe in twenty devilwaye
Vno Vno Vn to the bedde þer as þe mylward laye
He wende have cropen downe by his felawe Iohn
And by þe myller þer he crepte a noon
And kaute him by þe necke and soffte he spake
He sayde howe þowe swyneshed awake
For crystes sowle and here a noble game
For by that lorde þᵗat callid is saynt Iame
As I have thryes in þis short nyght
Pleyed wᵗith þe mylners dowter bolt vp ryght
Wheyleste þow haste as a coward ben a gaste
Ye fals harlot quod þoo þoo þᵉ Milleward haste
A fals traytoᵘur ⁊and false cheorle quod he
Þow shalt beo dede be goddes dygnite
Whoo dovrste beo so bold to desparage
My dowter þᵗat is com of suche linage
And by þᵉ throte bolle he kavte Aleyne
And he hente him dispitowselye agayne
On nose and mowþᵉ he smote him wᵗith his fiste
Downe Ranne þᵉ blood vppon̄ his naked breste
And Inne þe floor͗e wᵗith nose ⁊and mowthe to broke
Þey walowen booþe as pigges don in a poke
And vppe they sterte and downe a gayne a noon
Til þᵗat þᵉ myln̉er spurnid at a stoone
And downe he felle backewardes vppon̄ his wyf
Þᵗat wist noo thyng of al þⁱˢ nyse stryffe
For sheo was falle on̄ slepe a litille wyght
Withe Iohan þᵉ Clerke þᵗat waked al þᵗat nygh
And wᵗith þe Falle owte of her slepe sheo brayede
Helpe holy crosse of bromeholme sheo sayde
In manus tuas lord to þee I calle
A wake symonde þe Goblynne is on̄ me falle
Myn̄ hert is broste nowe helpe I name but dede
Þer lyeþᵉ vppon my wombe ⁊and eke on̄ my hede
Helpe symkyn̄ for þᵉ fals clerkꝭes nowe Fyght
Þis Iohan sterte vp als faste as eủer he myght
And grasped by þᵉ walles too ⁊and froo
To fynde a staffe and sheo sterte vp alsoo
And knewe þe esteres bette þan did þⁱˢ Iohan
And by þᵉ walle a staffe sheo fonde a noon
And sawe a luytel shymeryng of a lyght
By þe moone þat at an hole shone bryght
Soo by þat lyght sheo sawe hem booþe twoo
But sikurlye sheo nyste whoo was whoo
And as sheo sawe a weyght thyng be her eye
Ful wel sheo kouþe þe wyght marke and espye
She wend þe clerke had werid a volupier
And wᵗith þᵉ staffe / sheo drowhe hir nere ⁊and nere
Sheo wend have hitte þis Aleyne atte Fulle
And smoote hir husbonde on on þe milward pilled skulle
Þᵗat downe he gooþe and cryeþe harrowe I deye
Þes clerkes beete him wele and lete him lye
And greyþed hem / and tooke hir horse a noone
Hir sacke wᵗith meele / and on hir wey þey goon
Yitte at þe mylne dore / þey tooke þeyre cake
Of halue a busshel flowre wele ebake
Þus is þe proude milner welle ebeete
And haþe eloste þe moultre of þe whete
And paid for þe souper euery dele
Of Aleyne ⁊and of Iohan þᵗat beete hime wele
His wyf edyght and his dowter als
Lo suche it is a Myller to be fals
And þer fore þis proverbe is saide for soþe
Him thare not weene weele þᵗat yuel dooþe
A gylowr͗e shalle him selff begylid beo
And god that sittithe on̄ heght in magestee
Save alle þis companye her gret ⁊and smale
Þus have I qwite þe milner his tale
ÞE cooke of london whiles þe Reve spake
For Ioye he thought / he clowed him on̄ þᵉ backe
A ha quod he for crystes passioune
Þis miller hathe a sharpe conclusioıı̄un
Vppon̄ his argument of herbagage
Ful wel saide salamon in his langage
Ne bryng nowte euerye man in to thyn̄ howse
For herberowyng by nyght is paraillous
Wele aught a man avised for to beo
Whome þᵗat he bryngeþᵉ vn to his previtee
I pray to god so me me gyve sorowe and care
Iff eủer sithe I hight hogge of ware
Ne herd I miller bett̉er sette a warkewakewarke
He had a Iape of malice in þᵉ derke
And þer fore yf þᵗat ye wouchesaff to here
But god forbeede þat we stinten þere
A tale of me þᵗat am a poure man
I wolle yow telle / als wele as eủer I canne;
A litell Iape þᵗat felle in oure citee
¶ Oure hoste saide sir I graunte hit þee
Nowe telle on Rogger / looke þᵗat it be goode
For many a pasteye hastowe leten bloode
And many a Iacke of Douorre hastowe sold
Þat haþᵉ beon twyes hoote ⁊and thrys colde
Of many a pylgrym̄ hastowe cristꝭes curse
For of þⁱ pasteyes yette þey fare þᵉ worse
Whanne þey have bought of þee þe stoble goose
For in þi shoppe Flyeþe many a flye ful lowse
Nowe telle on̄ gentil hoggekyn̄ by þy name
Butte yette I pray þee / beo not wroþe for game
Þou sayste ful sooþe / Roggere be my faye
A man may seye ful sooþe in game ⁊and pleye
But sooþe playe qwade is þe flemmyng seyþe
And þer fore henry Rayly by þy feythe
Þaughe þᵗat my tale beo of an hostelier
Ne beo not wroþe
and tolde as ye may here
A Prentis whilome dwellid in oure Citee
And of a craffte of victaleris was he
Gaylard he was / as goldfynche in a shawe
Browne as bury / a propre short felowe
Wᵗith lokkes blake kembed ful fetyselye
Dauncen he kouþe right wel ⁊and Iolelye
For he was clepid perkyn Reueloure
He was als ful of love ⁊and ꝑparamoure
As Is þe hyve ful of honye swete
Weele was þe wenche þᵗat wᵗith him myght mete
Atte eủerye brydale wold he syng ⁊and hoppe
He loved bette þe taverne þanne þe shoppe
For when þer ony Ryding was in chepe
Owte of þe shoppe / þiþer wold he lepe
Til þat he had al þe syght eseyne
And Gavred enoughe he nold not com a gayne
And Gaderid him / a meymee of his soort
To hoppe ⁊and singe ⁊and to make disporte
For þanne they seitten stevene / where to mete
To pleyn̄ atte þe dees in suche a streete
For in þe toune nas þer noo prentyse
Þat fayerer kouþe handle a peyre of dyse
Þanne Perkynne kowþe and þer to he was Free
Of his despenses in place of previtee
Þat fonde his mastre well in his chaffare
For offten tymes he fonde his box ful bare
For sekurlye a prentys / a Reueloure
Þat haunteþe dyeses ryot or paramoure
His maistre shalle it in his shoppe abye
Al have he noo part of þe mynstralcye
For theof ⁊and Riote / þey ben convertible
Þowhe he con̄ pleye / on geterne or Rubibl
Reuell and trouþe as Inne a lowe degree
Þey beon ful wroþᵉ / al day as men may see
Þis Ioly prentyse wᵗith his mastre a boode
Til he were nyhe owte of his prentyse hode
Al were he snybbed booþe Eorly ⁊and late
And som tyme ledde wᵗith reuell to Newgate
But at þe laste his maistre him be þyovte yovte þovte
Vppon a daye whanne he his papre sowght
Vppon a proverbe þᵗat seyeþe þᵉ same worde
Wel better is a Roton appul owte of horde
Þanne þᵗat hit Roote al þe Remnaunt
So farithe it / by a Ryotous sarvaunt
Hit is wele lesse harome / to lete passe
Þanne he sheond alle þe sarvauntes in þe place
Þer fore his maistre / gaff him anaqvitaunce
And bad him goo wᵗith sorowe ⁊and mischaunce
And þus þis Iolye / apprentyse hadde his leve
Nowe lette hym Reuell al þᵉ nyght or leve
And for þ̉er is noo theoff wᵗith outen Resseyte
Þat helpithe him to waste and to beyte
Of þᵗat he brybe canne or borowe maye
Anoon he sent his bedde and his arraye
Vn to a Compier of his owne sorte
Þat loued þe deesse / suche Revel ⁊and disporte
And had a wyff þat held for covntenaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for her sustenaunce

¶Off þis tale / chauncier made namore;
¶Nowe this eondith here þe cookestale and nexste

Folowyng begynneþe þe prologe of þᵉ man of
lawes tale ·
(base) Ovre hoost saw wel that the brighte sonne
(base) The ark of his artificial day hath ronne
(base) The ferthe part and half an hour and moore
(base) And thogh he were nat depe ystert in loore
(base) He wiste it was the eightene the day
(base) Of April / that is messager to May
(base) And saw wel / that the shadwe of euery tree
(base) Was as in lengthe / the same quantitee
(base) That was the body erect that caused it
(base) And therfore by the shadwe / he took his wit
(base) That Phebus / which that shoon so cleer and brighte
(base) Degrees was fourty fyue clombe on highte
(base) And for that day / as in that latitude
(base) It was ten at the Clokke he gan conclude
(base) And sodeynly / he plighte his hors aboute
(base) ¶ Lordynges quod he I warne yow al this route
(base) The ferthe party of this day is goon
(base) Now for the loue of god / and of Seint Iohn
(base) Leseth no tyme / as ferforth as ye may
(base) Lordynges the tyme / it wasteth nyght and day
(base) And steleth from vs / what pryuely slepynge
(base) And what thurgh necligence / in oure wakynge
(base) As dooth the streem that turneth neuere agayn
(base) Descendynge fro the montaigne in to playn
(base) Wel kan Senec and many a Philosophre
(base) Biwaillen tyme / moore than gold in cofre
(base) For los of catel may recouered be
(base) But los of tyme shendeth vs quod he
(base) It wol nat come agayn / withouten drede
(base) Namoore / than wol Malkyns maydenhede
(base) Whan she hath lost it / in hir wantownesse
(base) Lat vs nat / mowlen thus in ydelnesse
(base) ¶ Sire man of lawe quod he / so haue ye blys
(base) Tel vs a tale anon / as forward is
(base) Ye been submitted / thurgh youre free assent
(base) To stonden in this cas / at my Iuggement
(base) Aquiteth yow now / of youre biheste
(base) Thanne haue ye doon youre deuoir atte leeste
(base) ¶ Hoost quod he depardieux ich assente
(base) To breken forward / is nat myn entente
(base) Biheste is dette / and I wol holde fayn
(base) Al my biheste / I kan no bettre sayn
(base) Plese yow / and therto wole I do my payne
(base) For swich lawe / as a man yeueth another wight /
(base) He sholde hymself / vsen it by right
(base) Thus wol oure text / but nathelees certein
(base) I kan right now / no thrifty tale seyn
(base) That Chaucer / thogh he kan but lewedly
(base) On metres / and on rymyng craftily
(base) Hath seyd hem / in swich englissh as he kan
(base) Of olde tyme / as knoweth many a man
(base) And if he ne haue nat seyd hem / leeue brother
(base) In o book he hath seyd hem in another
(base) For he hath toold / of louers vp and doun
(base) Mo than Ouide / made of mencioun
(base) In his epistles / that been ful olde
(base) What sholde I tellen hem / syn they been tolde
(base) In yowthe he made / of Ceys and Alcione
(base) And sithen hath he spoke of euerychone
(base) Thise noble wyues / and thise loueres eke
(base) Who so that wole / his large volum seke
(base) Clepyd the Seintes legende of Cupide
(base) Ther maystow seen / the large woundes wyde
(base) Of Lucresse / and of Babilan Tisbee
(base) The swerd of Dido / for the false Enee
(base) The tree of Phillis / for hir Demophon
(base) The pleinte of Dianire / and of Hermyoun
(base) Of Adriane / and of ysiphilee
(base) The barayne Ile / stondynge in the See
(base) The dreynte leandre / for his Erro
(base) The terys of Eleyne / and eke the wo
(base) Of Brixseyde / and of the Ladomea
(base) The crueltee / of the queene Medea
(base) The litel children / hangyng by the hals
(base) For thy Iasoun / that was of loue so fals
(base) O ypermystra / Penolopee / Alceste
(base) Youre wifhod / he comendeth with the beste
(base) But certeinly / no word ne writeth he
(base) Of thilke wikke ensample / of Canacee
(base) That loued / hir owene brother synfull
Off wiche coursed storyes / I say yowe fye
Oþer ellys of / Thuo Appoloneus
Howe þᵗat / þᵉ cursid kyng Anthiochus
By reffte his dowter / of hir maydenhede
wiche is / so orrible a tale to rede
Whanne he her threwe / vppon þᵉ pavement
And þer for / he of ful avicement
Nolde neủer wreyte / in noon of his sermonis
Of suche / vnkynde abhominacionns
Ne I wolle noon reherce / yf þᵗat I may
But of my tale / howe shalle I doone þⁱˢ day
Me were ryght looþe / bee likenid her̉er dowtles
Til a Muse / is clepid þe Peridesse
Metamorphosees / wot what I meene
But naþeleesse / I recche it noute a bene
Þaugh I come afftir him / with have wee baake
I speke in proose / and lete him Rimes make
Ryght wᵗith þᵗat worde / I with a sobre cheere
By ganne my tale / as ye shull afftir heer̉e
Þus Eondithe þe prologe of þe man of lawes tale
and here filowyng bigynniþe his tale
O hatefull harme/ conducon of pouert
wᵗith thruste wᵗith colde / wᵗith hunger so confounded
To asken helpe þee shameþe in þin hert
yf þowe noon axse / with neede þowe art so wounded
Þy verraye neede vnwrappethe all þⁱ woundes hid
And Maugree þyne hed ye moste for Indygence
Or begge or stele or borowe his dispence
¶ Þow blameste Criste ⁊and saiste ful bitturlye
He misse departiþe richchesse temporalle
Þey neyghibourgh þow wyteste ay synfullye
Þowe saiste þowe haste luyte and he hathe al
Parffay saystowe /some tyme he reken shalle
Whanne þᵗat his tayle shalle brennen in þᵉ gleede
For he nowte helpiþe þe needefulle in his neede
¶ Herken what/ is þᵉ sentence of þe wyse
Bette is to dien þanne have Indygence
Þyne owne neygheboure wolle þee despise
If þowe bee poure fare wel þⁱ reuerese

l.note: Yet of the wise man take þᵘ þⁱˢ sentenc
Alle the dayesof pour men be wik
Be war therfore er thow come to þe pryk
If thou be pouere thybroþ̉erhatith thee

div.l: And alle freendes flee frome þee ellas
O riche Marchaundes ful of weele bee yee
O noble prudente folke as in þis cas
Youre bagges been not filled wᵗith ambes as
But wᵗith sys cynke þat rynnith on yoʳ chaunce
At Crystenmasse Ful muryly may yee daunce
¶ Ye sechen lande and see for yoʳ wynnynges
As wyse folkes yee knowen alle þᵉ estate
In regnes yee been faders of tidynges
And tales booþe of pees and of debate
I were right nowgh of my tale deslate
Nere a Marchaunde goon is many a yeere
Me tolde a tale / wiche ye shulle afftir here

Þus Eondithe þe prologe and þe begynnyng
of þe tale
In Surry whilom/ þer dwellid a compagnye
Of merchaundes wyse þe wiche were sadde ⁊and trewe
Þat weyde where wenten/ wᵗith þeyre Spicerye
wᵗith clooþes of gold wᵗith Satynes riche of hewe
Þeyre chafare was / so thryfty ⁊and so newe
Þat every weyght hath deyntee to þeyre chafare
And wᵗith payne deele / and sellen hem þeyre ware
¶ Nowe fel it þat þe maystres of þᵗat sorte
Have shapen hem to Roome for to wende
Were it for chapmanhode or for disporte
Noon oþ̉er message / nolde þey þeder sende
But came him selfe to Roome þis is the eende
And in suche place/ as thought hem avauntage
For hir entente / þey tooke here herbergage
Soiourned have/ þees Marchaundes in þᵗat toune
A certeyne tyme as fel to her playsaunce
But soo by felle þe excellente renowne
Of þe Emperoures douter Fayre Coustaunce
Reported was with eủery circumstaunce
To þees Surreyne Marchaundes in suche wyse
Frome day to day as I shalle yow deuise
¶ þis was þe comune voyce of eủery man
Oure Emperowre of Roome/ so god him see
A dought̉er haþᵉ þᵗat sithe þe worlde by ganne
To reken als wele / hir goodnes as beaute
was neủer suche a noþ̉er as is shee
I pray to god in honoure hir susteene
And wold shee were of al Europe þᵉ qweene
¶ In hir is hyee honoure wᵗithoute pruyde
Trouþe with outen grieff or ellꝭes folye
Til alle hir werkes vertue is hir guyde
Humblesse haþe slayne in hir all thyrannye
She is myrrowre/ of al curtasye
Hir hert is werraye chaumbre of alle holynesse
Hir handes Mynistre / of gret almesse
¶ And al þeyre voyce was sooþᵉ as god is trewe
But nowe to purpose lete vs tourne a gayne
Þees Marchaundes have doon fraute hir shippis newe
And whanne þey have þis blissefulle mayden seyne
hoome to Surrye been þey retourned agayne
And doon þeyre needes as þey have doon yoore
And lyuen in wele I can sey yowe namore
¶ Nowe fil it þat þees Marchaundes stoode in grace
Of him was þe Sondan of Surrye
For whanne þey come from anye straunge place
He would of his benygne gret courtesye
Make hem goode cheere/ and besylye aspye
Tyþinges of sunderye / regnes ay for to here
And oþer wonderis þei myght see ⁊and here
¶ A mong al oþ̉er thynges speciallye
þees marchaundes hane him told of fayre coustaunce
So greet noblesse in ereneste al ceryouslye
Þat þis Sondan haþe kaught so gret playsaunce
To have hir figure on his rememberaunce
And al his luste and al his besy cure
Was to love hir whiles þᵗat his lyf maye dur
¶Par aventure in þilke large booke
Wiche þat I clepe/ þe hevene ewryten was
wᵗith þe sterres whan þᵗat he his broþ̉er tooke
þat he for love should have his deþe ellas
For in þe sterres clerer þanne is þe glasse
Is wreten god it woote whoo kouþe it rede
þe deþe of eủery man wᵗithouten drede
¶ In þe sterris many a wynter be foree
Was wret þe deþe/ of hector + Achilles
Of Pompy Iulius / or þᵗat he was borne
The stryff of thebes and of Ercules
Of Sampson. Tournus ⁊and of Socrates
Þeyre dethes/ but mens wittes been so dolle
Þat noo wyght canne it rede þᵉ at þᵉ Fulle
¶ þis Sawdan/ for his pryve counseyle sent
And shortly frome þis mater for to chace
He hathe til hem declared his Intente
And saide hem certayn/ but he myght have gʳᵃce
To have Coustaunce/ withe Inne a litle space
He nere but dede/ and charged hem in hye
To shapen for his liff some remedye
¶ Diuirse men diuirse thyngꝭes þei seyden
þey argumentꝭes casten vppe ⁊and downe
Many a subtyle rayson þey for hem leyden
þey spake of magyke ⁊and of abusyoune
But fynally for hir conclusioune
Þey canne not seen/ in þat noon avauntage
Ne in noon oþ̉er wey save mariage
¶ Þanne sey they þer Inne /suche defficultee
By way of Raysoune/to speke forþᵉ al playne
By cause þat þer was suche diuersitee
By twene þeyre booþe lawes þᵗat þey sayn
Þey trowe þat cristen prynce wolde so fayne
Wedden his chylde vn to ovre lawes swete
Þat vs hathe taught oure prophyt Makaineete
¶ And he annswerd raþer þanne I shoulde leese
Coustaunce I wolle be con crysten doutelesse
I mot been hirs I may noon oother chese
I pray yewe holde yowre argumentꝭes in pees
Saveþe my lyff and beeþe not reccheles
To gete me hir þᵗat haþe my lyf in cure
For in þᵗatis woo I may not longe endure
¶ What needeþe grette dilatacioune
I seye by tratyse and ambasatrye
And be the Popes mediacioune
And alle chirch and al þᵉ cheualrye
And in destroyng of al Mavmentrye
And to þencresse of cristes lawes dere
Þey been accorded soo as yᵉ shulle here
¶ Howe þᵗat þe Sowdan /and his barownage
And alle his liegees/ shulde encrystened bee
And he shalle have Coustaunce in mariage
And certeyne golde I not what quantite
And þerte fonde they suffisaunt suretee
þis was acorde/ and/ sworne oủer eche a syde
Nowe fayre Coustaunce /almyti god þᵉ guyde
¶ Nowe wolde som men awayten as I gesse
þᵗat I shoulde telle al þe purveyaunce
wᵗith þᵗat þemꝑperoure of / his hie noblesse
Haþe shapen for his dowt̉er feyre Costaunce
Welle may men knowe þᵗat so greet ordenaunce
May noo man telle in a lutel clause
And was arayed for so hye a cause
¶ Busshopes been shapen wᵗith here for to wenden
lordes and ladyes knightes of hye renowne
And oþ̉er folke enowe/ þis is þe eende
And notefyed is /þorowe þe toune
Þat euery wight / with gret deuocyoune
Shoulde praye to crist þᵗat he þis mariage
Resceyve in gree / and spede wel þis viage
¶ þe day is comen of hir departynge
I seye þᵗat hevy day it is nowe comen
þat þer may bee noo lenger tareyng
But forewardes þenne þey dresse hem al ⁊and sume
Coustaunce þᵗat wᵗith sorowe is al oủer comen
Ful pale arisithe and dressith her to weende
For weel shee seeþe þ̉er is noon oþ̉er eende
¶ Ellas what wondere is it þoughe shee weepe
þat shalle bee sent nowe to straunge nacioune
From al hir freendis/ wiche tendirly her kepte
And to bee bounde ondyr subieceyoune
Of oon shee ne knoweþe his condicyoune
Husbandes been goode alle and / have been yore
þat knowen þees wyves weele I say namoore
¶ Fadre shee saide youre wooful chylde Coustaunce
þowre younge dowt̉er offosted vp so soffte
And yee moder my soủerayne plesaunce
A bove alle thyng owtaken Criste on loffte
Coustaunce yowre chyld hir recomaundithe offte
Vn to yowre grace For I shalle to Surrye
Ne shal I never/ see yowe more with yeye
¶ Ellas and vn to Barbre nacioune
I most a noon sithen it is yowre wille
But crist þat straff for oure redempcioun
So yewe me grace hees hestes to fulfille
I wrechched woman noo force þawe I spille
Wymmen been borne /to charledme ⁊and penaunce
And been vndir mannes governaunce
¶ I trowe at Troye / whane Pirrus brake þe wal
Or Ylion which þat brent Theebes citee
Ne Roome for þe harome of hannibal
þat Rommaynis have evenqwisshed tymes thre
Nas herde suche tendre wepyng for pitee
As in þe chaumbre for hir departyng
But foorþe shee motte whethir shee wepe or syng
¶O firste mornyng cruell firmament
Withe þy dyournal / wyche þᵗat crowdest ay
And hurteliste al from eeste til poccydente
which naturallye wold hold a noþ̉er way
Þy crowdyng sette þe heven in suche aray
At þᵉ begynnyng of þis fyers wiage
þat cruell Mars hath slayn this mariage
¶ Infortunate Ascendonte / tortuous
Of which þe lord/ is helplesse falle ellas
Owte of angle / in to his derkeste hous
O Maʳs O Atasire / as in þis cas
Of feeble Moone / vnhappy been þy pas
þowe knetteste þee þer /wher þowe nart resteyvid
þere þowe wast welle/ From þens art þow wyssed
¶ Imprudent Emperowre of Roome/ O loo Ellas
Was þ̉er nOo Philosophre/ noon in al þᵗat towne
Is noo tyme bette þan oþ̉er in suche cas
Of vyage is þer noon elleccyoune
Namelye to folke of hye conducioune
Nought whane þe roote/ is of suche birthe eknowe
Allas we been/ to lewde or ellꝭes to slowe
¶ To shippe is browght þis woo ful fayre mayde
Ful Solempnlye/ withe eủerye circumstanse
Nowe Ihesu criste bee wᵗith yowe al shee saide
þer is namoore/ but fare wel fayre Coustaunce
Shee peynithe hir to make /good countenaunce
And forþe I let hir Sayle in þis manere
And tourne I wolle a gayne/ to my mastre
¶ þe modre of þe Sowdan/ welle of vices
How he wolle lette his olde sacrefices
And right a noon/ shee for hir counsayle sent
þey came Right soone/ to wete what shee mente
þus whanne assembled was þis folk in feer
un to hem alle/ shee sayde as ye shalle heer
¶ Lordes quod shee yee knowen eủerrychoone
Howe þᵗat my son/ in poynt is for to leete
þᵉ hoolye lawes of oure/ Alkernoune
yeff been oure prophetꝭes Marchaundes Makamete
But on avowe to gret god I hete
Þe lyff shal oute of al my body sterte
Or Makometꝭes lawe shal free myn herte
¶ What should vs tyde of þat newe lawe
But thralledome til oure body ⁊and penaunce
And afterwardes in helle to been + drawe
For we renᵉyen Macamete oure creaunce
But lordes welle we here make asuraunce
As I shalle seye/ assentyng to yowre loore
And I shalle make vs savfe for eủermore
¶ Þey sworen/ and assentid euery man
To lyve wᵗith hir and dye ⁊and by hir stonde
And eủeryche in þe best wyse he can
To strnkeþen hir shal doo his frendis fonde
And shee haþe þis empryse here take on honde
Wiche ye shulle here/ as I shalle yowe devise
And to hem alle she spake Right in þⁱˢ wyse
¶ We shoulde firste feynen/ vs cristendome to take
þe colde water shal greve vs but a luytle
And I shalle suche a feste /and revel make
Þat as I trowe I shalle þe sowdan qwyte
For þawhe his wyf bee crystened neuer so white
Shee shal have neede to wasshen a weye þᵉ Rede
Þouhe ful a fonte/ of watre shee wᵗith hir lede
¶ O Soudonasse Roote/ of Iniqvitee
Virago þowe Semaritane secounde
O þowe Serpente/ of Femenytee
lyche to þᵉ serpente/ deepe in helle ebounde
O feyned womman/ al þᵗat may confounde
Vertu ⁊and Innocence /thorowe þⁱ malyce
Ebredde in þee/ as nest of eủerye vice
¶ O Sathan enviouse/ sithe þᵗat Ilke day
Þat þowe were chased frome oure eritage
Weele knowestowe /to whome þe old waye
þowe madeste eve / to bryng vs in servage
þowe wolte for doon þis cristen mariage
þyne Instrument so welawey þᵉ while
Makest towe of womman/ whane þowe wilt man begyle
¶ þis Sowdanis modre / whanne I þis blame and warye
leete priuelye /hir counsayle goon hir waye
What shoulde I in þis tale nowe lenger tarye
She ridethe to þe Soudan uppon a daye
And saide to him she wold/ renay herlay
Repenting hir she hethyn was so longe
And cristindom of prestis handis fonge
¶ Besechyng him/ to doone hir þat honoure
þat shee myght have þe cristen folke to feste
To pleesen hem I wolle do my laboure
þe soudan sayþe I wolle done as yow leste
And knelyng thakithe hir of þat reqveste
So gladde he was he niste nowght what to saye
Shee kyste hir sone and home shee gooþe hir waye
¶ Arryved been/ þees cristen men to londe
In Surrye wᵗith hem/ a ful solempne Rowte
And hastlye þis Soudan sent his sonde
Firste to his modre/ and al þe regne a bowte
And sayde his wyf was commen owte of dowte
And prayethe hi to Ryden agayne þe qwene
þe honoure of his regne for to sustene
¶ Gret was þe prees and Riche was þᵉ arraye
Of Surreynes and Rommayns meete effeere
þe moodre of þe Soudan so Riche and Gaye
Resceyueth þe qween/ withe als a gladde cheere
As any modre myght hir dowter deere
Right to þe nexste citee þere by syde
A esye pas ful solempnely þey Ryde
¶ NOught trowe I þe tryumphe of Iulius
Of wiche þat lucan makeþe suche a boste
Was Ryallour ne no more curyouse
þanne was þeassembee of þⁱˢ blisfulle hoost
But þis scorpion þis foounde þⁱˢ wicked gooste
Þe Soudanis modre for al hir Flateryng
Caste vndir þis ful mortallye to stynge
¶Þe Soudan came him selfe soone afftir þis
So Ralley þat wondre it is to telle
He welcomeþe hir / wᵗith alkynis ioye ⁊and blysse
And þus in mirthe and Ioye I lete hem dwelle
þe fruyt of þis mat̉er nowe wolle I telle
Whanne þᵗat tyme came / men thought hit for þe beste
þat reuelle stynte and men shape hem to reste
¶ Þe tyme came þis old Soudanesse
Ordayned hathe hir feste of wiche I tolde
And to þe feste thees crysten men hem dresse
In general yee boothe þe younge ⁊and olde
Þer men may feeste / and / ryaltee be holde
And deyntees moo þanne I cane nowe devise
But al to deere þey bowte it er þey ryse
¶O sodayne woo þat ever art Successoure
To worldlye blysse espreynte with bitturnesse
Þe eonde of Ioye / of oure worldlye laboure
Wo occupyeth þe fyne of oure gladnesse
Herkyn þis consayle for þi sikurenesse
Vppon þi gladde dayes / have in þi mynde
Þunnware woo þᵗat comeþe ay behynde
¶ For shortly to tellen / at oon worde
Þe Soudan ⁊and þe crysten euerychone
Been al to hewen and stiked at þᵉ borde
But yf it were fayr Constaunce aloone
Þis old soudanesse þᵗat cursid croone
Hathe wᵗith her freendes/ doone þⁱˢ cursid dede
For shee her selfe wolde/ al þe countree lede
¶ Nee þer was Surryen /noon þᵗat was conuerted
Þat of þe counsayle of þe Soudan woot
þat he nas al to hewe/ er he astarted
And Coustaunce have þey taken anon foote hote
And in a Shippe al steerles god hit woote
Þey have hir sette/ and bede here lerne to sayle
Owte of Surrye a gaynewardes to Itayle
¶ A certeyne tresoure þat shee þedir ladde
And sooþe to sayn vytayle grete plentee
þey have hir gyven and clooþes eke shee hadde
And foorþe shee sayled in þe salt see
O my Coustaunce ful of benyngnitee
O Emperoures doughter /soo younge doghter ⁊and deere
He þat is lorde of Fortune bee þy steere
¶ Shee blessithe/ hir and wᵗith fulle pytouse woyce
Vn to þe crosse of cryste þoo þus saide shee
O clere o welfull o þowe holye croys
Rede of þe lambes bloode ful of pitee
Þat wesshe þe word frome þeold Iniquitee
Mee froo þᵉ feende/ and frome hes clawes kepe
Þe daye that I shalle drenche in this deepe
Victoryous tree ꝓproteccyoune of alle trewe
wiche oonly worþi was For to bere
Þe kyng of heven wᵗith hees woundes newe
þe wight lambe /which hurt was /wᵗith a spere
Fleomer of feondes owte of hevyn ⁊and eyrth
On whiche þy lymmes feythefullye extenden
Me kepe and yeue me myght my lyf/ tamenden
¶ Yeeris and dayes fleteþe þis creature
Thorough oute þe see of Grece vnto þe Stroyte
Of Marroke as was þer hir aventure
Of manye an hevy meele maye shee bayte
And Aftir hir dethe/ ful often may shee wayte
Or þat þe wylde waves/ wolde hir dryve
Vn to þe place þer þat shee shalle arryve
¶ Men myght welle asken/ whye shee was not slayn
Eeke at the feste/ who myght hir body save
And I annswere /to þat demaunde agayne
Who saved Danyell/ in þerrible Cave
þer everiche wight but he mastre ⁊and knave
were wᵗith þe lyouns fretten er þey asterte
Noo wight but god þᵗat he bare in his herte
¶ God liste to shewe his wondreful miracle
In hir for shee shulde seen his myghtye werkꝭes
Criste þat is to euery harome treacle
By certeyne meenis/ offte as knowen clerkes
Doþe for ententꝭes dyvers þᵗat derke is
To manys witte/ þᵗat for oure ignoraunce
We canne nowght knowe/ his prudente purveiaunce
¶ Ne sithe shee was not/ at þe feeste eslawe
+ Who kepte Ihonas in þe Fysshes mawe
Til he was spouted vppe at Nunyuee
Wel may men knowe it was noo wyght but hee
That kepte þᵉ peple Ebraike from hir drenchyng
wᵗith druye fete/ thorrowe þe See passyng
¶ Who bad þe foure Spirtes of tempeste
Þat pouer/ haue tannoyen /lande ⁊and See
Boþe northe and Sowthe /and also est ⁊and weste
Annoyen neyþer/ See ne lande ne tree
Sooþely þe comaundoure/ of þᵗat was he
That from þe tempeste ay þis womman kepte
Als wele whanne shee wooke as whanne shee slepte
¶ Where myght þis womman mete ⁊and drynke have
Three yere ⁊and moore howe lastith hir vitaylle
Whoo fedde þe gypsian marye in þe Cave
and in deserte/ noon wight sauf criste saunz fayle
Feyue thousand folke it was as gret maruayle
With looves fyve and Fysshes two to Feede
God send hir foysoun/ ay at hir greete neede
¶ Shee driveþe forþ in to oure occiane
Thorowe owte þe wylde see tille at þe laste
Vnder an holde/ þat nempnen I ne can
For in Northumbrelande þe wawe hir caste
And in þe sande þe shippe stiked so fast
Þat þens nold hit nowte in al a tyde
To wille of Cryste was þat shee shulde abyde
¶ Þe Counstable of þe Castel down is fare
To see this wracke /and al the Ship he soghte
And fonde þis wery womman ful of care
He fonde alsoo þe tresoure þat shee browght
In hir laungage mercy shee him be sowght
þe lyff oute of hir body / for to twynne
Hir to deliuere of wo that she was Inne
¶ A maner latyne corrupte was hir speche
But algates þer by was shee vndirstonde
þe Counstable whanne him liste noo leng̉er seche
þis woofulle womman he browght wᵗith him to londe
Shee kneeled a doune and thanked coistes sonde
But what shee was/ shee wold to noman say
For foule ne fayre þowe þᵗat shee shold dye
¶ She saide shee was so masid in þᵉ See
þat shee for gate hir mynde by hir trowthe
þe Constable hathe of hir greete pitee
And eke his wyf þᵗat þey wepe booþe for rowthe
Shee was so deligent withe owten slowþe
To serve ⁊and please euery wyght in þat place
þat al her loven þᵗat looken on hir face
¶ þe Counstable ⁊and dame hermegylde his wyf
Were paynyines ⁊and þe cuntrey euỷere where
But hermeguylde/ so loved hir as hir lyffe
And Coustaunce haþe so long esorourned þer
In orysounes wᵗith many a bitter teere
Til Ihesus haþe conuertid thurowe his grace
Dame Hermegylde / þe wyf of þat same place
¶ In al þat londe no crysten folke dourste rowte
Al crysten men been fledde from þᵗat cuntree
Thorowhe paynynns wiche conqverid al abowte
þe plages of þe Northe be lande ⁊and be see
To Wales fledde þe Crystianytee
Of old Bretownes dwellyng in þis yle
þer was þeyre Refute/ for þee meene while
¶ But yitte nere crysten bretovnes so exsiled
Þat þer nas some in þeyre preveytee
Þat honord Criste ⁊and heÞen folke bygle
And nyghe þe Castel þere þer dwellid three
Þat oon of hem was blynde ⁊and myght not see
But it were wᵗith thilke eyen of his mynde
wᵗith wiche men seen aftir þᵗat þey been blynde
¶ Bryght was þe Sune as in a Som̉ers daye
For whiche þe Counstable and his wyf alsoo
And Coustaunce hane etaken þe ryght waye
Towardes þe See/ a fourlong weye or twoo
To pleyen and to Romen/ too and froo
Right in þeyre walke þis blynde bretoune þey mette
Croked and old wᵗith eyen faste eshette
¶ In þe name of cryste cried þis bretowne
Dame hermegylde gyve me my syght agayne
þis lady wexsse affrayed of þe soune
leste þat hir husband shortlye for to sayn
wolde hir for Ihu criste love have slayne
Til Coustaunce made hir bolde ⁊and bad hir wirche
þe wille of þis/ as goddes chylde of his chorche
¶ Þe Constable abaysshed was of þe sight
And sayde/ lord what amounteþᵉ al þis fare
Coustaunce aunswered sir it is Cristꝭes myght
Þat helpithe folke owte of þe feendys snaare
And so ferforthe shee ga/ oure lawe declare
þat shee þe Constable /er þat it was eve
Conuerteþe and on Cryste made him byleve
¶ Þis Constable nas noo thyng lord of þᵗat place
Of wiche I speke þer as he Coustaunce fonde
But kepte hit stronglye many a wynt̉er space
Vndir Alla kyng of al Northumberlonde
þat was ful wys/ and worthy of his hande
A geyneste þe Scottes/ as þᵗat men may weele heere
But tovrne I wolle a gayne/ to my matere
¶ Sathan which ever/ awayteþe vs to gyle
Sawe of Coustaunce/ al hir parfeccioune
And caste a noon/ howe he myght qwite hir while
makyng/ a knyght þat dwellid in þat toune
love hir so hoote of foule affeccioune
þat þowte verralye him þᵗat he shoulde spille
But he of hir myght oones soo have his wille
¶ He woveþe her/ but yette avaylleþe hit nowght
Shee nolde consente til synne no be no weye
And for despyte/ he compaste in his þowte
To maken her on shameful dethe to dye
He wayteþe whanne þe constable was aweye
For pryvelye vppon a nyght he crepte
In to hermegyldes chaumbre whiles shee slepte
¶Wery for waked in þeyre orysounis
Slepethe and hermegylde and Constaunce alsoo
þis knyght þer þorowh Sathanas temptaciounes
Al sofftlye is vn to þeyre bedde egoo
And kutte þe throote /of hermegylde a twoo
levying þe blody knyff by dame Coustaunce
And went his wey þere god gyve him mischaunce
¶ Soone afftre comithe þis constable home agayne
And eke Alla þᵗat kyng of þat lande
þat sawe his wyf so dispitouselye slayn
For which Ful ofte he wepte and wrong his hande
And in þe bedde þᵗat blody kneyffe he Fonde
By Dame coustaunce ellas what myght shee saye
For verray woo hir hert was al a waye
¶ To kyng alla was tolde al þis meschaunce
And eke the tyme and where ⁊and In what wyse
þat in a shippe was founden þis Coustaunce
As her byforne yee have harde me devise
þe kynges hert of pitee gamie agryse
Whanne he sawhe so benygn a creature
Falle in disayse and in mysaventure
¶ For as þe lambe towardes his deþᵉ is browt
So stande this Innocente byfore þe kyng
þis fals kneyght that hathe þis traysoun wrought
Beriþe hir on hande þᵗat shee hathe don this thyng
But never þe lesse þer was gret movrineyng
Amonges þe peeple/ and sayn þey canne not gesse
Þat shee hathe doon/ so gret awykednesse
¶For þey have aye seen hir so vertuouse
And lovynge hermegyld Right as hir lyffe
Of þis bare wittenesse everyche in þᵗat howse
Sauf he þᵗat slowhe Hermeguylde wᵗith þᵉ knyffe
Þis gentil kyng hathe kaute a gret motyff
Of þat wyttenesse/ and thowte þᵗat he wold enqvere
Moore depper in this caas a trouthe for leere
¶ Ellas Coustaunce þowe haste noo chaumpioune
Ne fyght canstowe þe while soo weylaweye
But he þat straffe for oure Redempciowne
And bonde Sathan and lyeþe yit þ he laye
So bee þy strong chaumpioune þis day
For but yf cryste open myrakel kyþe
wᵗithowten gylt þowe shalt bee slayne als swithe
¶ Shee sette hir downe on knees ⁊and þus shee sayde
Immortal god þow þat savedest /Sousanne
Frome fals blame/ and þowe mercyful mayde
Marie I meene þe dowter to Saynt Anne
Before whos chylde þat aungeles singe Osanne
yf I bee gyltlesse of þis fellounye
My sokoure bee for /ellys nowe shalle deye
¶ Have yee not sen sum tyme a pale face
A monges þe pres/ of him þᵗat haþe bee ladde
Towardes his deþe where þᵗat hegete noo gras
And suche a coloure in his face haþe hadde
Men myght welle knowe his face þᵗat was bestadde
Amonges al þe facesse in þᵗat rowte
So standeþᵉ Coustaunce/ and lokithe her abowte
¶ O qveenes lyuage/ in prosꝑperitee
yee Duchesses/ and yᵉ ladies/ euerechoone
haue yee sum rowþe on hir adủersitee
An Emperowresse doughter/ stante alloone
She seeþe noo wyght/ to whome/shee canne make moone
O. blode Riall Þat stondiste in þis drede
Fer been þi Feendis at þy gretteste neede
¶ þis Alla kyng hathe suche compassioune
As gentil herte soone fillid of pytee
þᵗat from his yeen Ranne þᵉ wat̉er downe
Nowe hastelye goo fecche a book duod hee
And yf þe kneyght wolle swere howe þᵗat shee
Þat womman slowhe yette wolle we vs avise
Whom þᵗat we wolle shal been our͗e Iustice
¶ A brettoun booke wrettyn withe evangyles
Was Fette a oon þis book and swoore anoon
Shee gyltyff was/⁊and and in þe meene whiles
And hande him smoote/ vppon þe necke boon
Þat downe he felle at oones/ as dooþe a stoone
In syght of eủery bodye in þᵗat presence
A voyce was harde in opyn audience
A voyce was hearde in generall audience
And sayde thowe haste disclaunderid gyltlesse
þe dowter of hoolye chirche in hye p̉ersence
Þus hastowe doone and yette I holde my pees
Of þis marvayle agaste was al þᵉ presse
As mazed folke þey stonden/ eủerych oone
For drede of wreche/ saufe feyre Coustance a loone
¶ Grete was þe drede/ and eke þe Repentaunce
Of hem þat haden wrong suspecyoune
Vppon þis cely Innocente fayre coustaunce
And for þis mirakle in conclusioune
And eke by coustaunces mediacioune
þe kyng and many an /oþer in þat place
Conuertid was/ chauked bee crystes grace
¶ þis fals kneyght was slayen for his vntrouþe
By Iugement of Alla hastelye
And yette coustaunce had of his deþᵉ gret rowthe
And afftir this Ihesus/ of his mercy
Made Alla to wedde þaue solempnely
þis celi mayde so Fayre so bryght and sheene
And þus hathe criste emade/ Coustance þ̉er aqvene
¶ But who was woofulle/ yf þat I shal not lye
Of þis weddyng but donegylde/ right þoo
þe kynges modre/ Al ful of thyrannye
Her semed hir cursid herte brake a twoo
Shee wolde nowght þat hir son hadde soo
Shee thought his gret despite/ þᵗat he should take
So straunge a creature for er make
¶ Me liste not of þe chauffe ne of þe stree
Make so long a tale as of þe corne
What shoulde I telle of Al þe Rialltee
Of þe mariage/ or wiche course gooþe byfore
who bloweþe beste in trompe in pipe or horne
þe fruyte of eủery tale/ is for to seyne
þey ete þey drynke þey sing þey daunce þey pleye
¶ þey goon to bedde/ as it was skylle ⁊and Ryght
For þowe þᵗat wyfes been ful holy thynges
þey moste in pacience at þe night
Suche nessessaryes/ as been to hem plesynges
Of Folkes þat have weddid/ hem with wᵗith ringes
And ley a liutte hir holynesse aside
As for þe tyme it may noon oþ̉er be tyde
¶ On hir he gate a fayr son þ̉er a noone
To a busshop and þe Constable eke
He tooke his wyf to keepe whanne he is goone
To Skot lande wardes hees foomen for to seeke
Nowe fayre Coustaunce þᵗat is so humble ⁊and meke
So longe is goone withe chyld þat shee stille
kepeþe hir chaumbre as it is cristes wille
¶ þe Tyme is comen a feyre sonne shee bere
Mauricius at þe funt stone men him call
Þis Constable dooþᵉ send a messagiers
And wrote vn to þe kyng þᵗat clepid is Alle
howe þᵗat þᵉ bilssefull tydyngis been byfalle
And oþ̉er thyngꝭes spedeful for to sayn
He takeþe þe letter/ and foorþe he gooþ pleyne
¶ Þis messager/ til doone his avauntage
Vn to þis kynges modre Rideþe swythe
And saloweþe hir fayre in his langage
Ma dame quod hee yee may be gladde ⁊and blyþᵉ
And thonkeþe god an/ hundreþe thousand sithe
My ladye qweene haþe chylde wᵗithouten dowte
To Ioye ⁊and blisse/ of al þis Regne a bowte
¶ loo here þe lett̉ers/ enselid of þis thynge
þᵗat I mot bere wᵗith alle þe haste I maye
yive yee wil o ought on to your son þᵉ kynge
I am yowre sarvaunt booþe bee nyght ⁊and bee day
þe kynges moder/ aunswerd/ at now at þⁱˢ tyme naye
But her͗e a luyght/ I wol þow take þⁱ Reste
To morowe I shalle seye þee what me liste
¶ Þis messagiere dranke sadlye aale ⁊and wyne
And stollen were his lett̉eres prevelye
Oute of his box/ whyles he slepte as a swyne
And countrefayted were ful subtelye
Alle oþ̉er lett̉eres wrought right sinfullye
Vn to þe kyng directe/ in þis matere
Frome his Counstable/ as yee shulle aftre her̉re
¶ Þees lies speke/ þe qwene deliv̉ered was
Of so horryble a feendlye creature
Þat in þe castelle/ noone so hardye was
þer in for to abyde or to endure
þe modre was an Elffe by aventur͗e
Commen by charmes and by sorcerye
þᵗat eủery hateþe hir companye
¶ Woo was þe kyng whane he þis seye
But to no wyght he tolde his sorowes sooþe
I care namore but criste I thanke ⁊and preye
Welcome þi sonde loo lorde for eủermore
To me þᵗat am so late leernid in þy loore
wel com þi liste lorde ⁊and þi playsaunce
My wille I putte hoole in þyn ordinaunce
¶ Yette kepithe þis chylde be it foule or fayre
And eke my wyf vn to myn home comyng
Cryste whanne hym likeþe may sende me an heyre
More agreable þanne þis at his likyng
þis lettre he seelithe soore wepyng
Which to þe messagere /was taken soone
And foorþe he gooþe þer nys namore to doone
¶ O messagiere/ Fulfilled of drunkynes
Strong is þi brethe þi lymmes falteryn aye
And thowe bewryeste al mens sekrinesse
Þy mynde is lorne þowe iangeliste as a Gaye
Þi face is tournid al in a newe araye
wher dronkennesse regneþe in any rowte
Þer is noo counsaile hidde withe outen dowte
¶ O donegyle/ I haue noon engelishe dyne
Vn to thi malice and þy thiranny
And þer fore to þe feende I þe Resigne
lete him endiden of þy foule traytourye
Fy mannysshe fy o nay by god I lye
Fy feendlye spirite for I dare wel telle
þaugh þowe here walke þi spirit is in helle
¶ þis messagere came frome þe kyng a gayne
And at þe kyngꝭes moderis courte a light
And shee was of þis messagere ful fayne
She pleasid him in al þᵗat eủer shee myght
he dranke and welle his girdel vndir pyght
he slepithe ⁊and he fnowrtithe in his guyse
Al þe nyght til þat þe sunee cane ryse
¶ Effte were hees lies stolne euer echone
And counterfeyted lettrys in þis wyse
þe kyng commaundeþe his counstable a noone
Vppeyne of deethe ⁊and of hye Iuwyse +That he in no maidwise+
Coustaunce his wyf in his Regne tabyde
Three dayes and a quarter of oon tyde
¶ But in þe same Shippe/ as he hir fonde
hir ⁊and hir yowng sone/ and al hir gere
he shulde hir putte ⁊and throwe hir frome þᵉ land
And charge hir þᵗat shee neủer effte coome th̉er
O my coustaunce/ weele may þy gooste have fere
And slepyng in þi dreme/ meete in penaunce
Whane Dongylde/ caste al þis ordenaunce
¶ þis messagiere by þe morowe whanne he wooke
Vn to þe castelle/ holde he þis nexst weye
And to þe Constable/ he þe lettre toke
And whanne þᵗat he þⁱˢ pytowse łletre saye
Ful ofte he seyde ellas/ and weylaweye
Lord god quod he howe may þis worlde endure
So fulle of synne/ is many a creature
¶ O myghty god/ if þat it bee þi wille
Sithe þowe art Rightffulle/ Iuge howe may hit bee
þat þowe wolt souffre/ þe Innocentes to spille
And wikked folke regne in ꝓprosꝑperitee
O goode Coustaunce/ ellas so woo is me
þat I mot bee þi tourmentoure in hye
or dye þer fore/ þer nys no remedy
¶þer wepte booþe yonge ⁊and old in al þᵗat plas
Whanne þᵗat þe kynge þis curssid łletre sente
And Coustaunce/ withe a deedlye pale face
þe feyre day towardes þe shippe shee wente
But naþelesse shee takeþe in goode entente
þe wille of Criste and kneelyng on þᵉ Stronde
Shee sayde ay lorde welcom come to me þi sonde
¶ He þᵗat me kepte from þe fals flame
Whyles þᵗat I was on þe londe a monges yowe
He came me kepe/ Frome harome ⁊and frome shame
In þe shalt see/ al þoughe I see nought howe
Als stronge as eủer he was he is nowe
In him truste I and in his moder deer
Which is to me my Sayle ⁊and eke my steere
¶ hir litell chylde ley wepyng in hir arme
And knelyng pytouselye to him shee sayde
Pees luytel son I wolle doo þᵉ noo harome
wᵗith þᵗat þe kerchyf oủere his eyen she brayde
Al oủer hys litell eyen shee hit leyde
In hir armes shee lullid hit ful faste
Uppe to þe hevene shee hir eyen caste
¶ Modre quod shee/ and mayden bryght marye
Sooþe is þat thorowhe wymmens eggement
Mankynde was lorne/ and dampned ay to dye
For which þy chylde was on a crosse to Rente
þi bisseffulle eyen/ saughe al þis tourment
þanne is þer noon/ CompariSoune by twene
þy woo and myn withe I ne may soustene
¶ Þowe saughe þy chylde slayne/ befoore þyne eyen
And yette nowe levethe my litel chyld parfay
Now lady bright to whome/ alle synfulle cryen
þowe glorie of wommanhode/ þowe fayre maye
þowe have of Refute bryght sterre of day
Rewe on my chylde þᵗat of þⁱ gentilesse
Reweste on every synfulle in dystresse
¶O lytel chylde ellas/ what is þⁱ gylt
Þat never wroughteste synne as yit ꝑpardee
Why wolle þyne harde fadre have þᵉ spylt
O mercy my deere Constable qd she
As lete my lytel chylde/ dwelle here wᵗith þee
And gyve þowe darste nought saven him for blame
So kysse him cones yette/ for his fader name
¶Þer wᵗith shee lokithe backwardes to þe lande
And sayde farewelle housband Routhelesse
And vppe shee Risethe/ and walkeþᵉ downe þᵉ Stronde
Towardes þe Shippe/ hir folweþe all þe prees
And eủer shee preyethe hir chyld to holde his pees
And takiþe hir leve/ and wᵗith hoole entente
A soffte pas streyght to þᵉ wat̉er shee wente
¶ Evetailed was þe Shippe/ hit is noo drede
Haboundauntly for hir for long space
And oþer nestesariis þᵗat hir should nede
Shee had enough/ heryed by godes grace
For wynde and weþir/ al myghti god pour chase
And bryng hir home/ I canne no bett̉re saye
But In þe see shee driuethe forthe hir way
¶ Alla þe kyng comeþe home soone afftir þis
Vn to his castelle/ of which I yowe tolde
And askithe where/ his chylde ⁊and his wyff is
Þe Constable cane abowte his herte colde
And pleynly al þe maner þey have him tolde
As yee have herde I can tel it noo bett̉re
And sheweþᵉ þe kynge his Seele þ and his lett̉er
¶ And sayde him lord as ye comaunde me
Vppeyne of deþe/ so have I doone certayne
þis messagiere eugyned was/ til he
Moste bee knowe/ and telle platte ⁊and playne
From nyght to nyght/ in what place he had layn
And þus by witte/ and sotyle enqueryng
Y magined was by whome þis gan firste sprynge
¶ þe hande was knowe þᵗat þe łletre soo wrote
And al þe venyme of þis curside deede
But In what wyse certaynelye I noot
Þeffecte is þis þat Alla owte of drede
his modre sloughe as men may playnly rede
For þat shee thraytoresse was to hir legeaunce
Þus eendiþe þis Donegule wᵗith myschaunce
¶ þe sorowe þᵗat þis Alla /night ⁊and daye
Makeþe for his chylde/ and wyff alsoo
Þer is noo tunge/ þᵗat cane it tel ne may
But nowe wol I vn to fayre. Coustaunce goo
Þat Fleteþe in þe See in peyne ⁊and woo
Fyve yere and moore/ as likeþe Cristꝭes sonde
Er þᵗat hir shippe approched on to þᵉ lande
¶ Vndir an heþen Castel at þᵉ laste
Of wiche þe naame in my texste can not fynde
Coustaunce right þere wᵗith her chylde vpcaste
Almyti god þat savest al mankynde
have of Coustaunce and of hir chylde som mynde
which fallen is in heþen handes effte soone
In poynt to spille/ as I shalle telle yowe soone
¶ Downe frome þe castelle/ comeþe þ̉er many a wight
To gavren on this Shippe/ and on Coustaunce
But shortly frome þe castelle uppon a nyght
Þe lordes Styward god gyve him meschaunce
A theeff a Renegate/ Frome oure creaunce
Came in to Shippe alloone and sayde shee shoulde
His lemman bee wheþer shee wolde or nolde
¶ Who was þis wrecched womman/ þoo bygoone
hir childe crede /and shee ful pytouslye
But blysffulle Marye helpe hir ryght anoone
For wᵗith hir strogeling/ wele ⁊and myghtelye
Þis theeff fel oủer bord ful sodaynelye
where he was dreynte in þe see for pure vengeaunce
And þus hathe cryste vnwemmed kepte fiyre Coustaunce
¶ O foule loust luxurie/ loo þowe þyne eende
Nowght onlye þᵗat þowe Feyntest mannes mynde
But verraylye /þowe woldeste his body sheende
þende of þi werke or of þi lustes blynde
Compleynyng howe manye oone may men fynde
þᵗat nowght for werke sumtyme/ but for þentente
To doon þis synne been eyþer slayne or shente
¶ Howe may þees weyke womman have þe strengthe
her to deffende/ agayne þis renegate
A geynest golye þᵗat was soo huge of lengeþe
How myte Davithe make þee so maate
So younge ⁊and of armure soo desolaate
he nolde nowght looke vppon þi dredeful face
Wele may men see hit nis but goddei grace
¶ Who gave Iudithe courage or hardiness
To sleen him olyferne in þe tente
And to delyủer oute of wrecchednesse
þe people of god I sey for þis entente
þat Right as god vigour and spirit sent
To hem ⁊and saved owte of alle myschaunce
So sente he myght ⁊and strenkeþe to Coustaunce
¶ Forþe gooþe hir Shippe thorowe owte þe narowe mouþe
Of Iubalter and Septe dryvi foorþe ay
Some tyme weste and som tyme northe ⁊and sowþe
And some tyme este ful many a wery day
Til Cristes moodre eblessid bee shee ay
haþe shapen thorugh/ hir eendlesse goodnesse
To make an eende of al hir greete hevynesse
¶ Nowe lete vs stinte of Coustaunce but a throwe
And speke we of þe Rommayne Emperoure
which oute of Surrye /haþe by lettres knowe
Þe deþe of þe crysten/with dishonoure
Doon to his dowter/ by a fals traytoure
I mene coursed wiked Soudounas
Þat at hir feeste leete slee booÞe moor͗e ⁊and lasse
¶ For wiche þis emꝑperoure haþ sent anoone
A Senatoure wᵗith ryall ordenaunce
And oþer lordes god woot yee many oone
uppon þe Surreynes/ to take vengeauns
þey brenne ⁊and slee ⁊and bryng hem to mischaunse
Ful many aday/ but shortly þⁱˢ is þᵉ eende
Agayne to Roome/ þey shapen hem to wende
¶ Þis Senatoure/ repayreþe/ with victorye
To Roomewardes sayling ful Riallye
And mette þe Shippe fletyng/ as sayþe þᵉ Story
In wiche Coustaunce sutiþe ful pytovselye
No thyng ne knewe they what shee was ne whie
Shee was in suche array shee wolle not saye
Of hir Estate for leeff ne loope to deye
¶ he Bryngeþe hir to Roome/ and to his wyff
He haþe hir gyve/ and hir yovnge sone alsoo
wᵗith þᵉ Senatour/ þer þey ledde ther lyff
þus caune oure lady bryng wele oute of woo
Wooful Coustaunce and many oþer moo
And long tyme / shee dwellid in þat plase
In holy werkꝭes eủer as was hir grasse
¶ þe Senatours wyff to hir Aunte shee was
But for al þᵗat shee knewe hir neủer þᵉ moor͗e
I wolle noo lenger tareyen in þis cas
But to kyng Alla / which I spake of yoore
which for his wyff wepithe ⁊and sekithe soore
I wolle Retourne and leete I wolle Coustaunce
Vnder þe Senatoures/ owen gouernaunce
¶ Kyng Alla wich þᵗat/ þat had his moder slayne
Vppon a day Felle/ In suche Repentaunce
Þat yf I shortlye telle it shal and playne
Til Rome he came to Resceyve his penaunce
And put him in þe popes ordynaunce
In hye and lowe and Ihu criste be sought
For gyve his wicked werkes þᵗat he had wrovght
¶ Þe Faame a noone thorowe oute Roome is borne
howe kyng alla shall come ov̉er pilgrimage
By herbergeris þᵗat wenten him byforne
For wiche þis Senatoure as was pusage
Roode him agayne and many of his linage
Als welle to shewe his highe magnificens
As to doon any kyng suche Reuerence
¶ Gret chere loo dooþe þis noble Senatoure
To kyng Alla /and he to him alsoo
Eueriche of hem dooþe oþ̉er gret hounoure
And soo byffelle wᵗith Inne a day or twoo
Þis Senatoure is to kyng Alla goo
To feste and if I shal nowght shortely lye
Dam Coustaunce soone wᵗith him in conpayne
¶Some men wolde sey at preyere of Coustaunce
þis Senatoure haþe ladde þis chylde to feste
I may not telle eủery circumstaunce
Be as bee may þer was he at þᵉ leest
But sooþe it is right at his modres heste
By fore Alla duryng þe meete space
Þis chyld stoode lokyng ay oủer þe kyngꝭes face
¶ Alla þe kyng haþe ov̉er his chylde gret wondre
And to þe Senatoure he saide þus anoone
Whos is that fayre chylde þat stondiþe yeondre
I not quod he by god ⁊and by Saynt Ihon
A modir he haþe but fadre haþe he noone
Þat I of wotte and shortlye in a stounde
He tolde Alla in what wyse he him fonde
¶ But god woote/ quod þis Senatoure alsoo
So vertuous a liver in my liff

l.hi: Ne saughe I never as shee yitte in my lyffe

div.l: Ne saughe I neuer as shee ne herde of moo
Of wordlye wymmen of mayden ne of wyff
I dare wel say shee hade lever a kynff
Thorowe owte hir herte þanne been a womma͗n wykke
þer nas never man kouþe bryng hir to þᵉ prykke
¶ Nowe was þis chylde/ als like vn to Coustaunce
As possible is a creature to be
þis Alla haþe þe Face in Rememberavnce
Of fayre Coustaunce /and þer on musiþe hee
Þat if þe chyldes modre /were owght shee
Þanne is it his wyf/ and priuely seyhe
And spedde him frome þe table/ what he myght
¶ ꝐParfay thought he þe fantome is in my mynde
Me aught deeme it of Right fulle Iugement
Þat In þe salt see men may hir fynde
And afftirwardes/ he made þis argument
What wot I þaughe cryste haþe hir heþir sent
My wyf Coustaunce/ als wel as he hir ment
To my countree/ Frome þens as shee first went
¶ And afftir mete hoome wᵗith þe Senatoure
Gooþe Alla for to see þis wonder chaunce
þis Senatoure dooþe þe kyng greete hounour͗e
And hastely he sent afftre Coustaunc
But triste me wel hir liste not panne to daunce
Whanne þat shee wiste/ wher For was þᵗat sonde
Vnneoþes vppon hir feete/ she might þoo stonde
¶ Whanne Alla sawhe his wyf fayre he hir grette
And wepte eeke þᵗat it was rowthe to see
For atte þe fyrste looke he on hir sette
He knewe welle verraylie þᵗat it was shee
And for sorowe als doumbe/ as a tree
So was hir herte /shutte in hir distresse
whanne shee Remembred of his vnkyndnesse
¶ Twys she swounythe in his owne syght
He weepithe/ and excusithe him pitovselye
Now god quod he/ and alle hees halowes bright
So wysshelye of my soule þow have mercy
þᵗat of yowre harome/ al gyltles am I
As is Maurice my sonne so like youre Face
And ellis þe feende me fecche owte of þis place
¶ long was þe sobbyng and þᵉ byttre peyne
Er þat hir woofulle hert might hit sees
Gret was þe pitee for here hir pleyne
Thorughe wheeche pleyntꝭes/ gane hir woo encresse
I pray yow alle my laboure to releese
I may not telle hir woo/ vn til to morow
I am so wery for to speke of sorowe
¶ But finallye whanne þᵗat þe sooþᵉ is wyste
Þat Alla giltlesse was of al hir woo
I trowe an hunderithe tymes been þey keste
And suche a blisse is þere by twene hem twoo
Þat saue þe Joye þat lastithe eủer moo
Þer is noon lyche þat any creature
Haþe seyne or shalle/ whyle þᵗat þᵉ worlde may dure
¶ Þoo prayde shee þer hir husbande meekely
In fulle releef of al hir pitouse peyne
Þat he wold pray her fadre speciallye
Þat of his mageste he wolde encline
To Wouchesaff wᵗith him som tyme to dyne
She prayde him eke/ þᵗat he shoulde by no wey
Vn to hir fadre/ no word of hir saye
¶ Some wolde seye howe þᵗat þe chylde maurice
Dooþe this message/ vn to þe Emꝑperroure
But as I gesse/ Alla nas not so nyse
To him þat is so souuerin of honoure
As he that is of Cristes folke þe floure
Send any chylde but it is bette to deeme
he went him selfe and soo it may welle seene
¶ Þis Emperroure hathe grauntid gentillye
To come til dyner as he hym be sought
Als weele reede I he loked ful beselye
Vppon this chylde/ and on his dowghter thovte
Alla Retournith home and as him thowght
Arrayed for þe feeste/ in euery wyse
Asl Ferforthe as his konnyng may suffice
¶ Þe morowe cam/ and Alla can him dresse
And eek his wyff þis Emperowre to mete
And furþer þey Riden/ in Ioye ⁊and gladnesse
Til þat shee sawe/ hir fadre in þe Streete
Shee alight a downe/ and falliþe him to feete
Fadre quod shee yowre owne dowt̉er Coustaunce
Is nowe ful clene/ oute of youre Remembraunce
¶ I am youre doughter/ Coustance þoo qduod shee
Þat whilome yee have sente vn to Surrye
It am I Fadre which in þe salt See
Was putte alloone/ and dampned for to dye
Nowe goode fadre/ of mercy I yow creye
Sende me namore/ vn to noon heþenesse
But thankithe my lorde/ here of his kyndnesse
¶ Whoo canne þe pytovse Ioy etelen alle
Bytwyxe hem three/ sithe they been þus I mette
But of my tale/ makeN an eende I shalle
Þe day gooþe faste I wolle no leng̉er lette
Þees glad folke/ to dyner they hem sette
In Ioye ⁊and blysse atte mete I lette hem dwelle
A thovsand folde/ weele moore þan I canne telle
¶ This chyld Maurice was syþen Emperoure
Made by þe poope and livid crystinli
To crystes chirche/ he dide gret hounoure
But I lete al hes storye passe me by
Of coustaunce/ my tale is speciallye
In olde Romayne geestes/ may men fynde
Mauryces lyff I bere hit not in mynde
þis kyng Alla/ whanne he his tyme seye
wᵗith his coustaunce/ his holye wyff so swete
To England þey take þᵉ streyte weye
Where as þey lyve/ in ioye ⁊and in quiete
But litel while hit lasteþe I yowe behete
Ioy of this worde/ For tyme wolle notte abyde
From day to nyght/ it chaungeþe as þᵉ tyde
¶ Whoo lyved eủer/ in suche delyte a day
Þat he nas meeved/ oþer in conseyens
Or yre to talent or somkyns a fraye
Envy or preyde/ or passiouns of offence
I ne sye but for þis eende þis sentence
Þat litle whyle/ in Ioye or in plesaunce
lasteþ þe blisse of Alla/ with Coustaunce
¶ For deþe that takithe of hye ⁊and lowe his rente
Whanne passed was a yere as I gesse
Owte of þis worde/ þis kyng Alla hathe hent
For whome Coustaunce haþe take gret hevynesse
Now lete vs pray to god his soule blesse
And of Coustance/ now herkeniþe me I praye
howe towardes Roome shee shapithe hir o hir weye
¶Whanne shee to Roome is come þiscreature
And fyndeþe hir freendis þere boþe hoole ⁊and sounde
Nowe is shee scaped al herd a venture
But whanne þᵗat shee hir fadir hathe found
Downe on hir knees shee fallith to grounde
Weping in herte for tendirnesse blithe
She heryde god an hundrid mlthousand sithe
¶ In vertu and in holy almes dede
þei lyven al and neủer a sondre wend
Til dethe departid them þⁱˢ lyf þei lad
And Farithe nowe welle my tale is atta ende
Now IhuIesus Criste that of his myght may sende
Ioy aftir woo goủerne vus in his grace
And kepe vus al þᵗat ben in this place / Amen
Here Endithe the man of Lawes tale
Ovre hoste on̄ his stiropis stode anon̄
And seithe goodemen harkenithe eủerychon
þis was aa Tryfty tale for the nonis
Sir parishe prest quod he for goddis bonys
Tel vs atale as was thi foreward yor̉e
I see well that lernid men in lor̉e
Can muche goode by goddis dignitee
The parson him aunswerde benedicite
What Eylithe the man so synfully to swer̉e
Oure hoost aunswerde O Iankyn be ye ther̉e
I smel a loller̉e in the wynde qduod he
Now good men quod oure hooste herkenithe me
Abyde for goddis digne passion
For we shall have a p̉redicacioun̄
Þis loller wolle preche vs her so sumwhat
Nay be my fadre soule that shaƚƚ he nowte
Seyde the Squier shaƚƚ he not her preche
He shall no gospell glose her͗e ne teche
We be levithe her͗e al in grete god qduod he
He wolde show some difficultee
Or sprynging kokel in owre clene corne
And ther fore Est I warne the be forne
My Ioly body shaƚƚ a tale telle
And I shalle Clynke yowe so mery a belle
That I shaƚƚ waken all this Companye
But it shaƚƚ not be no philosophie
Ne Phisilias ne termes queynte of lawe
Ther is but litiƚƚ latyne in my mawe
Here beginnithe the Squier his tale/
At Sarry in the londe of tartary
Þer dwellid a kyng þᵗat werrid upᵒⁿ russy
Thorow which þe dide many a dowty man
This noble kynge was Clepid kambustan
Whiche in his tyme was of so grete Renowne
Þat þẻr was no wher̉e in no Regioune
So Excellent a lorde in alle thinge
He lakked not that longed on to a kynge/
As of the Secte which he was borne
He kepte his lay to whiche he was sworne
And þ̉ere to he was hardy wyse ⁊and Riche
And Petous and Iuste alwey eliche
Bothe of his worde beynge and honorable
Of his Corage as eny Centr̉e stabiƚƚ
Yonge Freshe and strong in armes desirows
As Eny bacheler of his howse
A Feyre ꝑpersone he was and Fortunate/
And kepte alwey so Rall estate/
he hade twoo sonnes on alpheta his wyff
Of whiche the Elder hight Algarsife
The tother sonne was clepid Cambollo
A douter had this worthi kynge also
þat yongeste was that hight Canase
But For to telle yowe of hir bewte
hit lithe not in my tonge/ ne in my connynge/
I dare not telle so hihe a thinge
Myn Englishe is eke in sufficient
I most be a rethoriche Excellent
Þat Coude þe Colours longing for þᵗat Arte
yf I shulde discrve her eủery parte
I am noon suche I moste speke as I Can
And so by fille this Cambuscan
Hathe xx wynt̉er borne his diademe
As he went From yeer to yeer I deme
He lete þe Feste of his nativitee
Do crye thorow Sorry the Cetee
þe last Idous of Mars aftir þe yeer
Phebus the sonne ful Ioly was and cler
For he was in his Exaltacioun
In Martis Face and is in his mansion
In Aries the Colorike þe hote signe
Ful lusty was þe weder ⁊and beynge
For whiche the fowles a yeuse the sonne shene
What Fo for the seson and þe yonge grene
Wel loude songe her affeccions
Hem semed to getin agene hir proteccions
Ayene the swerde of wynt̉er kene and colde
This Cambuskan of whiche I have yow tolde
In Ral vestementꝭes satte on his deyse
wᵗith diademe full hihe in his paleyse
And helde his feste ful solempnely and so Riche
That in this worlde was ther non hit liche
Of whiche yf I shulde telle all the array
Than wolde it occupien a Someris day
And Eke it nedithe not to devise
At Euỉer ord course þe ordre of hir servise
I wolle not telle of hir strong Sewes
Ne of hir Swannes ne her heronsewes
Eke in that londe as tellyn knyghtes olde
Is som mete þat is ful deynte holde
Þat in this londe men Reche of it but smal
Þẻr is noman that may Reporten all
I wolle not tarye yow for it is prime
And for it is frute but los of tyme
Vn to my firste tale I wol have my first recours
And so be felle þᵗat aftir the thirde Cours
While that this kynge sat in his hie nobley
Herkyng his mynstrellꝭes her thingꝭes pleye
Be for him at his borde delyciously
In atte þe halle dore sodenly
Þẻr come a knyght vpon a stede of bras
And in his honde a brode myrrowr of glasse
On his thumbe he had of golde a Rynge
And by his syde anakd swerde hangynge
And vp he Ridethe to the hye borde
In all the hall ne was ther spoke a worde
For marvayle of this kiyght hi to beholde
And besely they wayton boþe yonge ⁊and olde
This straunge knyght that Come so sodenly
Al armid saff his hede full Richelye
he Salude kynge ⁊and Quene ⁊and lordes alle
By ordure as they suten in the halle
wᵗith so hie Reverence and obeisaunce
As welle in Speche as in contenaunse/
þat Gawen wᵗith his olde curtesye
Thouh he come a yene oute of Feyrye/
Ne cowde hi mende wᵗith a worde
After this be fore the hie lorde
He wᵗith manly voyse seyde his message
Aftir the forme vsid in his langage
wᵗithoute sayle of sillable or of lettr̉e
And for his tale shulde seme the bett̉re
Accordant to his worde was his cher̉e
As techeth art of spech he that it ler̉e

l.hi: Al þᵗat I can nat clymbyn ouer so hie an hille

div.l: Than sey I thus to the comoune entente
Þus muche amountith þᵗat he ment
yf it so be þᵗat I have it in mynde
he seyde that the kynge of Arabye and of ynde
My lege lorde on this solempne day
Salvethe yowe as he beste can and may
And Sendethe yowe in honour at yowr feste
Be me that am al Redy at youre heste
This Stede of bras þᵗat Esely and welle
Can in the Spase of a day naturell
That is to sey in four̉e and xx owres
Marginalia+ Wher ye wil i drowt or shourꝭes
+ Ber͗en yowr͗e body to eủery place
To whiche ȝour̉e hert willith for to pase
wᵗith oute wem of yow throuȝe foule ⁊and feyr̉e
Or yf yowe liste to flye as hihe in þe here
As dothe an Eugle when hīm liste to sor̉e
This same Steede shal bere yow eueremoore
wᵗithouten harme til ye be ther̉e yoo leste
Thouhe that ye slepe on his bakke or Reste
And turne a yene wᵗith wrynging of a pyn
he that it wrovght it knew meny a gynne
he waytid many a Constulacion
Or he had this Operacion
And knewe meny a skyll and meny a bonde
This myrrowr and Eke that I have in my honde
hathe suche a myght that men may in hit see
when ther shall Falle eny advsitee
Vnto yoᵘur Regne or to yoᵘur sel vel also
And opinly whoo is yoᵘur Frende or foo
And oủer all this yf any lady bryght
hathe sette hir her herte on ony man̉er wyght
yf he be fals she shall his treson see
his new love and al his subtilitee
So opinly that þẻre shalle no thing hide
wher for̉e ayens this lusty someris tyde
Þis myrroure and this Rynge þᵗat ye may see
he sent to my lady Canace
yowre excellent dowt̉er þᵗat is here

l.hi: Is this that if hir list it for to were

div.l: Vppon hir Thombe or in hir purse it ber͗e
Þer is no foule þat Fleeþe vndir hevene/
þat she ne shall vndstonde his stevene
And knowe his menyng openly ⁊and pleyne
And avnswer̉e him in langage ageyne
And every grasse that growithe vppoōn the Rote
She shall knowe and whom it wolle do bote
Al be his wounde neủer so depe nor wyde
Þis naked swerde/ that hongith by my syde
Such vertu hathe that what man ye smyte/
Thorowe oute his armure it wolle kerve ⁊and byte
Wer̉e it as thikke as a braunchid oke
And what man it woundeþe wᵗith the stroke
he Shalle neủer be hole tyl yowe lyst of grace
To stroke him wᵗith the plate swerd in þe same place
Þat he is hurte/þᵗat is as mechill to seyne/
He mot wᵗith þe plat swerde ageyne
Stroke hīm in þe woᵘunde and it wolle close
This is a werrey sothe wᵗithouten glose
It faylithe not nowe whil it is in yoᵘur holde
And when the knyght hathe thus his tale tolde
he Ride ovte of the halle / and downe he light
his stede whiche that shone as sonne bright
Stout in þe Courte stille as eny stone
This knyght is to þe chaumbr̉e is ladde anon
And is vnarmed and to mete sette
Þe presentꝭes be Richely kepte
Þis ⁱˢ to sey the swerde ⁊and þe myrroᵘur
Bene borne anone in to the toure/
wᵗith Certen offic̉eres ordeynid þẻrefore
And on to Canace þe Rynge is borne
Solempnely þer she satte atte table
But Sekyrli wᵗith oute eny Fable
Þe horse of bras þat may not be Remewid
It Stondithe as it wer̉e to þe grounde I clevid
Þer may noman oute of the place it drive
For noon Engyne wyndes ne polyve
And cause whye for they can not þe crafte
And þẻer fore in the place þey have it laft
Til that the knyght have tawte hēm þe man̉er
To voyden him as ye shal aftir her̉er
Grete was the pres þᵗat swermid to ⁊and froo
To garen oủer þe hors þᵗat stode so
For it so hye was and brode⁊and longe
So wele proporciounide to bee strong
Ryght as it wer̉e astede of lumbardy
Þer to so horslye and so quikke of yee
As it agentil corsere poleyn̄ wer̉e
For Certes from his tayle vn to his ere
Nature nearte ne coude him not a mende
In noo degree as alle the peple wende
But eủermore her moste wondre it was
How that it coude goo and was of bras
It was of fᵉiery as alle þe peple wende
Diủerse Folke diủersely demid
As meny hedis as meny wittꝭes þẻre ben
Þei mormeden as doon a swarme of been
And made Skyllis aftir her fantesye
Rehersyng of the olde poetrye
And seide it was like the pigase
Þe hors that had wyngꝭes for to flee
Or ellꝭes it was the grekꝭes hors Synome
That browght the Grekis to distroccioun̄
As men in thes olde gestꝭes Rede
Myn herte quod on̄ is eủermore in drede
I trowe some men of armes ben þẻre in
That shape hem this Citee for to wynne
It wer͗e Right goode that/ alle suche thing wer͗e know
A noþẻre Rounde to his Felow lowe
And seyd he lyed for it was raþẻer like
An apparence made by some magyke
As iogoulours pleyn̄ at thes feestꝭes grete
Of sundry thoughtꝭes þus þei Iangille ⁊and trete
As lewde peple demen comynlye
Of thinges that ben made mor͗e subtelye
Then thei can in thei͗e lewdnenesse co͒mp̉rehende
They demen Gladly to þe badder͗ Ende
And some of hēm wonderid on̄ the myrroᵘur
Þat borne was vp into þe mastr͗e, towr͗e
How men myght in hit suche thingꝭes see
And oþẻre aunswerde and saide it myght wel be
Naturelly by composissioun̄
Of aungels and of sly for Refleccions
And saide that in Rome was suche one
Þei speke of Alcen̄ and of vetelon̄
And of Arestotle þat wryte in hir lyves
Of Queynte myrroᵘurs and prospecsatyses
As knowe þei þᵗat have her͗e bookes herde
And oþe͗re folke hathe wonderid on þe swerde
That wolde perishe thorow out eủery thinge/
And fel in speche of thelophus the kynge
And off Achilles for his queynte sper̉e
For he coude wᵗith hit boþe hele and der͗e
Ryght in suche wyse as men may wᵗith þe swerde
Of whiche Right nowe ye have yoᵘur selve harde
Þey speke of sundry hardynge of metalle
And speke of medecinis þẻre wᵗith aƚƚlle
And whan̄ and how it shulde hardid be
Whiche vnknowen algate is to me
Þoo speke Þei of Canaces Ringe
And saide al that suche a wond̉er thyng
Of crafte of Rynges harde þei neủer noon̄
Save that by moyses and kynge salamon̄
Had a man̉er connyng on̄ suche a mann̉er arte
Þus seyne the peple and drawen̄ hem a parte/
But netheles some seyden that it was
Wondre to make of Ferne glas

rdg.hi: And yit is glas nat lyk asshen of ferne

app.rdg: And yit is glas nat lyk asshen of ferne

div.l: þẻre fore sesithe hir Iangelynge ⁊and hir wondir
As for͗e wonderen̄ som̄ þe cause of þe þund͗e
On̄ Ebbe on̄ flode on̄ gossom̉er ⁊and on̄ myste
And on̄ althing til þe cause is wiste/
Thus Iaingelyn̄ þei demin̄ ⁊and devisen̄
Til that the kynge gan from the borde a Risen̄
Phebus hathe lefte the aungel meredionaƚƚ
And yitte assendyng was þe best Ryaƚƚ
Þe gentil lioun̄ wᵗith his Aldrian̄
When that þis tartre kyng Cambustan̄
Rose From̄ his borde þẻre he sat ful hihe
Be forne hīm gooþe the loude mynstrelsye
Til he come to his chambr͗e of par͗ementys
Þẻre as þei sownyn̄ diuers Instrumentꝭes
Þat is like an heven̄ for to her͗e
Now daunsen̄ lusty Venus childerin̄ der̉e
For in the Fysshe her ladye satte ful hihe
And lokeþe on hēm wᵗith a frendlye eye
This noble kynge is sette vpon̄ his trone
This staunge knyght is fet to hīm ful sone
And on̄ the davnce he goþe wᵗith Canace /
Þẻre is þe Reuel and þe Iolytee/
Þat is not able a dul man̄ to devise
He muste have knowe such of such of love ⁊and his ʆseruice
And be a festlych man as Fressh as maye
Þat shulle yewe deuisen suche a raye
Whoo coude yowe telle þe Forme of daunces
So vncouthe ⁊and so Fresshe countenauns
And þẻre to suche subtely lokynges
Fro drede of Ielowse of menꝭes preysinges
No man but launcelot /and he is dede/
Þẻre for I pas oủer alle þis lusty hede/
I sey nomor͗e but in this Iolynes
He lete hem too too men to soꝑper hem dresse /
Þe Styward bid Spicꝭes for to hye
And eke the wyne in alle þis melodye/
The vsshers and þe Squiers ben goon̄
The Spices and þe wyne ben come anon̄
They Ete and dronke ⁊and when þⁱˢ was at a Ende
Into the temple as Reson̄ was they wende
Þe service do þey solempnely that daye
What nedeþe to Reherse her̉e þẻre araye/
Eche man wot welle that a kyngꝭes feste
Hathe plente to þe moste ⁊and þe lest
And deyntes moo þan be in my knowyng
And aftir soꝑper gothe this noble kyng
To se his horse of bras wᵗithalle þe Rowte
Of lordes ⁊and ladies him a bowte
Suche wonderinge was of this horse of bras
That sithen the grete sege of troy was
Þẻre as men wonderid on an hors also
Ne was þẻre suche a wondering as was þo
But finally þe kynge axethe þe knyght
Þe vertu of this Coursoᵘur ⁊and þe myght
And prayde to telle hīm his goủernaunce
The hors gan to trippe ⁊and to daunce /
When that this knyght leyde honde on his Reyn
And seyde sir þẻre is nomore to seyne /
But yf yowe lyste to Redyn̄ ony wher͗e
Ye must trylle a pyn þat stonte in his er͗e
Whiche I s\h/alle telle yowe be twyx vs too
To nampne hīm also to what place yee wolle/
Or to what contrᵉ ye list to Riden
And when ye come þẻre ye list abiden
By him dessende ⁊and triƚƚlle a noþẻre pyn
For þẻre in lithe the Effecte of al þe gyn
And he wolle doune descende ⁊and do al yoᵘur wylle
And in that place he wolle abide stille
Þeye al þe worlde had þe contᵃrary sworne
He shall not thens be prowe ne borne
Or yf yow liste bid hīm thens goon
Tryƚƚlle this pynne ⁊and he wolle vanysshe anon
Ovte of þe syte of every man wyght
And come ayene be it day or nyght
When that yow lyste clepin hīm ayene
In suche a gyse as I shall unto yow seyn
Betwene me and yowe ⁊and þᵗat Rght sone
Rde when yow text underlinedtext underlined nomor͗e to done
Enformed when the kyng was of þe knyght
And hathe conseyuid in his wit a Right
Þe man̉er and þe forme of aƚƚlle this thing
Ful glad ⁊and blythe was this noble kynge
Repeyryng vn to his Rebel as be forn
Þe brydel is in to þe tovr borne
And kepte a monge his Iueles lefe ⁊and der̉re
Þe hors vaneshed I not in what man̉ere
Oute of hir syte he gete nomor͗e of me
But in luste þus I lete ⁊and in Iolytee /
Þis Cambustan his lordes fastynge
Til wel nye the day be gan to sprynge /
The noryssh of deiestions þe slepe
Gan on hem wynke ⁊and bad þem take kepe
That muche mete ⁊and laboᵘur wolle have Reste
And wᵗith a galping movthe hēm al be kyst
And seyde it was tyme to lye a dovne
For blode was in his dominacioun
Cherycheblode natures frende quod he
Þei than ken him galping by to be tre
And eủery wyght gan drawe hīm to his Reste
As slepe hēm bad þei take it for þe beste
Her dremes shall not be tolde for me
Ful wer͗e hir hedis of Fumositee
Þat causithe dremᵉs of whiche þẻre is no charge
Þei slepin til it was prime large
Þe moste parte but it wer͗e canace
She was fulle mesurable as women be
For of hir fadir had she take hir leve
To go to Reste sone aftir it was evin
her lyste not apallid for to be
Not on the morowe vnfestlyche for to se
And slepe hir firste slep and awoke
For suche ioye she in hir myrroᵘur toke
Boþe of hir queynte Rynge ⁊and of hir mirroᵘur
þᵗat twenty tymes she chaungid hir coloᵘur
And in hir slep for hir Impressioune
Of hir mirrour͗ she had a visioune
Wher for or þe sonne ganne vp glyde
She clepid vp hir mastres her be syde
And saide that hir liste for to arise
Þes olde women þat ben gladly wyse
As hir mastres annswerde hir a non
And saide madam wheþẻr wolle ye goon
Thus Erly for folke ben al in Reste
I wolle quod she a Ryse for me lyste
No leng̉er slepin but walken abovte/
Her mastres clepid women a grete Rovte
And vp þei Rysen wele x· or xii·
Vp risethe freshe Canace her selve
As Rody and bryght as þe yonge sonne/
Þat in the Rem is ten degrees I Ronne
No hier was she when she Redy was
And forthe she walkethe esely a pas
Arayed aftir the losty seson soote /
lyghtly for to pley and walke on foote
Not but v· or vi· of hir meyne
And in a trenche for in a parke goth she
Þe vapour͗ whiche fro þe Erthe glode
Makethe the sonne to seme Roddy ⁊and brode
But netheles it was feyr͗ a syght
That it made all hir hertꝭes for to lyght
What for the seson and þe mornynge
And for the foulis þᵗat she harde synge
For Ryght a non she wist what thei ment
Ryght by hir songe and knowe alle hir entente
Þe knot whie that eủery tale is tolde
Yf it be taryed tille luste be Colde
Of hem þᵗat have it herkenid yor͗
Þe savour͗ passiþe eủer leng̉er þe mor͗
For fulsumnes of prolixite
And by same Resoune thinkithe me
I shulde unto þe knot condiscendid
Aⁿᵈnd make of hir walkynge sone an ende
Amyd a tree for dred white as chalke
As canace / was pleynge in hir walke
Þer satte a faucon oủer hir hede fulle hie
Þᵗat wᵗith a petouse voyse so gan to crye
That al þe woode Resounde of hir crye
And betyn hadde hir selve so petousely
wᵗith bothe hir wynges to þe Rede blode
Ran Endlonge þe tree as she stoode
And eủer in oon alwey she cride ⁊and shrit
And wᵗith her bek her selff so she siuyt
Þat þẻre nas tigre ne cruelebest cruelbeste
Þat dwellithe oyþẻre in woode or in foreste
Þat wolde have wepte yf he wepe couthe
For sorowe of hir alwey she shrytt alwey so louþe
For þer was neủer yitte man on lyve
Yf that ʰᵉ coude a faucon welle discrive
Þat herde of suche a noþẻre of Feyrnes
As wele of plumage as of gentilesse /
Of Shappe of al þat myght I Rekenid be
A faucon peregyn þan semed she
Of Frem londe and eủermor͗ as she stode
She swovnethe nowe and now for lak of blode
Tyl welnye she is Fallen from þe tree
This faire kyngꝭes dowt̉er Canace /
Þat on hir fyng̉er hathe þe queynte Rynge/
Þorowe whiche she vndirstode vel eủery thinge
Þat eny foule may in his langage seyn
And coude answer͗ in his ledyn ayen
Hathe vndirstonde what this faucon seyde
And wel nye for Rowthe she dide
And to the tree she goþe ful hastelye
And on this faucon lokethe ful petovslye
And helde hir lappe a brode/ for wel she wyst
Þe faucon muste fal fro the twyste
When þᵗat hit swounithe nexte for lak of blode
A longe while to wayte þẻre she stode
Til at the laste she spake in this man̉er
Vn to the havke as ye shul aftir her̉e
What is þe cause/ yf it be for to telle
Þat ye ben in this furayle payne of helle
Quod Canace vnto this hauke above
Is it for sorowe of dethe or ellꝭes of love
For as I trowe yes ben þe causes too
Þat causithe moste a gentil herte wo
Of oþẻre harme It nedithe ⁿᵒᵗ to speke
For thowe your selve oppon yevr͗ selve wolde wreke
Which þᵗat previth wel þᵗat oþẻre Ire or drede
Mot be Encheson of your͗ crewel dede
Syn þᵗat I see noon oþẻre wᵗith yow chase
For love of god so do yoᵘur selve grase
Or what may be your͗ helpe for west ne est
