Saw I neủre or nowe byrde ne beste
Þat ferd wᵗith him selve so petovsely
Ye Sle me wᵗith yowr͗ sorow verrely
I have of yow so grete copassion
For goddis love come froo þe tree a downe
And as I am a kyngꝭes dowt̉er trewe
Yf þat I þe causes verely knew
Of yoᵘur disese yf that it lye in my myght
I wolde a mende it er it wer͗e nyght
As wysly helpe me grete god of kynde
And erbes Right I now shall I Fynde
To hold wᵗith yoᵘur hurtꝭes hastely
Þo shrit this faucon mor͗ petovslye
Than eủer she did and fil to grounde anone
And lithe a swone as dede as any stone
Til Canace hathe in hir lappe I take
Vn to that tyme off swone she kan awake
And aftir þᵗat she oute swoun gan breyde
Right in hir haukes lyden ryght þus she seyde
Þat pitee rynnethe sone in gentel herte
Feling is similitude in Reynes smerte /
Is proved al day as men may see
As wel by werke as by auctoritee
For gentil herte kitheithe gentilnesse
I se wele þᵗat ye have of my distres
Compassion my feyr canace
Of werray womanly benygnite
Þat nature in your͗ principils hathe I sette
But For no hope to fare the bette
But for to obey to yoᵘur herte free
And for to make oþẻre be ware by me
As by þe whelpe chastid/ is þe lioune
Ryght for that cause and that coꝯconclusion
While that I have leyser and space
Myn harm I wolle confesse or þᵗat I pas
And eủer while þe ton hir sorowe to lde
Þat toþẻre wepte as she to wat̉er wolde
Til that the faucon bad hir be stille \
And wᵗith a syk þus she saide hir wille
Þẻre I was bredde alas þat daye
And fosterid in a Roche of Marbill greye
So tendirly that nothing Eylid me
I ne wiste what was aduersitee
Til I coude fli ful hy vndir þe skyee
Tho dwellid a tarcelette me fast by
That semed of all gentillesse
Alle wer͗e he ful of treysoune ⁊and falsnes
That is wrappid vndir Vmble cher͗
And vndir huh of trowþe in suche man̉er
Vndir this plesaunce ⁊and vndir besy peyne
That no wyght wolde awende þᵗat he coude fayne
So depe in greyne he dide his colours
Right as a serpente hidithe him vndir flouris
Til he may se his tyme for to byte
Right so this god of love this Ipocryte
Dothe so his sormons ⁊and his obeisaunce
And kepite in semblaunt all hise observᵃnces
That sownythe vnto gentilnesse ⁊and love
As in a tombe is al the feir͗e above
And vndir is the Corþus suche as ye wote
Suche was the Ipocryte bothe colde ⁊and hote
And in this wyse he seruid his Entente
That sawe the fende noōn wiste what he ment
Til he so longe had wepte and compleyind
And many a yeer͗e his ʆseruice vnto me feynid
Til that my herte to petous ⁊and to myse
Al Innocent of his crouned malice
For ferde of his dethe as hit thoute me
Oppon his othis and his suerte
Grauntid him love vppon þis cōnducion
Þitt eủer mor͗e myn honoᵘur ⁊and my renoun
Wer͗e saued bothe pʳue and parte
This is to sey that after his deshert
I yaf IħuIhesu al my herte ⁊and al my thought
God woote and he and op̉re wise noght
And toke his hert in chounge of myn for ay
But sothe is saide gon sithe many a day
A trewe wyht and a theffe think not one
And when she sawe the thing so fend a gon
That I graunted IħuIhesu fully my loue
In suche a wise as I hauᵉ saide aboue
And yeue iħcihesu my trewe herte a nd a and free
As he swore he yaf his herte to me
A non this tygre ful of dobilnesse
Fil on his knees wᵗith grete vmbilnesse
Withe his Reủerens as by his Cher͗e
So like a gentil lover in his man̉ere
So Ramsstthe as it semith for the Ioye
That neủre Iason ne Pars of Troy
Iason Certes ne non oþ̉ere man
Syn Lamyth was þᵗat alderfirste be gan
To louyn to as writyn folke be forne
Ne neủer sithe the þe firste man was borne
Ne cowde man be xx ml parte
Countrefete the Sophimis of his arte
Ne nẻer worthi to vnbokel his galache
Ther doubilnesse of Feynyng shulde aproche
Ne so thank a white as he did me
His man̉er was an heuin for to see
To any woman wer͗e she neủer so wyse
So peyntid he his cher͗e at poynt devise
As welle his wordes as his countenauns
And so I louid him for his obeysaunce
And for the trowthe in his herte
That yf so wer͗e yf any thynge iħuihesu smert
Al wer͗e it neủer so lite and I I it wiste
Me thought I herde dethe at my hert twyst
And shortly so ferforthe this thinge went
That my wil was his willis Instrument
This is to sey my wil obeyid his wil
In al thing after that Reson fil
Kepyng the bondis of my worshipe eủre
Ne neủer had I thing so lefe ne lever
As iħuihesu god woote ne neủere shal I moo
This lastid leng̉er than a yer͗e or too
That I supposid of him nothying but gode
But finally þus at laste it stode
That fortune wolde that he muste twynne
Oute of that place whiche I was in
Wher me wer͗e woo it as no questioun
I Can not make of it discripcion
For oo thing I dar͗e telle boldely
I knowe what þe payne of deþe is þẻreby
Suche harme þᵗat he ne myght me leue
So on a day of me he toke his leue
So sorowfully eke that I went verely
That he had fellid as muche sorow as I
When that I harde iħuihesu speke ⁊and sawe his hewe
But netheles I thought he was so trewe
And eke that he Repeyr͗e shall a gayne
Wᵗith in a litle while sothe to seyn
And Reson wolde eke that he muste goo
For his honoᵘur and ofte hit fallithe soo
That I made vertu of necessitee
And toke it welle sin it muste be
As I best myght ⁊and hid from me me my sorow
And toke iħuihesu by the honde Seint Iohn to borowe
And I Seide thus loo I am yoᵘurs alle
Bothe suche as I have be to yow and shaƚƚlle
What he aunswerd hit nedithe not to Reherse
Who can sey bet þay he þat can do werse
When he hathe al said than hathe he don
Ther fore be houtthe him a longe spone
That shall ete wᵗith a fende þus hard I sey
So at taft he muste forthe his wey
And forthe he flethe til he come þẻre iħuihesu liste
When it cam him to purpose for to Rest
I trow þᵗat he had in tixt in mynde
That al thing Repayrnge to his kynde
Gladethe iħuihesu selfe þus seyn men as I ges
Men loue of ꝓpropyr͗e kynde Newfangelnesse
As briddis Don that men in cagꝭes fede
Fo r r they thow nyght alday of him take hed
And strawe hir Cage fair͗e ⁊and softe as silke
And yeve hem sugr͗e hony brede ⁊and milke
Ȝit Right a non as sone as his dore is vp
He wᵗith his fete wolle Sporne downe his cuppe
And to þe woode he wolle ⁊and wormes ete
So newfangle be they of hir mete
Of lovᵉ Novellriis of propr͗e Kynde
No gentilesse of blode may iħuihesu bynde
So ferde this tarcellet allas þe day
Thow he wer͗e gentil borne Freshe ⁊and gay
And goode to see ⁊and bothe vumble ⁊and Free
He Saw vppon a tyme a kyte Flee
And sodenly he lovid this kyte so

And hathe his trowthe falsid in this wise
Thus hathe þe kyte my love in his ʆservice
I am lorne wᵗith oute Remedye
And wᵗith that worde þis faucon gan to crye

Grete was the sorowe for þᵗith havkꝭes harme

They nist howe þey myght the faucon̄ gla
But Canacee he berithe her͗e in her lappe

Now can not Canace but Erbis delve

To hele wᵗith the havke fro day to nyght
She dothe hir besines ⁊and al hir myght
And by her beddis hede she made a mewe
And koverd it wᵗith weluettꝭes newe
In sign͗e of trowthe that is in wommēn sene
And all wᵗith oute the mew I peyntid grene
In whiche wer͗e peyntid al thes fals fovlis
As ben thes tidiffis tarcelettꝭes ⁊and owles
Right For dispite wer͗e peyntid her͗e be side
Pyes on he for to Crye and Chide
Þus lete I Canace her hawke kepyng
I wolle nomor͗e as nowe speke of hir Ryng
Til it come efte to pᵘurpose for to seyn

The kyngꝭes sone of whiche I yow to tolde

And yẻre I lefte I wolle a yene be gynne
Appollo wirlith vp his Chare so hihe

Here endith the Squyers tale
And here beginnithe þe Marchaundis tale
WEpinge ⁊and wayling Car͗e and oþẻre sorowe
I know I now bothe evin ⁊and Eke on morowe

I have a wyf qduod he the worst that any any may be

What shulde yewe reherce in special

Whilom þẻre dwellithe in lumbardy

And yeer͗e a wyfles man was he

To take a wyf it is a glorious thinge
And namly whan A man w olde wolde ⁊and hore

And trewly it sit wel for to be soo
That bachelers hathe of peyne ⁊and woo

For who Can be so buxom as a wyf
Whoo is so trewe who is so tentyf
To kepe him seke and hole as is his make
For in wele and in woo she nil hīm not forsake
She nys not wery him to love ⁊and serve
Thow that he lye bedrede til he sterve
And yit some Clerkꝭes seyne it nis not soo

Whatt force they Theopeharste dothe lye
Ne take no wyf qduod he for husbondrye

A Trew servaunt dothe mor͗e deligence
Thi goode to kepe than dothe thi wyfe
For she wolle Cleyme halfe parte al hir lyf

Afftir þⁱ þⁱ goode and hathe doon many a day

div.l: But Take no kepe of suche vanite
Defy Theopharst and herkenithe me
A wyf is goddis yefte verely
Al oþe͗ere man̉er yeftꝭes herdely e
As londes Rentꝭes pasturis ⁊and Comovne ¶/
Or oþe͗er yeftis meuable of Fortune
That passyn as a shadow on a walle
But drede not yf I pleynly spekyng shalle /
A wyf wolle laste ⁊and in thin hovse endure
Wel leng than the lyst ꝑparaventure
Mariage is a ful grete sacramente
He þat hathe no wyf is but shent
He livithe helples ⁊and is al disolate
I Speke of Folke in seculer͗e astate
And herkyn whi I sey not this for nowte /
The womman is for mannis helpe ewroute /
The hie god when he had Adam maked
And sawe hīm alone bely naked
God of his grete goodnes seide then
Lete vs now make an helpe r helpe helper to this maıı̄un
Like to him selfe and than he made eve
Her͗e may yee see ⁊and her͗e may ye preve

O Flesshe they beıı̄un ⁊and of o Flesshe I ges
Not but on herte in wille ⁊and in distresse
A wyf a Seynte mary benedicite

The blisse that is be twyxe hēm tweye
Ther may no tonge Telle it or herte thinke
Yf he be por͗e she helpithe hīm to swynke

Do this seithe he al Redy sir seithe she
O blesful ordovr͗e O wedlok pⁱciouse

div.l: And also they be so trewe and eke so wyse

A wyf is keꝑper of thi husbonderys

Cheriche thi wyf or elꝭes thow shalt neủer thee
Husbonde ⁊and wyfe what so men Iape or pley

For whiche this Ianuars of whiche I tolde

And for his frendes on a day he sent

Wᵗith face sad he hathe his tale to hēm tolde
He saide frendes I am hore ⁊and olde
And al moste god wote at my pittꝭes brynke
Oppon my sowle sum what must I thinke
I have my body folely dispendid
I blessid be god it shalle be amendid
For I wolle be incerten a weddid man
And that in al the haste that I Can
Vn to sum mayde feir ⁊and tendr of age

But for as muche as yee be mo than I

I wolle no womman of xx wynt̉er of age
It is but ben strawe ⁊and grete forage
And eke thes Olde wedowes god it wote
They con so mekyll Crafte of wades bote
So mekyll harme whan þᵗat hem liste
That wᵗith hem shulde I neủer leve in Reste /
For sondry skolis makithe subtile clerkꝭes ¶
Womman of mony a scole halfe a clerke is

rdg.seg: I wol no old wif haue for þis cause

div.l: For yf so wer þᵗat I had so myschaunce
That I in her cowd have no plesaunce
Þan shulde I lede my lyf in avovtrye
And so sterte to the devil when y dye
Ne children shulde I non on hir getyn
Yit had I leủer houndis had me etyn
Than that myn heritage shulde falle
In straunge honde ⁊and þus I telle yow alle
I doute not I wot the Cause why
Men shulde wed and forthermor wot I
There spekithe meny men of mariage
That wot nomor of it than wot my page
For whiche Causis men shulde take a wyf
Yf he may not Chaste be by his lyfe
Take hīm a wyf wᵗith grete devociou
Be cause of lefal procreaciou
Of Childerin to þe honoᵘur of god above
And not Only for ꝑparamour ne for love
And for they shulde lechery eschewe
And yelde hir dete while it is new .
Or for that Eche man shulde helpe oþe
In myschef as a sustr shulde helpe þe broþe
And levin in Chastite ful hevynly
But sirs be yoᵘur leve þat am nat I
For god be thankid I dare make avaunte
I fele my linys sterke ⁊and sufficiaunt

div.l: Thow I be hor y xx fare xx as dothe a tree

Myn herte ⁊and my lymes as grene

Diủerse men Diủersely hīm tolde

To weyve fro the worde of Salamon

Werke al thing be Counseil thus seide he
And than shalt þow nat Repente þee
But þat Salamon spak suche a worde
Myn owne der broþe and my lorde
So wisly god my soule bryng at Reste
I holde yowr owne Counseil for the beste
For broþe myn of me take this motyffe
I have be a courtman al my lyve
And yit god wote they I vnworthi I be
I have stonde in ful grete degree

Yitte had I neủer wᵗith non of hēm Debate /
I neủer hem Contrarijd trewly
I wot welle that þei can mor than I

So hihe sentense so holy ⁊and so welle

Crist holdithe hi of this ful wel apayde
And trewly it is a hie Corage /
Of ony man that steppid is in age
To take a yonge wyf for be my fadr kyn

Dothe nowe in this mat̉er as yee lyste

Iustinia þat ay sat ful stille ⁊and herde
HE Right on this wyse to placebo saide

Wᵗith ony yf so were she had
Moo goode thewes than hir visis bad
And all this axithe leysours to enquer
For god It wote I have wepte ful meny ater
Ful priveli sithe I had a wyfe

Certen I fynde it but Coste and Care

But I wot beste wher wryngithe me my sho
Yee may for me right as yee like do

How that yee entren in to mariage
And namly wᵗith a yonge wyf ⁊and a feir
Be him that made wat̉er erþe ⁊and heyr

This is to seye for to do hir plesaunce

I pray yow ȝe be not evil apayde
Wel qd this Ianuari hast thow saide
Straw for thi senek ⁊and for thi ꝓproverbes

div.l: I sey it is acursid man qd he

And wᵗith that worde þei Risen sodenly
And ben assentid sodenly þat he shuld
Be bedded when hīm lyste ⁊and when he wolde
þe fantesy ⁊and the besy coryousnes
Fro day to day can in his soule impres
Of Ianuary about his mariage
Many feyr shap ⁊and meny feyr vysage
Þe passithe thorowe his hert nyght be nyght
As who so toke a mirowr pulshid bryght
And set is in a Comon market place
Þan shulde ye see many a figure passe
By this myrroᵘur and in the same wyse ¶
Can Ianuary in his thought Devise
Of maydenis whiche dwellid be side
He wyst not wher he myght abyde
For thowhe that on hathe bewte in his face
Anoþe stont so on the peples grace
For hir sadnesse ⁊and hir benygnitee

And som wer Riche and had bad name
But natheles be twixte ernist ⁊and game
He at the laste poyntid hīm on one
And lete his herte from al oþe goon

For love is blynde alday and may not see
And when he was in his bed browte
He purtreyd on his herte ⁊and in his thovght
Her freshe bevte and hir age tendr
Hir medil smal ⁊and hir armes long ⁊and sklend

Her womanly beryng ⁊and hir sadnesse
And when he was from hir cōndiscendit
Him thought his thought myght not be amendid
For when he him selve concludid had
Him thought eu þe mennys wyttꝭes so badde
Þat Impossible it wer to Replie
Ayenste his Choyse þis was his fantesey
His frendꝭes sent he to at his Instaunce /
And prayde hem to do hīm that plesaunce
Þat hastely to hem thei wolde come
He wolde a brygge al hir laboᵘur⁊and al hir sin
Nedithe for him nomor go nor Ride
He was apoynted þe he wolde abyde
Placebo Com ⁊and eke his frendis sone
And alþerfirst he bad hem alle a bone /
Þat noon of hem non argumentꝭes shulde make
A yenste þe purpose whiche he had take
Whiche was plesaunt to god seyde he
And werrey grounde of his prosꝑperite
He seyde þe / was a maydyn inthe towne
Whiche þᵗat of bevte had grete Renovne
Al wer it so Sche was of smal degr
Suffisethe hīm hir thoughtyowth⁊and hir bevte
Whiche mayde he sayde shulde be his wyf
To lede in ese ⁊and holynesse his lyfe
And thankid god that he myght have hir al
Þat no wyght wᵗith his blisse parten shalle
And preyde hēm to laboᵘur in this nede
And shape that he faylid not to spede

Þan is no thing qd he þᵗat may me displese

The whiche I wolle Reherce in yoᵘur psence /¶
Ye have harde sey full yor a goo .
Þer may noman have ꝑperfite blisse too

For they he kepte hīm From the synnes vij .
And eke from eủeryche braunche of þᵗat tree
Yit is þe so ꝑperfite prosꝑperite
And so grete Ease ⁊and luste in mariage
Þat eủer I am a gaste now in myn age
Þat I shal lede so mery a life now her
For sithe that verrey hevin is boute so der
Wᵗith tribulaciou ⁊and gret penaunce /
How shulde I leve in suche plesance
As al weddid men do wᵗith þe wyfes
Come to the blis þer Crist etern on live is
This is my drede as yit my bretherin twey
Assoylithe me this questiou y yowe pray
Iustinus whiche that hathe t his foly
Aunswerynge anon Right in his Iapery
And for he wolde his longe tale a brigge

div.l: (base) In diuers art and in diuerse figures

div.l: (base) A Markys whilom lord was of that lond
(base) As were his worthy eldres hym bifore
(base) And obeysant ay redy to his hond
(base) Were alle his liges bothe lasse and moore
(base) Thus in delit he lyueth and hath doon yoore
(base) Biloued and drad thurgh fauour of Fortune
(base) Bothe of his lordes and of his commune
(base) Ther with he was to speke as of lynage
(base) The gentileste yborn of Lumbardye
(base) A fair persone and strong and yong of age
(base) And ful of honour and of curteisye
(base) Discret ynogh his contree for to gye
(base) Saue in some thynges that he was to blame
(base) And Walter was this yonge lordes name

(base) In tyme comynge what myghte hym bityde
(base) But on his lust persent was al his thoght

(base) Or ellis that the lord best wolde assente

(base) He to the Markys seyde as ye shal heere
(base) O noble Markys your humanitee
(base) Assureth vs and yeueth vs hardynesse
(base) As ofte as tyme is of necessitee
(base) That we to yow mowe telle oure heuynesse
(base) Accepteth lord now of your gentillesse
(base) That we with pitous herte vn to yow pleyne
(base) And lat youre erys noght my voys disdeyne
(base) Al haue I noght to doone in this matere
(base) Moore than another man hath in this place
(base) Yet for as muche as ye my lord so deere
(base) Han alwey shewed me fauour and grace
(base) I dar the bettre aske of yow a space
(base) Of audience to shewen oure requeste
(base) And ye my lord to doon right as yow leste
(base) For certes lord so wel vs liketh yow
(base) And al youre werk and euere han doon that we
(base) Ne kouden nat vs self deuysen how
(base) We myghte lyuen in moore felicitee
(base) Saue o thyng lord if it your wille be
(base) That for to been a wedded man yow leste
(base) Thanne were your peple in souereyn hertes reste
(base) Boweth your nekke vnder that blisful yok
(base) Of souereyntee noght of seruyse
(base) Which that men clepe spousaille or wedlok
(base) And thenketh lord among your thoghtes wyse
(base) How that oure dayes passe in sondry wyse
(base) That of wedlok comes grete Emprice
(base) For thogh we slepe or wake or renne or ryde
(base) Ay fleeth the tyme it nel no man abyde
(base) And thogh youre grene youthe floure as yit
(base) In crepeth age alwey as stille as stoon
(base) And deth manaceth euery age and smyt
(base) In ech estat for ther escapeth noon
(base) And also certeyn as we knowe echon
(base) That we shal dye as vncerteyn we alle
(base) Been of that day whan deth shal on vs falle
(base) Accepteth thanne of vs the trewe entente
(base) That neuere yet refuseden thyn heste
(base) And we wol lord if that ye wol assente
(base) Chese yow a wyf in short tyme at the leeste
(base) Born of the gentileste and of the meeste
(base) Of al this lond so that it oghte seme
(base) Honour to god and yow as we kan deme
(base) Delyuere vs out of al this bisy drede
(base) And tak a wyf for heighe goddes sake
(base) For if so bifelle as god forbede
(base) That thurgh youre deeth youre ligne sholde slake
(base) And that a straunge Successour sholde take
(base) Youre heritage o wo were vs alyue
(base) Wher fore we pray yow hastily to wyue
(base) Hir meke prayere and hir pitous cheere
(base) Made the Markys herte han pitee
(base) Ye wol quod he myn owene peple deere
(base) To that I neuere erst thoghte streyne me
(base) I me reioysed of my libertee
(base) That selde tyme is founde in mariage
(base) Ther I was free I moot ben in seruage
(base) But nathelees I se your trewe entente
(base) And truste vp on youre wit and haue doon ay
(base) And truste vp on you and
(base) Wher fore of my free wyl I wol assente
(base) Wherfor of my fre wille I assente
(base) To wedde me as soone as euere I may
(base) But ther as ye han profred me to day
(base) To chese me a wyf I yow relesse
(base) That choys and pray yow of that profre cesse
(base) For god it woot that children ofte ben
(base) Vnlyk hir worthy eldres hem bifore
(base) Bountee comth al of god nat of the stren
(base) Of which they been engendred and ybore
(base) I triste in goddes bountee and therfore
(base) I truste in god and euer haue do by fore
(base) My mariage and myn estat and reste
(base) I hym bitake he may doon as hym leste
(base) Lat me allone in chesyng of my wyf
(base) That charge vp on my bak I wol endure
(base) But I pray yow and charge vp on your lyf
(base) That what wyf that I take ye me assure
(base) To worshipe hire whil that hir lyf may dure
(base) In word and werk bothe here and euerywhere
(base) As she an Emperours doghter were
(base) And ferther moore this shal ye swere that ye
(base) Agayn my choys shal neither grucche ne stryue

(base) At your requeste as euere mote I thryue
(base) Ther as myn herte is set ther wol I wyue
(base) And but ye wol assente in swich manere
I pray yow spekithe no more of this mat̉ere
Wᵗith hert chere þei swore and assentyn
Tyl al this thing þ̉er seide no wyȝte nay
Be seching him or thei wentyn
Þat he wolde graunt hem o certeyn day
Of his spousale as sone as eủere he may
For yit al wey the peple dredde
Lest that marcus wolde no wyf wedde
He grauntid hem a day suche as hym list
On whiche he wolde be weddid sekirly
And saide he dide all this at hir request
And they wᵗith humble entente buxomly
Knelynge on hir knees ful reuerently
Hym thanken alle and thus they have an ende
Of hir entente home a yane þei wende
And here vp on he to his officers
And here vppon he toke his officers
And comaundeth for the feste to pᵘurueye
And to his pryuee knyghtes ⁊and Squyers
Swich charge he yaf as hym list on he leye
And thei to his comandement obey
And eche of hem dooth alle his diligence
To dōnn to that feste hye reuerence
¶Nowte fer fro þᵗat paleys honurable
Þ̉er as this Markes shope his mariage
I stode a thrope of syte ful delitable
In which that poure folke of that village
Hadden hir bestes and hir herbergage
And of hir laboure toke hir sustenance
After that the erthe yaf them ahabundance
A mong this pore folke þ̉er dwelte a man
Which that was holde pourest of hem alle
But hihe god som tyme sende kanne
His grace in to a litel Oxes Stalle
Ianicula men of that þroop hym call
A doght̉er he had fair͗e y nogh to syȝt
And Grisildis this yonge mayden hyȝt
For to speke of vertuous ⁊and of honor beaute
Than was she ōnn the faireste vnder the sōnn
And ful pourely y fostorde vp was she
No likerous lust was þronȝe hire hert I rōnn
Wel ofter of the welle thanne of the wyne tōnnn
She dronke and for she wolde vertu plese
She knew wel laboure and nōnn ydelese
But thoghe this mayde so tendre wer͗e of age
Yette in the brest of hir virginitee
Ther was I enclosed rype and sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charitee
Hir͗e olde poure fader fostred she
A fewe shepe spynnynge on felde she kepte
She wolde not ben ydel til she slepte
And whanne she homeward came she wolde bryng͗e
Wortes and oþ̉ere herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she seeythe for his lyuynge
And made hir bed harde ⁊and no thyng softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lyf ōnn loft
With eủery obeysance and diligence
Þat chylde myght done to the fadres reuerence
Vpon Grisilde this pore creature
Ful ofte this Markes sette his eye
As he rode on huntyng ꝑperauenture
And whan it be fille he myghte hir e spie
He noght withe wantōnn loke of folye
Hise yen cast hir on but in sad wyse
Vpon hir cher͗e he wolde hym ofte auyse
Commendynge in his herte hir͗e womānhede
And eke hir vertu passyng any wyght
Of so yong age as wel in cher͗e as dede
For thowhe the peple had no grete insyȝht
He considered in vertue ful ryȝt
Hir bounte and disposed that he wolde
Wed hir only yf he eủere wedde wolde
Þe day of weddyng came but no wyȝt can
Tel what wom̄an it sholde be
For which merueyle wondred many a mān
And seide whan thei were in pⁱriuetee
Wol oure lord leue yett ni vantee
Wolle he nat wedde alas the while
Whi wolle he hym self and vs bigyle
But nathelees this Markes had dōnn make
Of gemmes sette in golde and in Asure
Broches and rynges for Grisildis sake
And of hir clothyng tokr mesure
Of a mayde like to hir stature
And eke of hir the ournementes alle
That to swiche a weddyng sholde falle
The tyme of vndrōnn of the same day
Approcheth that this weddyng shulde be
And alle the pales put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degree
Houses of office stuffed wᵗith grete plentee
Ther mayst thow see of deynteuous vitaille
Þat may be founde as fer as last the Ytaille
This Roial Markes richely arrayed
Lordes and ladys in his compaigny
Þ͗e whiche that to the fest was prayd
And of his retenue the Bachilrye
Wᵗith many a sown of sondry melodye
Vn to the village the which I tolde
In this aray the ryȝt wey thei holde
Grisilde of this god wote ful Innocent
That for hir shapen was al this aray
To fecchyn wat̉er at the welle is she went
And comythe home as sone as eủer she may
For wel she hadde herd \sey/ that ilke day
Þat Markes sholde wedde if she myght
She wolde fayne a sey som of that syȝht
She thoghte she wolde wᵗith oþ̉er e maydens stonde
That ben my felawes in our͗e dor͗e ⁊and see
Þe Markese and þ̉erfor͗e wol I fonde
To done at hom as sone as it may b
The laboure whiche that longithe to me
And thanne I may at leysonne ther be holde
Yf she this wey vnto the castell holde
And as she wolde on the threshewolde gon
The markes came and ganne hir for to calle
And she sette downe hir wat̉er ryȝt A non
Be syde the threshewolde in an oxes Stalle
And downe vp on hir knees she ganne to falle
And wᵗith sad conntenaunce she knelid stille
Tille she had hard what was the lordes wille
Þis thoughtful Markes spake vn to that ma\y/de
Ful sobirly and seide in this man̉er
Wher is yoᵘur fadir o gresyd he saide
And sche wᵗith reuerens and humble cher͗e
Answerd lorde he is al redye her͗e
And in sche gothe wᵗith oute eny leng̉er let
And to markes sche hir fadir fette
He by the honde than toke this olde man
And sayde thus when he hadde hi asyde
Ianicula I ne may ner can
Þe plesaunce of myn herte hyde
That thow wouchesaff what so be tyde
Þi dout̉er wolle I take or that I wende
As to my wyf to hir lyfes ende
Thow louist me I wot it wel c̉erteyne
And erte my feythefulle legeman y born
In all that likethe me I dare wele seyn
It likethe me and specially þ̉erfor͗e
Tel me that poynt that I seyde befor͗e
And yf thow wolt vn to that purpose drawe
To take me as for thi son in lawe
This sodeyne case ys man was stōnned so
That rede he wexte A basshid and all quakyng
He stode vnnethe seyde he wordes mo
But only quod he this lorde my willinge
Is as ye wolle not A geyne yoᵘur likynge
I wole no thinge ye be my lorde so dere
Ryght as yow list goủernithe this mat̉ere
Yit wol I quod this Markes softelye
Þat in thi chambr͗e I mid þᵘ ⁊and sche
Haue A collacion and wotist þᵘ whi
For I wol axe hir yf it be hir wille
To bey my wyf ⁊and rule hir aft̉er me
And alle this shalle be don in þ̉er p̉ersence
I uyl not speke oute of þ̉er audience
And in the chammbr͗e while þei wer͗e aboute
Her͗e tretys whiche ye shulle as aftir here
The peple come in to the house al wᵗith oute
And wonderid hem in howe honest man̉er
As she tentyfly kepte hir fadir der͗e
But witt̉rely gresild wondre myȝte
For neủer erst saw sche suche A syȝte
No wondir it was thowhe sche wer͗e A stonyed
To se so grete a gest come in that place
Sche was neu͗e to suche geste I wonned
For whiche sche loked wᵗith ful pale face
But schortly this mat̉er for to chase
Thes ben the wordes that the markes seide
To this verry venyngne feythefulle maide
Gresylde he saide ye shulle wol vnderstonde
It likethe un to yeure fadir ⁊and to me
That I yow wedde and eke it may so stonde
As I supose that ye wolle it so be
But thes demanndes ax I furst ꝙquod he
That sithe it shalle be don in hasty wyse
Wolle yow assent or yow a vise
I sey thus be ye redy wᵗith gode hert
To alle my lust and that I frely may
As me best thinkithe thowhe ye lawhe or smerte
And ye neủer to gruche nyȝt nor day
When that I sey ye that ye sey not naye
Neyþ̉er by worde nor be frownyng conntenᵃaunce
Swer͗e this and her͗e I yow ensuve alliaunce
Wonderyng vpon thes wordes wond̉erly for drede
Sche seide lorde vndigne and laworthi
I am to suche honoᵘur as ye bede
But as ye wolle yoᵘur selfe so wolle I
And her͗e I swer͗e that neủer willyng
In werke or thowe I yow disobeye
For to be dede thow me wer͗e loth to dye
Þis is in yow gresilde myn ꝙquod he
And forthe he gothe wᵗith A ful sobre cher͗e
Owte at the dor͗e and Aftir come sche
And to the peple thus seyde he in this man̉er
This is my wyf that stondithe her͗e
Honoure hir ⁊and lovithe hir I yow pray
Who so lovithe me þ̉er is nomor͗e to sey
And for no thyng of hir olde gere
Sche schulde brynge into his howse he had
Þat women shulde dispoylin hir þ̉er
Of whiche thes ladies wer͗e nat ful gladde
To handil hir clothis wher͗e in sche was cladde
But netheles this mayden bryte of hewe
From fote to hede thei clothid hu newe
Her heris thei kempte that lay vntrussed
Ful redely wᵗith hir fyng̉rees smale
A croune on hir hede thei haue y dressid
And set hir ful owches grete ⁊and smale
Of hir aray what shulde I make A tale
Vnnethe the peple hir knew for hir feirenesse
Whanne she translated was in suche richesse
Þis Markes hathe hir spousid withe A rynge
But for the same cause And thanne he satte
Vpon An hors snowe white wel Ammbelyng
And to his palys or he leng̉er latt
Wᵗith ioyfull peple that hir ladde ⁊and mett
Conveyde hir and thus the day þei spent
In ravel til the son gan discende
And schortly forthe this tale for to chas
I sey that to this new markesesse
God hathe hir suche favoure sent of his grace /
That it ne semithe by no likenes
That she was borne and fedde ni rudenes
As in A citee or in An Oxis stalle
But norischid in An Emꝑperours halle
To eủery wyte woxen is sche so der͗e
And worschipfulle þᵗat folke wher͗e sche was bor͗e
And from hir burthe knewe hir yer͗e by yer͗e
Vnnethe trowed thei but durst have swore
That to Ianicula of whiche I spake be for͗e
Sche douȝter As by Comecture
Hem thowte sche was A noþ̉er creatoᵘur
For that eủer wertuous was sche
Sche was encresid ni suche exellence
Of thewes gode I sette in grete bounte
And so discete and faire of eloquence
So benyngne and digne of reverence
And coude the peplus hertꝭes so enbrace
Þat eche hir lovid that loke on hir face
Nat only of Saluces in the towne
Puplischid was the bowte of hir name
And eke be syde in mony A regioun
Yf one seyde welle anoþ̉er seyde þᵉ same
So spredde of hir bevte the name
Þat men and women bothe yonge ⁊and olde
Goithe to Saluces hir to be holde
Þis Walt̉er rewly but nat but riall
Weddid wᵗith fortunate honest
In goddes pese lyveth ful honestlye
At home and outward grace I now herd he
And for he sauȝe that vndur lowe degre
Was oft vertu hid þe pepul him be held
A prudent man and that is seen ful selde
Ne only this gresylde thorow hir witte
Coude Alle the fete of wyfly humblenes
But yit when the Cas requirid it
The comyn profite / coude she redres
Þer nas rancoure discorde ne hevines
In al the londe that sche A pase
And wysely brynge hem in rest ⁊and ese /
Þow hir husbonde wer͗e Absent or none /
Yf gentilmen or oþ̉er of þᵗat cuntree
Wer͗e wrothe sche wolde brynge hem at one /
So wyse and rype wordes had sche
And ni Iugement so grete equite /
Þat sche from hevene was sent as men wende /
To save peple and eủery wronge Amende
Nat longe tyme Aftir that this gresilde
Was I wedded she A dowt̉er had I borne
Al had hir lever A borne A knave childe
Glad was the Markes And þᵉ folke þ̉erfor͗e
For thow A maide childe Come Albefor͗e
Sche may vn to A knave chylde atteyne
By lyklynes sithe sche is not bareyn
Ther fil as it befallithe tymes mo
Whenne that þis childe had soken but a throw
This markꝭes in herte he throwte so
To tempt his wyf hir sadnes to know
Þat he ne myȝt oute of his hert I trowe
This merveilous desire his wyf to assey
Nedeles god wote he thowte hir to assey
He had assayde hir ofte tyme before
And fonde her evir gode what nedithe it
Here for to tempe and alle wey more ⁊and mor͗e
Þouȝe some men preise it for A sotil wit
But as for me I sey that ful will it sitt
To assey A wyve when that it is no nede
And put hir in Angwishe and drede
For whiche þes markes wroute in þⁱˢ man̉er
Ye came a bove a nyȝt þ̉er as sche lay
Wᵗith sterne face and vgglye wᵗith cher͗e
And seide thus Gresild quod he that day
Þat day that I yow toke from yoᵘur pore array
And put yow in A state of hye nobles
Ye have not that for geten as I ges
I sey Gresyld þe p̉resent dignite
In whiche I have put yow as I trowe
Makethe yow not foryeteful for to be
Þat I yow toke in youre astate ful lowe
For onus wel ye must yoᵘur selve knowe
Take hede of eủery worde þat I sey
Þer is no wyght þat herith but we twey
Ye wote yoᵘur selve how that he Came here
In to this house that is not longe A goo
And þouȝe ye to me be bothe lef and dere
Vnto my gentiles ye be not so
Þei sey to hem it is grete schame ⁊and woo
For to ben subiectꝭes And in sarvage
To the that borne art in A smal vilage
And namlie sithe thi dowt̉er was borne
Thes wordes han thei spoken dowtles
But I desire as I have done be fore
To lyve my lyf in rest ⁊and pes
I may not in this Cas be recheles
I mot done wᵗith thi dowt̉er for þᵉ best
Not as I wolde but as my peple lust
And yit god wote this is ful lothe to me
But netheles with oute youre wetynge

Goithe forthe A non wᵗith Dorengen he seyde
And bryngithe her to suche A plase A non
Thei token hir leve ⁊and on hir wey they gon
But thei ne wyst why sche thedir went
He wolde no wyȝte tel his entente
Þis squier͗e whiche hyȝt Aurelius
On Dorengen that was so Amerowse
Of Aventure happid to mete
A myd the toun in the quicest strete
As sche was boun to go the wey furthe ryȝt
Toward the gardyn þ̉er as sche was hyȝt
And he was in to the gardyn Also
For wel he spied when sche wolde goo
Oute of hir house to ony man̉er place /
But thus thei mettyn by Aventure ⁊and grace /
And he saluethe hir wᵗith glad entente
And axed hir wheþ̉erward sche went
And sche Answerd halfe as sche wer͗e mad
Vn to the gardyn as my husbond bad
My trouthe for to holde Alas Alas
Aurelius gan wondir ni this cas
And in his hert had grete cōmpassion
Of hir cher͗e ⁊and of hir lamentacion
And of erveragus þe worthi knyȝt
That bad hir holde that sche had be hyȝt
So lothe him was þᵗat his wyf schulde breke hir trouthe
And in his hert he cauȝt of this grete routhe
Considering the best on eủery syde
Þat from that lust wer͗e hi lev̉er Abide /
Þan to do so hyȝe A foly wrechidnes
A geyne frannchesye ⁊and gentilnes
For whiche in few wordes seyde he þus
Madame sey to yoᵘur lorde erveragus
Þat sithe I se yoᵘur grete gentilnes
To yow and eke I se yoᵘur distresse /
Þat him wel lever have A schame ⁊and þᵗat wer͗e rowthe /
Þan ye to me thus schulde breke yoᵘur trowth
I have wel leủer eủer to suffre wo
Þan I departe þe love be twyx yow two
I you relese madame into youre honde
Quite every survient ⁊and eủery bonde
Þat ye haue made / to me as eủer her͗e be forne /
Sithe that tyme that ye were borne
My trovthe I plyte I schalle yow neủer rep̉reve
Of non behest her͗e I take my leve
As of the truest ⁊and best wyf
Þan eủer yitt I knew ni All my lyf
But eủery wyf be ware of hir behest
O Deregen I remembre at the lest
Þat Can a Squier͗e do A gentil dede
As welle as can A knyȝt wᵗith out drede
Sche thankd him vpon hir knees bare /
And home vnto hir husbonde is sche fare /
And tolde him al as ye have herd ben seyd
And be ye sekir þᵗat he was wel A payde /
Þat I wer͗e impossible me to wryte
What schuld I lengur of this cas indyte
Arveragus ⁊and dorengen his wyf
In soủereyne blisse leden forthe hir lyf
Nevir Aftir was ang̉re hem be twene
He cherischith her as sche wer͗e A quene /
And sche was trew to him for eủermor͗e
Of thes to folke ye gete of me nomor͗e
Aurelius that his Cost hathe Al forlorne
Cursithe the tyme that he was borne
Alas Alas quod he that I be hyȝt
Of purid golde A thousand pounde weyȝt
Vn to this philesopher how shalle I do
I se no mor͗e but that I Am for do
My heritage I must nedes selle
And be A begg̉er her͗e may I not dwelle
And schamen al my kynrede in this place
But I of him may gete sum grace /
But netheles I wolle of him Assay
At Certeyne yeerꝭes and dayes to pay
And thanke him of his grete curtesye /
My trowthe wolle I kepe I wolle not lye /
Wᵗith herte sor͗e he gothe vn to his cofre
And browte golde vnto this philosofer
Þe valowe of .V. hunderid pounde I ges
And him be sought of his gentilnes
To graunt him dayes of the remnaunt
And saide mast̉er I der͗e wel make A vaunt
I faylid neủer of my trouthe as yit
For sekrly my dette schalle be quitte
Toward yow how eủer that I fare
To go A beggyng ni my kirtil bare
But ye wolde vouchesaff on suerte
Two yeer͗e or thre to respite me
Thanne wer͗e I wel for ellꝭes mot I selle
Myn heritage þ̉er is no more to telle
This philosophir sobirly Annswerd
And seide thus when he thes wordes hard /
Have I not holde covenaunt vn to the /
Þis Certis wel and trewly ꝙquod he
Hast thow nat had thi lady as þᵒᵘ liketh
No no ꝙquod he and sorowfully sikethe
What was the cause tel me yf þᵒᵘ can
Aurelius his tale he be ganne
And tolde him Al as he hathe harde befor͗e
It nedithe nat to reherse it yow nomor͗e
He saide Arveragus of his gentilnes
Had leủer to dye in sorow ⁊and destresse
Than that his wyf wer͗e of hir trowthe fals
Þe sorow of Dorengen he tolde him Als
How lothe hir wer͗e to be A wickid wyf
And that sche had leủer A lost hir lyf
And that hir trouȝthe sche swor͗e thorow hir Innocence
Sche neủer erst had hard of A parence
That made me to have in hir so grete pite /
And right as frely as he sent hir to me
As frely sent I hir home Ayene
This al and sum þ̉ere is nomor͗e to seyne
This philosopher Aunswerd leve broþ̉er
Eủerche of yow did gentilnes to oþ̉ere
Thow art A Squier͗e ⁊and he is A knyȝt
But god forde for his blesfull myȝt
But A Clerke coude do as gentil a dede
As wel as eny of yow it is no drede
Sir I relese thi thousand pounde
As ryght now thow wer͗e copyn oute of the grounde /
Ne neủer or now thow hadest knowen me
For sir I wolle not take id of the
For alle my Crafte ne for Al my travayle
Thow hast wel pend for my vitaile
It is I nowe fare wel ⁊and have gode day
And toke his hors ⁊and forthe he gothe his wey
Lordyngꝭes this question than Axe I yow
Whiche was the most fre as thinkithe yow /
Now tellithe me er ye furþ̉er wende /
I can ne mor͗e my tale is at an ende
And Here Endithe the Frankeleyn his tale /
And here begynnythe þe Secound Nonne Ꝓprolog
The ministre͗e and noryce / to vices
Whiche that men clepe in englisshe idelnes
Whiche that pot̉er of the yatꝭes is of delytes
To eschewen and by hir contrary to oppres
Þat is to sey by leful besynes
Wel oute we to done \al/ oure entente
Les þat the fend þrouȝe idelnes vs hent
For he wᵗith his thousand Cordes sleygh
Continuily vs waytithe to be clappe
Whenne he may man in ydilnesse Aspye
And can lyȝtly chasm hem in his trappe
Til that A man be hente ryȝt be the lappe
He nys not wher the fende hathe him in honde /
Wel ouȝt vs worthe ⁊and idelnes wᵗithstonde
And thowhe men dredin neủer for to dye
Þit se men be reson doutles
Þat idelnes is hoten slogardy
Of whiche þ̉ere comithe neủer gode encrese
And sene that slowthe his holdithe in A lese /
Only for to slepe ⁊and ete ⁊and drynke
And devouren al that oþ̉er swynke
And to put vs from suche idelnes
Þat Cause is of so grete confusion
I have her͗e done my feythefull besynes
Aftir the legent ni translacion
Ryght of thi gloriens lyf ⁊and passioun
Þow wᵗith thi garlound wrouȝt of rose ⁊and lile
Þe mene I ma\i/de And martir seint cecely
And thow that flour͗e ert of virgins alle
Of whom that barnard lyst so welle to write /
To the at my fyrst begynnyng I calle
Þow Comfort of vs wrechis do me endite
Þi maydens dethe þat whenne þrouȝe her meryte /
The eterne lyf thow graunt ⁊and of þe fende victory
As men now Aftir rede ni hir story
Þow maide ⁊and mod̉er Douȝter of thi son
Þow welle of m̉ercy synfull soulis to cure /
In whom þᵗat god for bounte ches to woun
Þow humble ⁊and hye A fore eủery Creature
Þow noblest so ferforthe our nature /
Þat no dysdeyne the make had of kynde /
Þi son in blode and fleshe to clothe ⁊and wynde /
Wᵗith in the Cloist̉re blisful of þⁱ entresse /
Toke manis schappe eternal love ⁊and pes
Þat of the tryne Compas lord ⁊and gyde is
Whom hevene ⁊and erthe ⁊and see owȝe to relese
Ay heryen ⁊and þ̉er virgine
Bare of thi body and dweltest may pure
Þe Creatoure of eủery Creature
Assemblid is in the magnificens
Withe m̉ercy godenesse ⁊and sothe pite
Þat thow that erte the sonne of excellence
Nat only helpest hem þat prayn the
But often tyme of thi benyngnite /
Ful frely or that men thin helpe be seche /
Þow gost be forne ⁊and art oure soules leche
Now helpe thow blesfull ⁊and faire mayde
Me flemed wrecche in þes desert of gāll
Þink on the woman Canane þᵗat seyde
Þat whelpes eten som of þe crounes alle
Þat from hir lordes table ben I falle
And thow that I vnworthi son of eve
Be synfulle yitt accepte my be leve /
And for that forthe is dede wᵗith outen werkes
So for to werchen yeve me witte ⁊and space
Þat I be quite from thens þ̉er most werke is
O thow that ert so faire ⁊and ful of grace
Be myn ad vocate in that hie place
Þer as wᵗith outen ende / is songe Oȝanna
Þow Cristꝭes modir dowt̉er der͗e of Anne
And for thi lyȝt my soule in sosone lythe
That troubelid as by þe cogitacioune /
Of my body / And Also by þe weyght
Of erthely lust and fals effeccioun
O haven of refute / O salvacioun
Of hem that ben in sorow ⁊and in distresse
Now helpe for to do my werke I wolle me dres
Yit I pray yow that redyn that I wryte
For yeve me that I do no deligens
Þis ilke story befely to endite
For bothe have I þe wordes and þe centence
Of him þᵗat at the seintꝭes reverence
Þe story wrote and folowen hir legent
Word by worde ryȝt as the wryter ment
First wolde I þe name of seint cecely
Expoun as men may in hir story se
It is to sey ni Englische hevenes lely
For pure chastyfnes of virginite
Or for sche wytnes had of honeste
And grene of consciens ⁊and of gode fame
Þe swot savour͗e lily was hir name
Or cecely is to sey þe wey to blynde
For sche ensample was by gode teching
Or elis seceley as I wretyn fynde
Is ioyned by A maner convynyng
Of heven and lia ⁊and hir in figuryng
Þe heven is get for thouȝt of holynes
And lia for hir lastyng besynes
Cecilia may eke be seyde in this man̉er
Wayting of blyndnes for hir grete lyȝt
Of sapiens ⁊and of hir thewis clere
Or els this maydenes name bryȝt
Of heven and loose comythe for which berth
Men myȝt her wille þe heuene of peple calle
Ensample of gode And wise werkes wᵗith alle
For leos pepul in englisch is for to sey
And ryȝt as men may in the hevene see
Þe sonne and mone and sterris eủery wey
Right so gostly men in this maiden fro
Seyn of feithe \þis/ grete magnanimite
And eke the Clernes hole of sapience
And sondry workes bryght of excellence /
As ryght so thes Philesophers wryte
Þat heve is swyfte ⁊and rounde ⁊and eke brynnyng
Ryght so was feire Ceceley þe whyte
Ful swyft and besy eủer in gode workyng
And rounde ⁊and hole in gode perseuerynge /
And brynnyng eủer in charite ful bryȝte /
Now have I declared yow what sche hyȝt
This made bryȝt Cecelye as hir lyf seithe
Was comme of Romāns ⁊and of noble kynde
And from hir Cradell vp fosterde in þe feithe
Of cryst ⁊and bare his Gospel in hir mynde
Sche neủer sesyd as I wreten fynde
Of hir prayer͗e ⁊and god to love ⁊and drede
Be sechyng him to kepe hir maydynhede /
And when this mayden schulde vn to A man
I weddid be that was ful yonge of Age
Whiche that I Clepid was Valerian
And day was Comme of hir mariage
Sche ful ⁊and humble in hir corage /
Vnder hir robe of golde that sat ful faire
Had next hir flesche I clade hir in An heyr͗e
And while that the orgons made melodye
To god Above in hir hert thus songe sche
O lord my body ⁊and eke my soule gye
Vnwemyed lest I confoundid be
And for his love oppon the tree
Euery secounde ⁊and thirde day sche fast
Abydnig in hir horysons ful faste
Þe Come ⁊and to bed must sche gone
Wᵗith hir husbonde as it was the man̉er
And privelie sche seyde to hi A non
O swete o welbelouid \spouse/ so der͗e
Þ̉ere is A Counsaill And ye wolle it her͗e
Whiche that ryȝt fayne wolde to yow sey
So that ye swere ye wol it not be wrey
Valerian gan to hir fast swer͗e
Þat for no cause ne thing that myȝt be
He schulde neủer be wryen hir
And thanne at lest to him seyde sche
I have An Aungell whiche that lovithe me
Þat wᵗith grete love wheþ̉er I wake or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
And yf he may felen oute of drede
That ye me touche or love in vilonye
He ryȝt A non wol slee yow wᵗith þe dede
And in yoᵘur thought þus schulle ye dye
And yf ye me ni clenes gy
He wolle yow love as me for yoᵘur clennes
And schew to yow his ioye ⁊and his bryȝtnes
This Valerian corected as god wolde
Answerd a gayn I schul trysten the
Lete me that Aungell se ⁊and him be holde
And yf that it A verry Aungel be
Þanne wolle I done as thow hast praid me
And yf thow love A noþ̉er man for sothe
Right wᵗith this swerde than wolle I sle yow bothe
Cecelie Answerd a non ryȝt in this wyse
Yf that yow list the A non ye schulle the Aungel se
So that yow trow on crist and yow baptise
Goforth to Via apia quod sche
Þat fro this towne stonde but myles thre /
And to the pore folke þat þ̉er dwellyn
Sey hem ryght as I schall yow tellyn
Tel hem þat I Cecely yow to hem sende
To schewen yow þe gode Vrbane þe olde
For secere nedes and for gode entente
And when that ye Seint Vrbane han be holde
Teline him the wordes whiche I to yow tolde
And when he hathe purged yow from synne /
Þan schulde ye se that Aungel or we twynne
This Valerian is to the place gon
And ryȝt as he was tauȝt by his lernyng
He founde this urban A none
A monge the seyntes beryels lokyng
And he A non wᵗith outen tareynge
Did his message and when that he it tolde
Vrban for ioye gan his hondes vp holde
Þe teris from his yen lete he falle
Almyti lord o IħuIhesu Cryst quod h
Swer͗e of Chast conceil hierd of vs al.
Þe frute of that sede of Chastite
Þat þᵒᵘ hast sowe in cecely take to the
Lo loke Ay besy be wᵗith oute gyle
Þin ovne service / þin thralle ceceli
For thilke spouse þᵗat sche but now toke
Ful like A fers lioune sche sendithe hir
As meke as eủer was eny lambe to yowe
And wᵗith that worde Anon þ̉er gan \A/per͗e
And olde man I Clothid in white clothes cler͗e
Þat had A boke wᵗith łlettres of golde in honde
And gan be for͗e Valerian fer to stonde /
Valerian as dede fel doune for drede /
O lord of Al feithe O god god wᵗithouten mo./
O crystendome fadir of Al Also
Abovin Al. and oủer al euery wher͗e
Thes wordes al wᵗith golde wretyn wer͗e
Whanne this was red thus seide this olde man
Levist thow this thing or non sey ye or nay
I leve all this thing ꝙquod Valerian
For sother thing than this I dare welle seye
Vndir heuene no wyȝt thinke may
Þo vaneschid this olde man he ne wist wher͗e
And pope Vrban hym crystend him rȝght þ̉er
Valerian gothe home and fyndethe cecely
Wᵗith in his Chambr͗e wᵗith an Aungel stonde
This Aungel had of roses ⁊and of lile
Crounes two þe whiche he bare on hond
And first to cecile as I vnderstonde
He yafe the ton ⁊and he gan take
Þat oþ̉er to Valerian her make
Withe body clene ⁊and vnwemmed þouȝt
Kepithe ay wel thes crownes ꝙquod he /
From Paradyse to yow he have I browte
Ne neủer mo ne schulle thei roton be
Ne lesen hir swote savoure / trustithe me /
Ne neủer wyȝt schulle se hem wyth yȝe
But he be chast ⁊and hate Vilonye
And þow Valerian for þᵒᵘ so sone
Assentist to goddes counsaill Also /
Sey what þᵒᵘ lyst ⁊and þᵒᵘ schalt have þⁱ bone /
I have a broþ̉er ꝙquod Valerian tho
Þat in this world / I love no man so
I pray yow that my broþ̉er may have gᵃrace /
To know the trowthe as I do in þis place
Þe Aungel seyde god liketh þⁱ request
And bothe wᵗith the palme of Martirdoms
Ye shulle come into his blisfull rest
And wᵗith that worde tiburce his broþ̉er come
And whenne that he the savour͗e vndirnom
Whiche that the roses ⁊and the lilies cast
He spake vn to his broþ̉er on gret hast
And said I wondir this tyme of yeer͗e
Whens that sote sauour͗e comithe so
Of roses ⁊and of lilies that I smel so her͗e
For thowhe I hadde hem in my hondꝭes two
Þe sauoure myȝt in me no depꝑper go
Þat swote smel I ni myn hert fynde /
Hathe Chaunged me al ni an oþ̉er kynde
Valerian saide two crowns have we
Snow white ⁊and rose rede that schunthe cler͗e
Whiche that thin yen han no myte to sey
And as thow smellid thorow my prayer͗e
So schalt thow sen hem lef broþ̉er der͗e
Yf it so be thow wolt wᵗithouten slouthe /
Beleue A ryȝt And knowe verry trouthe
Tiburce Aunswerde seist thow this to me
In sothe or in drem\e/s I harkyn this
In dremes quod Valerian have be /
Vn to this tyme broþ̉er myn I wysse /
But now at erst in trowithe oure dwellyng is
How wistist thow this ꝙquod tiburce in what wyse /
Quod Valerian that schall I devise /
Þe Aungel of god hathe me þe trowþe I taute /
Whiche that thow schalt se yf þᵒᵘ wolt renay
Þe ydoles and be clene and els noȝt
And of the miracle of thes crowns twey
Seint Ambros in his prefase list to sey
Solempuly þis noble doctoure der͗e
Commendith ⁊and seyithe in þis maner͗e
The palme of Martirdom for to receyve
Seint Cecely fulfillid of goddes yifte /
Þe worlde ⁊and eke hir Chamb̉re gan schewyn
Wyttenes tyburces ⁊and cecilies schryfte
The whiche god of his bounte wold schyft
Crounes two of floures swete smellyng
And his Angel the Crounes to hem bryng
The mayde hathe broute hem to his blis A bove
Þe worlde hathe wist that it is worthe certeyn
Devocioune of Chastite wel for to love
Þow scheude him cecile Al opyn ⁊and playne
Þat al idoles is but athing in veyne /
For thei ben dome / and þ̉erto þei ben dose
And Chargid him his idolnes for to leve
Who so trowithe not this A best he is
Quod þo tiburce yf I schall not lye
And sche can kys his brest that hard þis
And was ful glad he coude trowþe Aspie
This day I take the for myn Alye
Seide this blessid fere maiden der͗e
And Aftir that sche saide as ye mow her͗e
Lo ryȝte so as ye love quod sche of crist
Made me thi broþ̉eris wyf ryȝt in þis wyse
A non for myn alye here take I the
Sithe that thow wolt thin idoles despise
Go wᵗith thi broþ̉er now and the baptise
And make the cler͗e that þᵒᵘ may be holde
Þe aungeles face / wᵗith thi broþ̉er of tolde
Tiburce Answerd ⁊and saide broþ̉er der͗e
First tel me wheþ̉er I shall ⁊and to what man
To whom quod he com forth wᵗith ryȝt gode cher͗e
I wolle the lede vn to the pope Vrban
To Vrban broþ̉er myn Valerian
Quod þo tiburce wolt þᵒᵘ me þ̉erdꝭes lede
Me thinkith that it were a wond̉er dede
Ne menest nat Vrban quod he tho
Þat is so ofte dampned to be ded

div.l: (base) Almachius that herde of this doynge
(base) Bad fecchen Cecilie that he myghte hir se
(base) And alderfirst lo this was his axynge
(base) What maner womman artow quod he
(base) I am a gentil womman born quod she
(base) I axe thee quod he thogh it the greue
(base) Of thy religioun and of thy bileue
(base) Ye han bigonne youre question folily
(base) Quod she that wolden two answeres conclude
(base) In o demande ye axed lewedly
(base) Almachie answerde vnto that similitude
(base) Of whennes comth thyn answeryng so rude
(base) Of whennes quod she whan that she was freyned
(base) Of conscience and of good feith vnfeyned
(base) Almachius seyde ne takestow noon hede

(base) Youre myght quod she ful litel is to drede
(base) For euery mortal mannes power nys
(base) But lyk a bladdre ful of wynd ywys
(base) For with a nedles point whan it is blowe

(base) Ful wrongfully bigonne thow quod he
(base) And yet in wrong is al thy perseueraunce
(base) Wostow nat how oure myghty princes free
(base) Han thus comanded and maad ordinaunce
(base) That euery cristen wight shal han penaunce
(base) But if that he his cristendom withseye
(base) And goon al quyt if he wol it reneye
(base) Youre Prynces erren as youre nobleye dooth
(base) Quod tho Cecile and with a wood sentence
(base) Ye make vs gilty and is nat sooth
(base) For ye that knowen wel oure Innocence
(base) For as muche as we doon a reuerence
(base) To crist and for we bere a cristen name
(base) Ye putte on vs a cryme and eek a blame
(base) But we that knowen thilke name so
(base) For vertuous we may it nat withseye
(base) Almache answerde chees oon of thise two
(base) Do sacrifice or cristendom reneye
(base) That thow mowe now escapen by that weye
(base) At which this holy blisful faire mayde
(base) Gan for to laughe and to the Iuge she sayde
(base) O Iuge confus in thy nycetee
(base) Wiltow that I reneye Innocence
(base) To maken me a wikked wight quod she
(base) Lo he dissimuleth heere in audience
(base) He stareth and woodeth in his aduertence
(base) To whom Almachius vnsely wrecche
(base) Ne wostow nat how fer my myght may strecche
(base) Han noght oure myghty princes to me yeuen
(base) Ye bothe power and auctoritee
(base) To maken folk to dyen or to lyuen
(base) Why spekestow so prowdly thanne to me
(base) I speke noght but stedefastly quod she
(base) Nat proudly for I seye as for my syde
(base) We haten dedly thilke vice of pryde
(base) And if thow drede nat a sooth to here
(base) Thanne wol I shewe al openly by right
(base) That thow hast maad a ful greet lesyng here
(base) Thow seist thy princes han thee yeuen myght
(base) Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight
(base) Thow that ne mayst but oonly lyf byreue
(base) Boþe for to sleen and for to quyke a wight
(base) Thow hast noon oother power ne no leue
(base) But thow mayst seyn thy princes han thee maked
(base) Ministre of deeth for if thow speke of me
(base) Thow lyest for thy power is ful naked
(base) Do wey thy boldnesse seyde Almachius tho
(base) And sacrifice to oure goddes er thow go
(base) I recche nat what wrong that thow me profre
(base) For I kan suffre it as a Philosophre
(base) But thilke wronges may I nat endure
(base) That thow spekest of oure goddes here quod he
(base) Cecilie answerde o nyce creature
(base) Thow seydest no word syn thow spak to me
(base) That I ne knew therwith thy nycetee
(base) And that thow were in euery maner wise
(base) A lewed Officer a veyn Iustise
(base) Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter eyen
(base) That thow nart blynd for thyng that we seen alle
(base) That is a stoon that men may wel espien
(base) That ilke stoon a god thow wolt it calle
(base) I rede thee lat thyn hand vpon it falle
(base) And taste it wel and stoon thow shalt it fynde
(base) Syn that thow seest nat with thyne eyen blynde
(base) It is a shame that the peple shal
(base) So scornen thee and laughe at thy folye
(base) For comenly men woot it wel oueral
(base) That myghty god is in hise heuenes hye
(base) And thise ymages wel thow mayst espye
(base) To thee ne to hem self mowe noght profite
(base) For in effect they be nat worth a myte
(base) Thise and swiche othere seyde she
(base) And he weex wrooth and bad men sholde hir lede
(base) Hoom til hir hous and in hir hous quod he
(base) Bren hire right in a Bath of flambes rede
(base) And as he bad right so was doon the dede
(base) For in a Bath they gonne hire faste shetten
(base) And nyght and day greet fyr they vnder betten
(base) The longe nyght and eek a day also
(base) For al the fyr and eek the Bathes hete
(base) She sat al coold and feeled no wo
(base) It made hir nat o drope for to swete
(base) But in that Bath hir lyf she moste lete
(base) For he Almachius with a ful wikke entente
(base) To sleen hire in the Bath his sonde sente
(base) Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho
(base) The tormentour but for no maner chaunce
(base) He myghte noght smyte al hir nekke atwo
(base) And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce
(base) That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce
(base) The ferthe strook to smyten softe or soore

div.l: (base) This tormentour ne dorste do namoore
(base) But half deed with hir nekke ycoruen there
(base) He lefte hir lye and on his wey he went
(base) The cristen folk whiche that aboute hire were
(base) With shetes han the blood ful faire yhent
(base) Thre dayes lyued she in this torment
(base) And neuere cessed hem the feith to teche
(base) That she hadde fostred hem she gan to preche
(base) And hem she yaf hir moebles and hir thyng
(base) And to the Pope Vrban bitook hem tho
(base) And seyde I axed this of heuene kyng
(base) To han respit thre dayes and namo
(base) To recommende to yow er that I go
(base) To perfourme that I before haue do
(base) Thise soules lo and that I myghte do Werche
(base) Here of myn hous perpetuelly a cherche
(base) Seint Vrban with hise deknes pryuely
(base) The body fette and buryed it by nyghte
(base) Among hise othere Seintes honestly
(base) Hir hous the chirche of Seinte Cecilie highte

(base) In which in to this day in noble wyse
(base) Men doon to crist and to his Seinte seruyse
(base) Here is ended the Nonnes tale
(base) ¶ The prologe / of the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~
(base) ¶ hic incipit fabula Canonici
(base) Whan toold was al the lyf / . of Seinte Cecile
(base) Er we hadde riden / fully fyue Mile
(base) At Boghtoun vnder Blee / vs gan atake
(base) A man / that clothed was / in clothes blake
(base) And vnder nethe / he wered a Surplys
(base) His hakeney / which that was al pomely grys
(base) So swatte / that it wonder was to see
(base) It semed / as he had priked Miles three
(base) The hakeney eek / that his yeman rood vpon
(base) So swatte / that vnnethe myghte it gon
(base) Aboute þe peytrel stood þe foom ful hye
(base) He was of foom as flekked as a pye
(base) A Male tweyfoold / vp on his croper lay
(base) It semed / that he caried lite array
(base) Al light for Somer / rood this worthy man
(base) And in myn herte / to wondren I bigan
(base) What that he was / til that I vnderstood
(base) How that his cloke / was sowed to his hood
(base) For which / whan I hadde longe auysed me
(base) I demed hym / som Chanoun for to be
(base) His hat heeng / at his bak / doun by a laas
(base) For he hadde riden / moore than trot or paas
(base) He hadde ay priked / lik as he were wood
(base) A Clote leef / he hadde vnder his hood
(base) For swoot and for to kepe his heed from heete
(base) But it was ioye / for to seen hym swete
(base) His forheed dropped / as a Stillatorie

(base) And whan that he was come / he gan to crye
(base) God saue quod he / this ioly compaignye
(base) Faste haue I priked quod he / for youre sake
(base) By cause / that I wolde yow atake
(base) To riden / in som myrie compaignye
(base) His yeman eek was ful of curteisye
(base) And seyde sires / now in the morwe tyde
(base) Out of youre hostelrie / I saugh yow ryde
(base) And warned heer / my lord and my souerayn
(base) Which / to ryden with yow / is ful fayn
(base) For his desport he loueth daliaunce
(base) ¶ Freend / for thy warnyng god yeue thee chaunce
(base) Thanne seyde oure hoost. for certein / it wolde seme
(base) Thy lord were wys / and so I may wel deme
(base) He is ful iocunde also / dar I leye
(base) Can he oght telle / a myrie tale or tweye
(base) With which / he glade may this compaignye ;
(base) ¶ Who sire my lord ; ye / ye with outen lye
(base) He kan of murthe / and eek of Iolitee
(base) Nat but ynough / also sir trusteth me
(base) And ye hym knewe / as wel as do I
(base) Ye wolde wondre / how wel and craftily
(base) He koude werke / and that in sondry wise
(base) He hath take on hym /. many a greet empⁱrise
(base) Which were ful hard / for any that is heere
(base) To brynge aboute / but they of hym it leere
(base) As hoomly / as he rit amonges yow
(base) If ye hym knewe / it wolde be for youre prow
(base) Ye wolde nat forgoon his Aqueyntaunce
(base) For muchel good / I dar leye in balaunce
(base) Al that I haue / in my possessioun
(base) He is a man / of heigh discrecioun
(base) I warne yow wel / he is a passyng man
(base) ¶ Wel quod oure hoost . I pray thee tel me than
(base) Is he a clerk / or noon ; telle what he is
(base) ¶ Nay / he is gretter than a clerk ywis
(base) Seyde this yeman / and in wordes fewe
(base) Hoost of his craft som what I wol yow shewe
(base) ¶ I seye / my lord / kan swich subtilitee
(base) But al his craft. ye may nat wite for me
(base) And somwhat helpe I yet to his wirking
(base) That al this ground / on which we been ridyng
(base) Til that we come / to Caunterbury toun
(base) For al the ground to Caunterbury toun
(base) He koude al clene / turne it vp so doun
(base) And paue it / al of siluer / and of gold
(base) ¶ And whan this yeman / hadde this tale ytold
(base) Vn to oure hoost. he seyde benedicitee
(base) This thyng is wonder mueillous to me
(base) Syn that thy lord / is of so heigh prudence
(base) By cause of which / men sholde hym reuerence
(base) That of his worship / rekketh he so lite
(base) His ouerslop / nys nat worth a myte
(base) As in effect to hym / so moot I go
(base) It is al baudy / and to tore also
(base) Why is thy lord so sluttissh I the preye
(base) And is of power bettre clooth to beye
(base) If that his dede / accorde with thy speche
(base) Telle me that. and that I thee biseche

div.l: (base) ¶ Why quod this yeman ; / wherto axe ye me ;
(base) God help me so / for he shal neuere thee
(base) But I wol nat anowe that I seye
(base) And therfore / keep it secree I yow preye
(base) He is to wys / in feith / as I bileeue
(base) That that is ouerdoon / it wol nat preeue
(base) Aright ; / as clerkes seyn / it is a vice
(base) Wherfore in that I holde hym lewed ⁊and nyce
(base) For whan a man / hath ouer greet a wit
(base) Ful oft hym happeth / to mysusen it
(base) So dooth my lord / and that me greueth soore
(base) God it amende / I kan sey yow namoore
(base) ¶ Ther of no fors / good yeman / quod oure hoost
(base) Syn of the konnyng of thy lord thow woost
(base) Telle how he dooth / I pray thee hertely
(base) Syn that he is / so crafty and so sly
(base) Where dwelle ye / if it to telle be ;
(base) ¶ In the Suburbes / of a toun quod he
(base) Lurkynge in hernes / and in lanes blynde
(base) Where as thise robboᵘurs / and thise theues by kynde
(base) Holden / hir pryuee fereful residence
(base) As they / that dar nat shewen hir presence
(base) So faren we / if I shal seye the sothe
(base) ¶ Now quod oure hoost / . lat me telle to the
(base) Why artow / so discoloured of thy face ;
(base) ¶ Peter quod he / god yeue it harde grace
(base) I am so vsed / in the fyr to blowe
(base) That it hath chaunged my colour I trowe
(base) I am nat wont in no Mirour to prie
(base) But swynke soore / and lerne multiplie
(base) We blondren euere / and pouren in the fir
(base) And for al that we faille of oure desir
(base) For euere we lakke / of oure conclusioun
(base) To muchel folk / we doon illusioun
(base) And borwe gold / be it a pound or two
(base) Or ten / or twelue / or manye sommes mo
(base) And make hem / wenen at the leeste weye
(base) That of a pound / we koude make tweye
(base) Yet is it fals / but ay we han good hope
(base) It for to doon / and after it we grope
(base) But that Science / is so fer vs biforn
(base) We mowen nat al though we hadden sworn
(base) It ouertake / it slit awey so faste
(base) It wole / vs maken beggers atte laste
(base) ¶ Whil this yeman / was thus in his talkyng
(base) This Chanoun drough hym neer ⁊and herde al thyng
(base) Which this yeman spak / for suspecioun
(base) Of mēnnes speche / euere hadde this Chanoun
(base) For Catoun seith / that he that gilty is
(base) Demeth alle thyng. be spoke of hym ywis
(base) That was the cause / he gan so ny / hym drawe
(base) To his yeman / to herknen al his sawe
(base) And thus he seyde / vn to his yeman tho
(base) Hoold thou thy pees / and spek no wordes mo
(base) For if thou do / thou shalt it deere abye
(base) Thou sclaundrest me / heere in this compaignye
(base) And eek discouerest that thou sholdest hyde
(base) ¶ Ye quod oure hoost / telle on what so bityde
(base) Of al his thretyng rekke nat a myte
(base) ¶ In feith quod he / namoore I do but byte
(base) ¶ And whan this Chanoun / saugh it wolde nat bee
(base) But his yeman / wolde telle his pryuetee
(base) He fledde awey / for verray sorwe and shame
(base) ¶ A quod the yeman / heere shal arise game
(base) Al that I kan / anon now wol I telle
(base) Syn he is goon / the foule feend hym quelle
(base) For neuere heer wol I with hym meete
(base) For peny ne for pound I yow biheete
(base) He that me broghte first vn to that game
(base) Er that he dye / sorwe haue he and shame
(base) For it is / ernest to me by my feith
(base) That feele I wel / what that any man seith
(base) And yet for al my smert and al my grief
(base) For al my sorwe / labour / and meschief
(base) I koude neuere leue it / in no wise
(base) Now wolde god / my wit myghte suffise
(base) To tellen / al that longeth / to that Art
(base) And nathelees / yow wol I tellen part
(base) Syn that my lord is goon / I wol nat spare
(base) Swich thyng / as that I knowe / I wol declare
(base) ¶ Heere endeth the prologe of the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~
(base) With this chanoun dwelled haue I seuen ȝeer
(base) And of his science am I neuer the neer
(base) Al that I hadde I haue y lost therby
(base) And god wot so haue many mo than I
(base) Ther I was wont to be right freissch and gay
(base) Of clothing and of good array
(base) Now may I were an hose vpon myn heed

(base) That slydynge science hath me maad so bare

(base) And ȝit I am endetted so ther by
(base) Of gold that I haue borwed trewely
(base) That whil I lyue I schal it quite neuere /
(base) Lat euery man be war by me for euere /
(base) What maner man that casteth him therto

(base) For vnto schrewes Ioye it is and ese
(base) To haue here felawes in peyne and disese
(base) Thus was I ones lerned of a clerk
(base) Of that no charge I wol speke of oure werk
(base) Whan we ben there as we schulle exercise
(base) Oure eluysshe craft ; we semen wonder wise
(base) Oure termes ben so clergeal and so queynte
(base) I blowe the fuyr til that myn herte feynte
(base) What scholde I telle eche proporcioun
(base) Of thinges whiche that we worchen vppon

div.l: (base) As on fyue or sixe vnces may wel be

(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
