div.l: (base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
¶ Here begynnithe þe ꝐPardoners tale .
LOrdinges quod he in churchis when I prech
I peyne me to have an haunten spech
Herang it out as rounde as goithe a bell
For I Can alle by rote that I telle
My tyme is alwey on ⁊and eủer was
Radix omniu maloru est cupeditas
First I pronounce whens that I come /
And thanne my bull schew I all ⁊and sum
Ovre lege lordis sele is my patente
Þat schew I fyrst my body to warent
Þat no man be so bolde prest ne clerke
Me to distroble of Crystꝭes holy werke
And aftir that telle I forthe my tales
Bullis of popes and of Cardinalles
Of patriaches ⁊and bisshopes I schewe /¶
And in latyne I speke a wordes fewe
To saverou withe my predicaciou
And for to styr men to devocioun
Þan schew I Forthe my long cristal stones
I Cramyd ful of Cloutes ⁊and of bonis
Relikes thei ben as wen thei echone
Þan have I in latou a scholderbone /
Which was an holy Iewes schepe
God men sey I take of my wordes kepe
Yf that this bone be wasche in ony welle
Yf cow or Calfe or schepe or ox swell
Þat eny worme hathe I rote or I stonge
Touche he this bone a nōnn he schalle be sounde
And yit also forthermore
Of pocke or scabbe or of oþ̉er sor
Schall eủery schepe be hole þat of this well
Drynkithe a drawte or take kepe what I telle
Wol eủery wyght er þᵗat þe cok him crowith
And do thing that him hovithe
Fastyng drink of this welle a drawte
As thilke holy Iew oure elders ones tauȝt
His bestꝭes⁊and his stor schul multeplie
And sirs also hit helithe Ielowsye
And þ̉er a man befal in Ielousy rage
Lete make wᵗith this wat̉er his potage
And neủer schall he mor̉e wyf mystrest
Þei he þe sothe a defaute by hir wyst
Al had sche taken prestꝭes two or þre
Her is a meteyne eke ye may se
He that his honde wolle put in that meteyn
He schalle have multepliyng of his greyn
When he hathe sowen be it whet or otꝭes
So that of pens oþir of grotꝭes
And men ⁊and women o thing werne I yowe
Yf ony wyȝt be now in this chorche
Þat hathe done synne horryble þᵗat he
Dere nouȝt for schame schryven be
Or ony woman be sche yong or olde
Þat hathe made hir husbonde kukwolde
Suche folke schall have no power ne grace
To offre to my relikꝭes in þis place
And who so fyndithe hi oute of suche blame
Yf thei wolle come vp ⁊and offr a goddes name /
And I asoyle hem by the auctoryte
Suche that by bull was grauntid me
By this gavde have I wonne every yer
An hundrid marke sith I was pardon
I stonde like a Clerke in a pulpit
And schew lewde peple ⁊and doun thei sett
I preche so as ye have hard be for
And tel an hunderde Iapis more
Þenne peyne I me to strech forth my necke
And est ⁊and west vpon the peple I becke
As dothe a dofe syttyng vp on a berne
My . hondes ⁊and my tonge go so yerne
Þat it is Ioy to se my besynes ¶
Of averice and suche oþ̉er cursidnes
Is al my prechyng to make he fre
To yeve her panes ⁊and namly vn to me
For myn entente is nouȝt but for to wyn
And no thing for correcciou of synne
I rek neủer when thei be buryed
Þowhe that hir soules go a blak buryd
For Certes mony a predicaciou
Sounithe ofte tyme in evil entenciou
Som for plesaunce of folke ⁊and for flaterye
To be avauncid be Ipocrasye
And som for veyne glorie ⁊and some for hate
For when I dare not oþ̉er wyse debate
Þan wol I stynge he wᵗith my tong smerte
In preching so that he schall not a starte /
To ben defamed falsely yf þᵗat he
Hathe trespassid to my broþ̉er or to me
For thow I telle not his proꝑper name
Men schul wel know it is the same
By simony ⁊and by oþ̉er circumstaunces
Thus quite I folke that doith vs displesauns
Þus spete I oute venym vnder huȝe
Of holynes to seme holy ⁊and trewe
But schortly myn entent I wol devise /
I preche of nothing but of Covetise
Þer fore my tyme is yit ⁊and eủer was
Radix omnium maloru est Cupeditas
Þus Can I preche a yene the same vice
Suche as I vse ⁊and that is averise
But they I my selfe be gylty in that synne
Yit Can I make oþ̉er folke to wynne
From Avaryece / and sor to repent
But that is nauȝt my pryncipall entente
I preche no thinge but for couetyse
Of this mat̉er I ouȝt I now suffise
Þan tel I of ensamples meny one
Of olde stories longe tyme a gone
For lewde peple louen tales olde
Whiche thingꝭes Can thei well reporte ⁊and holde
What trow ye whiles that I may preche
And wynne golde ⁊and sylủer for I teche
Þat I wolle lyve in povert wylfully
Nay nay I thouȝt it neủer truly
For I wolle preche ⁊and bede in sundry londes
I wol not do no labour wᵗith my hondes
And make balkes ⁊and liue þ̉er by
Be cause I wolle not begge ydelly
I wolle none of the aposteles count̉erfete
I wolle have mony Cheses ⁊and whete
Al were it evin of the porest page
Oþir of the porest widow in a vilage /
Al schulde hir Childerin sterve for famen
Nay I woll drynke þe likoure of þe wyn
And have a Ioly wenche in every toun
But herkenithe lordes in conclusiou ¶
Youre likyng is that I schall tel a tale
Now I have dronke a drawte of Corny ale
Be god I hope I schall telle yow a thinge
Þat schall be reson ben at yoᵘur likyng
For thowe my selve be a ful viciouse man
A moral tale yit I yow tel can
Which . I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now holde yoᵘur pese my tale I wol begynne
IN flaunderis whilom was a company
Of yong folke that haunten foly
As ryot hasard steves ⁊and taverns
Þei daunsen ⁊and pley at dyse both day ⁊and nyȝt
And etyn also ⁊and dronken oủer al hir myȝt
Þorow which þei don þe devil sacrefise
Wᵗith in the develis temple in cursid wyse
Þe suꝑperfluites abhominable
Hir othis ben so grete ⁊and dampnable
Þat it is gresely for to here . hem swer
Oure blessid lordes body þei to tere
Hem thouȝt Iewes rent him not I nowe
And eche of hem at oþris synis lowhe
And þan ryȝt a none cam to ublesteres
Fetes ⁊and smal yong frutesteres
Syngers wᵗith harpes baudes wafereris
Such ben verre the develis offisers
To kyndill ⁊and blow the firis of lechery
That is avexid to glotony
Þe holy wryte take I to wytnesse
Þat lechery is in wyne is a dronknes
Loo how that dronken loothe onkyndly
Ley by his douȝt̉eres two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he wist not what he wroute
And þe for fro repent him ouȝt
Heroudes who so wolle þe storys seche
Þe may ye lerne ⁊and by ensample teche
When he of his wyne was replete at his fest
Ryȝt at his oune table yave his hest
To slene the baptist Iohn ful gyltles
Senek seith eke gode wordes doutles
He seith he can no dyfferens fynde
Be twyx a man that is oute of his mynde
And a man that is dronklew
But þᵗat wodnes is fallen in a schrew
Parseverth leng than doth dronknes
O glotony ful of cursidnes
O Cause first of oure confusiou
O original first of oure dampnaciou
Til Crist had boute vs wᵗith his blode a yen
Lo how der ⁊and schortly was to seyne
A boute was the Cursid vilony
Corupte was al this worlde þorow gloteny
Adam oure fadir ⁊and his wyf also
From paradyse to laboᵘur⁊and to woo
Were drivin for þᵗat vyse it is no drede ¶
For whiles that adam fastid as I rede /
He was in paradyse ⁊and when that he
Ete of þe frute defendid on a tre
And a none he was oute cast to wo ⁊and pyne
O glotony on the wel oute vs pleyne
O wist a man how mony maladys
Folowith the excersyse of glotenyes
He schuld be þe mor mesurable
Of his dyete syttyng at the table
Alas the schorte throte the tendir mouthe
Makest þat Est ⁊and west Northe ⁊and southe
In erthe in eyr in wat̉er men to swynke
To gete a glotou mete ⁊and drynke
Of this mat̉er O poule wel Canst þᵘ trete /
Mete vn to wombe ⁊and wombe eke vn to mete
Schal god distriıı̄une boith as poule seithe
Alas a foule thing is be my feith
To sey this worde ⁊and fouler is þe dede
When men so drynkith of the white ⁊and of þe rede /
Þat of his throte he makith his prive
Þorow thilke cursid suꝑperfluite
Þe Apostel seith weping ful petovsly
Þ̉er walken mony of whiche yow told have I
I Sey it now wepyng wᵗith petouse voyse
Þer ben enmyes of Cristꝭes croise
Of which þe ende is dethe þe wombe is hir god
O wombe O . holy o stynkyng god
Fulfillid of dung and of Corrupciou
At eyþ̉er ende of þe foule is þe sounde
How gret Cost and labour is to fynde
Thes cokes how þei stampe streyn ⁊and grynde
And turn substaıı̄unce in to Accidente /
To fulfil al thi lekerouse talent
Oute of the harde bonis knokinge þei
Þe Mary for thei Cast nouȝt a weye
Þat may go þorow the golet softe ⁊and sate /
Of spiceri of levis barke ⁊and rote /
Schall be his sause made by delyte
To make him yit a newer apetite /
But certes he that hauntith such delites
Is dede while livithe in the vices
A lecherowse thing is wyne ⁊and druknes
Is ful of stryving ⁊and wrecchidnes
O dronkyn man disfigurid is þⁱ fase /
Foule is þi brethe foule ert þᵘ to enbrase
And þorouȝ thi dronkin nose semith þi soune /
As þouȝe þow seidest ey sampsou sampsou
And yit god wote sampsou drank neủer no wyne /
Þow fallest as þᵘ were a stikid swyne /
Þi tong is lost ⁊and al thi honest cures
For dronknes is verry sepultures
Of manis witt ⁊and his discrecioun
In whom that drynes hathe dıı̄unacioun ¶
He can no counsail kepe it is no drede
Now kepe yow from the white ⁊and from þe rede
Namly from the white wyne of lepe
Þat is to selle in fyssh strete or in chepe
Þis wyne of spayne kepith subtely
In oþ̉er wynes growyng fast by
Of which þ̉er risith such fumosite /
Þat when a man hathe dronken drauȝtꝭes þr
And wenithe that he be at home in chepe
He is in spayne ryȝt at the tou of lepe
Nouȝt at þe rochel ne at þe bordevx toun
And than wolne thei sey sampsou sampsou
And herkenith lordingꝭes O worde I yow pray
Þat al the soủerayne actꝭes dare I sey
Of þe victorys in the olde testamentꝭes
Þat þorow werry god þᵗat is omipotent
Wer done in abstinence ⁊and in prayer
Lokithe the bible ⁊and þ̉er ye may it ler
Lokithe attilla the grete conqueroᵘur
Dide in his slepe wᵗith schame ⁊and dishonoᵘur
Bledyng ey at his nose in drunknes
A Capten schulde lyve in sobirnes
And oþ̉er al this a vise yow ryȝt wel
What was Comaundid vn to lanyel
Nouȝt Samuel Lamuel sey I
Redithe the bible ⁊and fyndith it expressely
Of wyn yeving to them that hathe Iustice /
No more of this for it may welle suffice /
ANd now that I have spoke of glotony
Now welle I defende yow hasardy
Hasard is verr modir of lesynges
And of disseyte cursid for sweringꝭes also
Of batel ofte tyme ⁊and of oþ̉er mo
It is repreve ⁊and Contrary to honoᵘur
For to be holde a comoune hasardour
And eủer the hier he is of astate
Þe mor he is holde desolate
Yf that a prynce vse hasardy
In al goủernaunce ⁊and al polesye
He is ay be Comovne opynioune /
I holde the les in reputacioun
Stilbou that was holde a wyse enbasetoᵘur
Was sent in to carinthe wᵗith gret honoᵘur
For Calidomy to maken him aliaunce /
And when he Cam him happid þis chaunse
Þat al the gretest þᵗat was of þis londe
Pleyng at the hasard he him fonde
For which as sone as þᵗat myȝt be
He stale him home to his Contree
And saide þ̉er wolle I not lese my name /
I ne wolle not take on me for gret defame /
Yoᵘur for to alye to non hasardoure
Sendithe oþ̉er wyse enbassetoure
For be my trouth me wer lever dye
Þanne I to yow schuld hasardowris a wey
For ye that ben so glorious in honoᵘur /¶
Schall nouȝt alye yow wᵗith haserdour
As be my wille ne as be my trete
Þis wyse philesopher thus oveyid to me
Loke yow vse no pley of dyse in thyn house
Loke eke that the kynge demetruse
Sent him a peyr dyse of golde in scorne
For he had vsed hasardy þer be forne
For whiche he schulde his glorie ⁊and his renoun
At no valew of Reputacioun
Lordes myȝten fynde oþ̉er pley
Honest I nowhe to dryve a wey þe day
NOw wolle I speke of oþis fals ⁊and grete
A woord or too as oþ̉er bokes entrete
Gret sweryng is a thynge ab hominable /
And fals sweryng is a thyng mor reprovable
Þe hye god for bade sweryng at alle /
Witnes of Mathew but in specialle
Of sweryng seithe holy Ieromy
Þow schalt swer sothe thin othis ⁊and schalt not lye
And swer in dome ⁊and in ryȝtwysnes
For ydil sweryng is a cursidnes
Be holde ⁊and se that in the fyrst table
Of hyȝe godes hestꝭes honourable
How that the secounde hest of him is þis
Take not my name in ydilnes a mys
Lo rathir he for beddes suche sweryng
Or homicide or ony oþ̉er cursid thinge
I Sey as by ordyr thus it stondithe
Þat knowith they þᵗat his his hestꝭes vndirstondith
How that the seconde heste of god is þᵗat /
And forthermore I wolle tel þe tale al plat
Þat veniaunce schall not part from his house /
Þat of his othis is so ovtragious
Ay be goddes pcious herte ⁊and his nayles
And by his blode that is in haylis
Sevyn is my chaunce ⁊and þin is v . ⁊and þre
Ay goddes Armes yf þᵘ falsly pley me /
Þis dag schall þorow thin herte go
Þis fruyt Comith of þe bechid bonis too
For sweryng Ire falsnes homicide
Now for the love of Criste þᵗat for vs dide
Levith yoᵘur othis bothe grete ⁊and smale
For Cristꝭes sake ⁊and herkenith to my tale
Thes riatoᵘurs of thre which I tel
Long or pryme rang eny bel
Were set hem in a taủerne for to drynk /
And as they sett thei harde a bell clynke
Be forne his Cors was Caryd to a grave
Þe tou of hem gan Calle to his knave
Go wete qd he ⁊and axe redelye
What Corse is that that passith for by
And loke that thow report his name wele
Sir qd this boy it nedithe neủer a dele
Hit was me tolde or I Came her too owris
He was parde an olde felow of youres ¶
All sodenly was he slayne to nyȝt
For dronke as he satt vp on his bench vp ryȝt
Ther Come a prevy thef men clepin dethe
That in this Contre alle þe peple slethe
And wᵗith his spere he smote his hert in too
And went his wey wᵗith oute wordis mo
And maist̉er or ye Come in his psence /
He hathe a thousand slayne þis pestelence /
Me thinkith that it wer ryȝt nessessarye
For to be ware suche an adủersary
Bethe redy for to mete him eủermor
Thus tauȝt me my dame I sey nomor
O seynt Marie seide this tauern
The chylde seithe soth for he hath slayne to yeer
Hens oủer a myle wᵗith in a grete village /
Bothe man ⁊and woman Childe ⁊and page
I trow his habitacioun be þe
To be avisid gret wysdom it were
Er that he did a man to dishonoᵘur
Yee goddes armes saide this ryatoᵘur
Is it suche ꝑperell wᵗith him for to mete
I Schall him seke by dale ⁊and eke by strete /
Herkene felawes we thre be alones
I schalle him seke be kokkꝭes der bonis
Lete eche of vs be come oþ̉eris broþ̉er
And eche of vs holde vp his honde to oþ̉er
And we wolle sle this fals traytoᵘur dethe
He schalle be slayne he þᵗat so mony slethe
Be goddis dignitee or that it be nyȝt
To gedir hath thes thre hir hertꝭes hyȝt
To liue ⁊and dye eủerych of he wᵗith oþ̉er
As he wer his owne sworne broþ̉er
And vp they stert al dronke in this rage
And forth they gone toward þᵗat village
Of which the taủerner hadde spoke be forne
And many a grysly othe hathe they sworne
And Cristꝭes blessid body they to rent
Dethe schall be dede yf that we may him hent
When thei have gon not fully a myle
Ryȝt as they wolde have trodyn oủer a style
An olde pore man as sone thei mett
This olde man ful mekely hem gret
And seyde thus now lordyngꝭes god yow se
Þe proudest of thes riotours thre
Annswerd what carle wᵗith an hard grace

And of prudence / and hir benignite

Or so hardy to hir trerspas

And / Criethe fals Coward wrek thi wyf

Vp on my feyþe þow art som officere
Som worthi sextein or som selarere
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Þᵘou art a mast̉er whan þᵘou art at home
No pore Cloysterere ne no pore novice
But A goủernour wyli ⁊and wyse
And þ̉er wᵗith al of brawes ⁊and of bones
A wel fayr͗e ꝑpersone for the nones
I pray to god yeve him cōnfusion
That First the browȝt in to relugion
Thow wost han be A . tredefoule A ryȝte
Haddist thow as grete leve as þᵘou hast myȝte
To parforme al thi luste in engenderure
Þow hadest be goton mony A Creature
Allas whi werist thow so wyde A Cope
God yeve me sorow and I were A pope
Not only þᵘou but eủery myȝty man
Thowȝe he were shore hey vp on þe pan
Shulde han A wyf for alle þⁱˢ worlde is lorne
Religion hathe taken vp alle þe Corne
Of tredynge ⁊and be borell men ben shrimpes
Of feble trees Comythe wrecchid ympes
This makithe our childeren ben so slender
And feble that þei ne may not wele engendre
This makithe that our wyfes wolle assay
Religyous folke for þey may bett̉er paye
Of venus payment that may we
God wote no lussheborows pay yee
But beþ not wroth my lord thow I playe
Ful ofte in game A sooþ I have hard say
This worthi monke toke alle in paciens
And saide I wol done al my deligence
As ferre as sonneþ in to honestee
To telle yow a tale or too oþ̉er þree
And yf thow leste to herkyn hedirward
I wolle yow seye the lyf of seint Edwarde
Or eles tregedies / first wolle I telle
Of which I have an hundred in my selle
Tregedyes is for to telle A Certeyne story
As elde bokes maken memorye
Of hēm that stonde in grete prosꝑperite
And is yfalle oute of hyhe degree
In to myserye ⁊and endith wrecchidl
And they ben versefyed comenly
Of sex fete þᵗat men clepen examytron
In prose eke ben endited many one
And eke of meter in many sundry wyse
Loo this ouȝte you ynow suffice
Now harkenith yf you lyst it for to her͗e
But first I yow be seche in this matere
Thouȝ I by ordre telle not þos þynges
Be it of popes Emꝑperoʳurs or kynges
And Aftir age as men wreten fynde
But telle hem . some bifore ⁊and some by hynde
As it Comeþ now to my remembraunce
Have me Excusid of myn ignoraunce
I wolle be wayle in man̉ere of tregedye
The harme of hīm that stondith in hye degre
And fellen so þᵗat þ̉er nas no remedye
To bryng hem oute of hir adủersitee
For Certeyne whan fortune liste to flee
Ther may no man of hure þe cours be holde
Lete noman truste on blynde ꝓprosꝑperite
Beþ ware by this ensample yong ⁊and olde

l.hi: ¶ Primo de lucifero

div.l: At lucyfere þow he An Aıı̄ungel were
And not A man at hīm I wolle begynne
For youþ ne fortune may nōn Aungel der͗e
From hyȝe degree yit felle he for his synne
Doune into helle wher as he is yit ynne
O lucifere bryȝtest of Angelles alle
Now art thow sathanas that maist not twynne /
Out of mysery in wych þᵘou art I falle

l.hi: ¶ De Adam

div.l: Lo Adam in the felde of damascene
Wᵗith goddes owne fynger wrouȝt was / he
And not by getynge of mannes sperme vnclene
And welte alle paradys sauynge oo tree
Hadde neủer worldly man so hye degree
A adam hadde til he for his goủernaıı̄unce
Was drevyn oute of his hye ꝓprosꝑperite
To laboure and to helle ⁊and to myschaunse

l.hi: ¶ De Sampsone

div.l: LOo Sampsone which was annunciat
By the Aıı̄ungel longe or his natiuite
And was to gode Almyȝty cōnsecrat
And stode in noblesse / while he myȝt see
Was neủer suche A noþ̉er as was he
To speke of strenght ⁊and þ̉erto of hardynesse
But to his wyfes tolde his secree
Thorow whiche he slow hīm selve for hevynesse
SAmpson this noble ⁊and myȝti champion
Wᵗith oute wepene save his hondes tweyne
He slowe and Al to rente þe lyone
Toward his weddynge walkynge by the weye
His fals wyf Coude him so plese ⁊and preye
Tille she his Counseill knew ⁊and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his Counseiƚƚlle gan be wrey
And him forsoke ⁊and toke A noþ̉er newe
An hunderid foxes toke sampson for Ire
And alle hir tayles he to gedyr bonde
And sette the foxes tayles al on fyre
For he in eủery tayle had put A bronde
And thei brent alle Cornes in that londe
And alle hir olyves ⁊and hir vynes eke
A thovsand men he slowe wᵗith his honde
And had no wepene but an asse cheke
Whenne thei were slayne so thriistid hīm þᵗat he
Was wel ny lorne For which he gan to prey
That god wolde of his m̉ercy have some pyte
And send him drynke or eles most he dye
And of this asse Cheke þᵗat was so drye
Oute of A wange toþe spronge anon a welle
Of which he dronke y nowe shortly to seye
Thus helpe him god as Iudicu can telle
By verray force at gason on A nyȝte
Maugre philicitiiens of that Citee
The gate of þe toun he haþ vp plyȝt
And on his bakke y caryed hīm hathe he
Hye on an hille wher as myȝt see
O noble ⁊and myȝti sampson leve ⁊and dere
Ne haddest thow tolde to wommen þy secree
In Al this worlde ne hadde be thi pece
This sampson neủer syþ̉er dronke ne wyn
Ne on his hede Came rasour non ne sher͗e
By p̉recepte of þᵉ messang̉er devyn
For al his strenght was in his here
And fully twenty yeer͗e by yeer͗e
He hadde of Iraeell þe goủernaunce
But sone aftir shalle he wepe ful many a teere
For women shulle brynge hīm to mysche
UN to his leman dalida he tolde
That in his heris al his strenght lay
And falsly to his fomen she hīm solde
And shepyng in hir barme vpon a day
She made to Clyppe or shere his her͗e Aweye
And made his foo men all his Crafte Aspien
And when thei him fonde in such araye
They bonde hīm fast ⁊and put oute his yen
BVt or his hede were Clippid or y schave
Ther was no / bonde þᵗat myȝt hēm bynde
But now is he in p̉resoune put in / A / cave
Wher as thei made hīm at the querne grynde
O noble Sampson strengest of mankyd
O whilom Iugge in gloryre ⁊and richesse
Now maiste thowe wepe wᵗith thin yen blynde
Sithen thow art I falle into wrecchidnesse
The Ende of thes Caytyfes was as I shall sey
His foo men made A fest vp on A day
And made hīm as hure fole by fore hēm play
And this was A temple of a grete Araye
But at the laste he made A foule A fraye
For he too postꝭes shoke ⁊and made hēm falle
And doun felle þe temple ⁊and al þ̉er it laye
And slowhe him selfe ⁊and eke his fomen alle
This is the Ende þe pⁱrinces eủerychone
And eke A thousand bodiis were þ̉er slayne
Wᵗith fallyng of the grete temple of stone
Of Sampson wolle I no more sayn
Be ware of this Ensample olde ⁊and pleyne
That no man telle her Counseill to hir wyfes
Of suche thinge as þey wolde have secre sayne
Yf that it touche hir lemes or hir lyves
¶ De Ercule //
OF Ercule that soủerayne cōnquerour
Sygned his werkes lewed ⁊and hye renoun
For in his tyme of strenght he bare þᵉ flour͗e
He slowe ⁊and by rafte the skynne of the lyoun
He of seynt Aures leyde þe bost A downe
He Arpies slowh þe cruell bridde fell
He golden apples raffte of the dragon
He drowe oute Serberoys þe hounde of helle
HE slowe þe Cruell Tyraunt Buserous
And made his hors to frete hīm flesche ⁊and bone
He slowe the veraye serpent venemous
Of Achilles too hornes brake he one
And he slow Cacus in A Cave of stone
He slowe the geaunt Anteus þe stronge
He slowe the gresly bore ⁊and þᵗat a none
And bare his hede vpon his necke longe
Was neủer wyȝte sithen the worlde be gan
Þat slowe so many mynstres as did he
Þorow oute þis wyde world his name ran
What for his strenght and his bounte
And into eủery reme went he for to see
He was so stronge that no man myȝt hīm lette
And at the worldes ende as saith trophe
In stede of boundes he A piler sette
A lemman had this noble Champion
That hyȝte dyaniyre / as fresche as may
And as the Clerkes maden mencion
She hath him sent A sherte freshe ⁊and gaye
Allas his shirt and welaweye
Eve nemed was subtily wᵗith alle
That or he had werid it halfe A daye
Hit made his bones from his fleshe falle
BVt natheles some Clerkes her͗e excuson
By one that hyȝt nessus þᵗat it maked
Be as it be may I wille hure not accusen
But on his bak this shert he werid al naked
Tyl that his flessh was for þe venyme blakid
And whan he saw non othir remedy
In hote coles he hath hīm selve raked
For wᵗith no / venym deynid hīm to dye
Thus straf this worthi myȝti Arcules
Loo ho may trust on fortune ony throwe
For hīm that folowith all þⁱˢ worlde of pres
Or he be ware is ofte leyde full lowe
Ful wyse is he that him self Can knowe
By ware for whanne that fortune lyst to glose
Thene waytith she hir man downe to throwe
By suche A weye as he wolde lest suuppose
¶ De Rege Nabigodonoser
The myȝti trone the p̉resious tresoure
The glorious septre ⁊and Riall mageste
That had the kyng nabugodonoser
Wᵗith tonge vnneþe may discreuid be
He twyes wan Ierlm̄Ierusalem the Citee
The vessell of the temple wᵗith him ladde
At babulon was his soủerayne se
In whiche his glorye ⁊and his delite he hadde
The fairest childer of þe blode rialle
Of Ierlm̄Ierusalem he dide do gylde A none
And make echēn of hēm to bēn his cherle
A monge al oþ̉er danyel was one
That was the wysest childe of eủery chone
For he the dromes of þe kynge expounde
Wher as in Calday Clerke was þ̉er none
That wyst to what fyne his dremes souned
This proude kynge lete make A statute of
Sexty Cubettꝭes longe ⁊and sevene in brede
To which ymage boþe yonge ⁊and olde
Comaunded he to loute ⁊and have in drede
Or in A forneyse full of flaumes rede
He schuld be brente þat wolde not obeye
But neủer wolde assent to that dede
Daniysel ne his yonge felawes tweyne
This kyng was proude passing of his degre
He wende god þᵗat syttith in mageste
Had nouȝt be so gret a lorde as he
But sodenly he loste his dignitee
And like A best hīm semid for to be
And ete heye as an Oxe and laye þ̉er oute
In rayne wᵗith bestꝭes wylde walkid he
Til Certeyne tyme was comyn A boute
ANd like an eglis fetheris was his heris
His nayles like briddis Clawes wer͗e
God releued him a certeyne yeeris
And yaf hīm wytte ⁊and than wᵗith many a teere
He thankid god / ⁊and eủer his lyf in fere
Was he to done a mys or more to trespas
And or that tyme · y leyde was on his bere
He knewe wele that god was ful of myȝt ⁊and gᵃrace
¶ De Baltasar
His sone which that / hyȝt baltazer
That helde the regne aftir his fadris day
He by his fadir Couþe not be ware
For proude he was of herte ⁊and of araye
And eke an ydolastre was he aye
His heye estate assured hīm in pryde
But fortune Cast him downe ⁊and þ̉er he laye
And sodenly his regne ganne devide
A Feste he made vn to his lordis alle
Vpon A tyme he made hēm blyþe be
And than his officers gan he Calle
Goo bryngith forthe þe vesseles qduod he
Which that my fadir in his prosꝑperite
Oute of the temple of Ierrlm̄Ierusalem be rafte
And to oure heye goddes thanke wee
Of honoure that oure elders wᵗith vs lafte
His wyf his lordes ⁊and his concubynes
Ay drynken whiles hir Apetyte last
Oute of this noble vessels sondry wynes
And on A walle he his yen Caste
And sawe an hande armles þᵗat wrouȝte ful fast
For fere of which he quoke ⁊and sykid sore
This hond that baltaser made so sore a gast
Wrote mane techil phares ⁊and no more
IN all that londe magican was þ̉er non
Þat couþe expoune what þⁱˢ łletre ment
But danyel Expouned it A none
And saide kynge / god to þi fadir sent
Glorie and honoʳur Regne tresour ⁊and rent
And þ̉erfore god grete wreche on him sent
And him be rafte the regne that he hadde
HE was oute Caste of manis companye
Wᵗith asses was his habitacion
And ete heye as a best in wete ⁊and drye
Til that he knew by grase ⁊and by resoıı̄un
Þᵗat god of hevene hath dominacioun
Oủer eủery regne and eủery Creature
And than hadde god of him cōmpassioun
And him restored his regne in his figur
Eke thow that art his sone ⁊and poude also
And knowest alle thes thingꝭes p̉revely
And rebel to god ⁊and art his foo
Thow drankest eke of his vessellis bodely
Thy wyf eke ⁊and thi wenches synfully
Dronke of the same vessel sondry wynes
And heryde fals goddes cursedly
Ther fore to the shapen gret peyne is
This honde was from god þᵗat on þᵉ walle
Wrote · mane techil phares trustiþ me
Thi regne is do þou woldest it not at alle
Devidid is thi regne / and it shalle be
To Medes ⁊and to perces yoven qduod he
And thilke same nyȝte the kynge was slawe
And daryous occupithe his degree
Thow he þ̉erto had nouþ̉er ryȝt no lawe
LOrdyngꝭes herby ensample may ye take
How that in lordshipe is no sekyrnes
For whan fortune wolle A man forsake
He berith A wey his regne ⁊and his richesse
And eke his frendes bothe more ⁊and lesse
And whanne A man hath frendes þorow fortune
Mys happe wol make hīm enemyes I gesse
This preverbe is ful soth ⁊and ful comune
¶ De Cenobia · / ·
CEnobia of palamere þe quene
As weten ꝑpersyens of hure noblesse
So worthi was in Armes ⁊and so kene
That no wyght passid hir in hardynesse
Ne in linage ne in oþ̉er gentilnesse
Of the kyngꝭes blode of pers is she discendid
I Say she nad not moste fayrnesse
But of hir shappe she myȝt not bēn Amendid
FRoo chyldhode I fynde that she fledde
Office of woman And into wode she went
And many a wylde hartꝭes blode she shedde
Wᵗith arowes brode þᵗat she to hym sent
She was so swyfte that she A none hīm hent
And whan that she was elder she wolde kylle
Lyouns and liberdes ⁊and beres Al to rente
And in hir Armes welde hem at hir wille
She durst wylde bestꝭes dennys seke
And renne in þe mounten al þe nyȝte
And slepe vndir A bosshe she coude eke
Wrastelyn by verray force and myte
Wᵗith enye man were neủer so wyȝte
Ther myȝt no thing in hir Armes stonde
She kepte hir maydinhode from eủery wyȝte
To noman deynid she to be bounde
BVt at the last her frendes han hir maryed
To Odenak A prynce of that Citee
Al were it so that she hīm longe taryed
And ye shall vndirstonde how that he
Had such fantasyes as hadde sche
But netheles when they wer͗e knyt in fer͗e
Thei leveden in Ioy ⁊and felicite
For eche of hēm hadde oþer leve ⁊and dere
SAve o thing that she nolde neủer assent
By no wey that he shulde by hir lye
But ones for hit was hir pleyne entente
To have A childe þe worlde to multeplie
And As sone as sche myȝt Aspie
That she was not wᵗith childe wᵗith that dede
Than wolde she suffre him do his fantasye
Est sone ⁊and but ones out of drede
And yf she were wᵗith childe atte thilke caste
No more shulde he pley þᵗat ilke game
Tyl fourty dayes were paste
Then wold she suffre hīm do the same
All were this odenak wylde or tame
He gate no more of hir / but thus she saide
Hit was to wyfes lecherye ⁊and shame
In oþer cas yf that men wᵗith hem playde
Twoo sones by this odinak hadde she
The which she kepte in v̉ertu ⁊and in letterure
But now in to oure tale turne we
I seye that worshipfull Creature
And wyse ther with ⁊and large wᵗith mesure
So penyble in the werre ⁊and curteyse eke
No more laboure myȝte in werr͗e endure
Was none thouȝe al this worlde shuld seke
HEre rich araye myȝt not be tolde
As welle in vessell as in clothing
She was Cladde all in perrey ⁊and in golde
And eke she lafte not for non huntyng
To have of sundrye tongꝭes folke knowyng
Whan that she leyser hadde ⁊and for to entende
To lerne bokes was alle hir likinge
How she in vertu myȝte Al hir lyf dispende
ANd shortly of this story for to entrete
As douȝti was hir husbonde as was she
Þat they Conquerid many regnes grete
In the oryent wᵗith many A faire Citee
Appertinent vnto the magestee
Of Rome ⁊and wᵗith strong honde held hēm fast
Ne neủer myȝt hir fomen done hem flee
As longe as Odenakes dayes last
HEr bataillꝭes he so leste hem for to rede
A geyn sopeo þe kynge ⁊and oþ̉er mo
And how that alle the prosses fel in dede
Whi she Conquerid ⁊and what title had þ̉erto
And aftir of hir myscheff ⁊and of hir woo
How she was byseged ⁊and I take
And lete him · vnto my mast̉er petrak goo
That wrytith y now of this I vndirtake
Whan Odenak was dede sche myȝtily
The regnes helde ⁊and wᵗith hir propre honde
A geyne hir foos sheo fauȝt trulye
That ther nas kynge ne prince in / al that londe
Þat he nas glade / yf he that gᵃrace fonde
That she ne wolde vpon his lond werreye
Wᵗith hir thei made Allyance be bounde
To ben in pes ⁊and lete hir ryde ⁊and pleye
The Emꝑperoure of rome claudeus
Ne him be fore Romayn Galyene
Ne dorst neủer be so coragious
Ne none ermyn ne none Arabiene
That durst ones to fore hir be sene
Wᵗith ynne the felde that durst wᵗith hir fyte
Lest that she wolde wᵗith hir hondes hem slene
Or wᵗith her meyne put hem to flyȝte
IN kyngꝭes Abyte went hir sones twoo
As heyres of hure Regiones alle
And harmanno ⁊and tyntalite bothe twoo
Her names were as ꝑperciens hem call
But ay hathe fortune in hir hony galle
This myȝty Quene may no while endure
Fortune oute of hire regne made hir falle
To wrecchidnesse ⁊and to mys Aventure
AVrilious / when that the goủernaıı̄uns
Of Rome Come in to his hondes tweye
He shope vp on this quene to done Vengeaıı̄unce
And wiþ his legions he toke his wey
Toward Cenobye shortly for to sey
He made hir fle and atte last her hente
And feteryd hir ⁊and eke hir childeryn tweye
And wanne the lond and home to Rome went
Amonge oþ̉er thingꝭes þat he wan
Hur Chare þat wrouȝte was wᵗith gold ⁊and perrey
This grete Romayn this Aurilian
Hathe wᵗith him ladde for þᵗat men shulde seye
Be forne his tryumphe walkith she
Wᵗith gylt cheynis on hir necke honginge
Crownid she was And Aftir hir degree
And fulle of perrey charged was hir clothinge
Allas fortune sche that whilom was
Dredeful of kynges ⁊and to Emꝑperoʳurs
Now gawreþ alle the peple on hir Allas
And she that helmed was in sterke stoures
Shal on her hede now bere A vitrimete
And she that bare the Ceptre ful of flowers
Shall bere A dystaf / he cost for to quite
O noble o worþy Peter glorye of spayne
Whome fortune helde / so hye in mageste
Wel ouȝte men þy petous dethe Compleyne
Thy bastarde broþ̉er . made the to flee
And Aftir that A sege by subtilite
Thou were be trayed / and ladde to his tente
Wher as he wᵗith his oune honde slowe þe
Succedynge in thi regne ⁊and in thi rente
The felde of snowe wᵗith þe egle of blak þ̉erin
Cauȝt wᵗith þe lyme rodde colours as þᵉ glede
He brewe þis Cursidnesse ⁊and al this synne
The wycked nest was werkere of þis nede
Not Charles olyvere þᵗat aye toke gode hede
Of trowth ⁊and honoʳur / but Armorek
Glenibloun Olivere correpte for mede
Brouȝte þis worthi kynge in suche A breke

l.hi: ¶ De Rege Sypre

div.l: Worthy petre kyng of Sypre Also
Þat Alisaundyr wan be hye mastrie
Ful many an heþen / wrouȝtest þou full woo
Of which þyn owne lyegs had enuye
And for no thing / but for chevalrye
They in the bedde / han slayne the be þe morow
Thus gan fortune goủerne ⁊and gye
And oute of Ioye / bryng into sorowe

l.hi: ¶ De Barnabo Melan

div.l: OF Melan grete barnabe vuscounte
God of delite and skourge of lumbarde
Whi schulde I not thy fortune A counte
Seyn in estate thow Clombe were so hye
Thi broþ̉er sone that was thy double Allye
For he thi neveu was ⁊and þⁱ sone in lawe
Wᵗith in his p̉resone made the to dye
But whi ne howe wote I that þᵘou wer͗e slawe

l.hi: ¶ De counte pyse

div.l: OF hewe erle of pyse þe langoure
Ther may no thing telle for pite
But litle oute of pise þ̉er stonte a toure
In whiche toure in p̉resone put was hee
And wᵗith him ben his litle childerin thre
Þe elder scarsly fyve yeer͗e was of Age
Allas fortune it was grete cruelte
Suche bryddes for to put in A kage
DAmpned he was in that p̉reson to dye
For rogere which þᵗat bishoppe was of pise
And on him A fals sugestioun to Aspie
Thorow which the peple gan on him Aryse
And putten hīm p̉resone in such A wyse
As ye have hard ⁊and mete ⁊and drynk hadde
So smal that it may vnnethe suffice
And þ̉er wᵗith alle it was ful pore ⁊and badde
ON A day be fill that in þᵗat houre
Whan that this was wont to be wrouȝte
The gayler shute the dores of þe toure
He hard it wele but he sawe it nouȝte
And in his herte Anone ther fil A thouȝte
Þat thei for hungre wold do hēm dye
Allas qduod he Allas þᵗat it was wrouȝte
Ther wᵗith the teres felle froo his ye
His yong sone þre yeer͗e was of age
Vnto hīm saide fadir why do ye wepe
Whan wolle the gayler bryng oure potage
Is þ̉er no morsel brede that ye do kepe
I am so hungry that I may not slepe
Now wolde god I myȝt slepen eủer
Than shulde no hung̉er in my wombe crepe
Ther nys no thinge save brede þᵗat me wer͗e lever
Thus day by day þe childe gan to crye
Til in his fadir barme A doun it laye
And saide fadir fare wele I mot deye
And kyste his fadir ⁊and dide the same daye
And whan his wofull fadir dede hīm saye
For woo his armes twoo he gan to byte
And saide fortune Allas ⁊and wellaway
Thy fals wyles my woo Y may wyte
His Childerin that fortune hung̉er was
That he his armes gnowe ⁊and not for woo
And saide fadir do not so Allas
But rathir ete þe fleshe vpon vs too
Oure flessh / þou yavest vs take oure flessh vs froo
And ete y now · ryȝte thus to him þey seyde
And aftir that wᵗith ynne A day or too
They leyde her doune in his lappe ⁊and dide
Hym selfe dispeyrid eke for hung̉er strafe
Thus endid is þe myȝty erle of pyse
Fro hye estate fortune for hīm Carfe
Of this tregedye / it ouȝte y now suffice
Ho so wolle here it in a leng̉er wyse
Redithe the grete poete of ytayle
Þᵗat hyȝt daunte for he can it devise
Fro poynt to poynte not o worde wolle he fayle

l.hi: ¶ De Nero ⸫

div.l: Alle thouȝhe that nero were as vicious
As eny fende that lithe ful low A doune
Yit he as tellythe vs sweþne
This wild worlde hadde in subieccion
Bothe est ⁊and west Septemptreon
Of Rubiis ⁊and saphers And of perles white
Were alle his clothis brovded vp ⁊and dovn
For he in gemmis gretly gan delyte
MOre delicate mor͗e pompꝰus of Array
More proude was neủer Emꝑperoʳur þan he
That ilke clothe that he hadde wered A daye
Aftir that tyme he nold it neủer see
Nettes of golde thred hadde he grete plente
To fisshen in tybre whan hīm lust to pleye
His lustꝭes wer͗e as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frende wolde hīm obeye
HE Rome brent · for his dilicasye
Þe senatoures he slowe vp on A day
To here were men wolde wepe or crye
And slow his broþ̉er ⁊and by his sust̉er laye
His modir made he in pitouse Aray
For he hir wombe slytte to be holde
Wher he Conseyvid was so weylaway
That he so lyte of his modir tolde
NOo tere oute of his yen for þᵗat syȝte
Ne Came · but sayde · a fayre wōmman was she
Grete wondir is þat he couþe or myȝte
Be domesman of here dede beaute
The wyn to brynge comaunded hee
He dronke A non and non oþ̉er worch made
Whanne myȝte is ioyned into crueltee
Allas to depe wolde / þe venym wade
IN yowþe A maist̉er hadde þas Emꝑperoʳur
To teche hīm lettrure ⁊and curiouste
For of moralite he was the floure
As in his tyme but yf bokes lye
And whiles his maist̉er hadde of hīm mastrye
He made him so connynge ⁊and so souple
That longe tyme it was tyrannye
Or eny vice of him dorst vnvncouple
This seneca of which I devise
By cause Nero hadde of hīm suche drede
For he for vices wolde hym chastise
Discretly as by worde ⁊and not by drede
Sere wolde he sayne / an Emꝑperoʳur mote nede
Be vertuous and hate tyrannye
For which in A baþþe he made hīm to blede
On bothe his Armes / til he most dye
This Nero hadde eke of a Custumance
In thouȝte Ayenst his mast̉er for to ryse
Which him þouȝte Aft̉erwarde A grete grevaunce
Þ̉erfore he made him dye in this wyse
But natheles this senek the wyse
Chese in A bathe to dye in this man̉ere
Raþ̉er than mo oþir turmotyse
And thus hathe nero slayn his mast̉er der͗e
Nowe felle it so that fortune leste no leng̉er
The hye pryde of Nero to cheryshe
For thouȝe · he were stronge / yit was streng̉er
She thouȝte thus by god / I am to nyce
To sett A man þat is fulfillid of vice
In hye dregre / and Emꝑperour hīm Calle
By god oute of his sete / I wolle hīm tryce
Whan he best wenithe sonnest shalle he falle
The peple roos vp on him on A nyȝte
For his defaute · and when he it Aspied
Oute at his dores anon he hathe him dyȝte
Allone and þ̉er he wende han ben allyed
He knokkid faste and ay þe mor͗e he cride
Þe faster shetten thei the dores alle
Tho wiste he welle he hadde him selfe mys gyde
And wente his wey no lengor wolde he calle
The peple cryde ⁊and Rumbled vp ⁊and doun
That wᵗith his eris herde he how þei saide
Wher is this fals traytour þis Nerou
For fere almoste oute of his wynte he brayde
And to his goddes petousely he saide
For socoure . but it myȝte not be tyde
For drede of this him þouȝte þᵗat he dide
And ran in to A gardyn him selfe to hyde
And in this gardyn fond he cherles tweye
Þat setyn by A fyre ful grete ⁊and Rede
And to this cherles twey he gan to praye
To sleen him ⁊and to gyrden of his hede
That to his body / whan that he wer͗e dede
Were no dispite . y do for his defame
Him selfe he slow he Couþe no bett̉er rede
Of whiche fortune lowe ⁊and made A game
WAs neủer A Capten vndir A kynge
That regnes mo put in subieccion
Ne streng̉er was in the felde of Al thinge
As in his tyme ne grett̉er of renoune
Ne more pompus in heye p̉resumpsion
Thanne oliferne which fortune ay keste
So lecrously ⁊and ladde hīm vp ⁊and doun
Tille that his hede was of or þᵗat he wyst
Not only that this worlde had of hīm awe
For lusynge of richesse ⁊and of liberte
But he made eủery man reneye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lorde saide he
Non oþ̉er god shold honoured be
A yenst his hest / no wyȝte dare trespasse
Save in Betulia A stronge Citee
Wher Elyachym / A prest was of the place

l.hi: ¶ De Oliferno ⸫

div.l: BVt take kepe of the dethe of Oleferne
A mydde his oste he dronke laye a nyȝte
Wᵗith ynne his tente large as is A berne
And yitte for Al his pompe ⁊and al his myȝte
Iudithe A womman as he lay vp ryȝte
Slepynge his hede of smote ⁊and fro his tente
Ful prively she stalle fro eủery wyȝte
And in to the Cite with it she wente

l.hi: ¶ De Rege anteocheo //

div.l: What nedith it of kyng Anteoch us
To telle his heye ⁊and Riall magestes
His hye pryde his werke venemous
For suche A noþ̉er nas neủer none but hee
Redethe which he was in Machabe
And redithe the proude wordes þᵗat he sayde
And while he felle fro his prosꝑperitee
And in an hulle how wrecchidly he dyde
FOrtune him hadde an haunced so in pryde
Þat verraly he wende he myȝte enteyne
Vnto the sterres vp on eủery syde
And in A balaunce to weye þe mounteyn
And alle the flodes of the se restreyne
And goddes peple hadde he most in hate
Hem wolde he slee in turment ⁊and in peyne
Wenyng that god ne myȝte his pride Abate
ANd for þᵗat Nichamoure / ⁊and Tymothe
Wᵗith Iewes were venqysshed myȝtly
Vn to the Iues suche an hate had he
That he hadde grevid his . chare ful hastely
And swore and saide ful spitously
Vn to Ierlm̄Ierusalem wolde he efte sone
To wreke his yre on hit full cruelly
But of his purpose he was lette ful sone
GOd of his manas him so sore smote
Wᵗith in visible woundes ay vncurable
That in his guttꝭes Carfe so Aboute
That his peynes were inportable
And Certeynely þe wreche was resonable
For many manes guttꝭes dede he peyne
But for his purpose Cursid ⁊and dampnable
For al his smerte he nolde hīm restreyne
BVt badde A none Apparayle his hoste
And sodenly or he was of hit ware
God daunted alle his pride ⁊and alle his bost
For he so sore felle oute of his chare
That hurt his lemes ⁊and his skynne to tare
So that he ne myȝt goo ne Ryde
But in A chayer men A boute hīm bare
Al for brused bothe bak ⁊and syde
The wreche of god hīm smote so cruelly
That in his body wickid wormes crepe
And þ̉er wᵗith all he stonke so horribley
Þᵗat none of alle his meyne that hīm kepte
Wheþ̉er that he wake or ellꝭes slepe
Ne myȝte not the stynke of him endure
In this myschef he waylid ⁊and eke wepte
And knew god his lorde to fore eny creature
TO alle his hoste ⁊and to hīm selfe Also
Ful fulsom was the stynk of his carayne
No man myȝte hīm bere too ⁊and froo
And in his stynke ⁊and in his horible peyne
He straff full wrecchidly in A mounteyne
Thus hathe this robboure ⁊and homiside
That many A man made to wepe ⁊and pleyne
Such gwerdon / as by longith vnto pryde

l.hi: ¶ De Alexandre

div.l: The storye of Alesaundre is so comune
Þat eủery wyȝt that hath discresioun
Hath harde somwhat / or all of his fortune
This wyde worlde as in Conclusioune
He wan be strenght or for his hyȝe renoun
They were gladde for pes vnto hīm sende
Þe pryde of man ⁊and best he leyde A doun
Wher so he Cam vn to the worldes ende
Comparyson myȝt neủer be maked
By twene any oþ̉er conqueroure
For all this worlde for drede of hym quakid
He was of knyȝthode ⁊and of fredom floure
Fortune him made þe hyer of hir honoʳur
Save wyn ⁊and women no thing myȝt a swage
His hye entente in Armes ⁊and laboure
So was he ful of levyng Corage
What pete were it to hīm þow I yow tolde
Of daryous and an hundred thousand moo
Of kynges pryncꝭes ⁊and erles bolde
Whiche he conquerde ⁊and broute him into woo
I say as ferr͗e as men may ryde or goo
Þe worlde was his what shulde I mor͗e devise
For thow y wryte ⁊and told yow eủer moo
Of his knyȝthode it myȝte not suffice
Twelfe yeer͗e he regnid as seyþe machabe
Philippes sone of Masidone was hee
That ferst was kynge of Grece þe contree
O worthi gentill Alisaundre / Allas qduod he
That eủere schulde falle in suche degree
Enpoysonid of thi folke thow were
Thi fortune in to An asse hathe turnid þe
And yit for the ne wepe sche neủer A tere
Hoo shall yeue teres me to cōmpleyne
The dethe of gentilnesse ⁊and of Fraunchise
That alle the worlde welde in his de mayne
And yitt him thouȝte it myȝte not suffice
So ful was hir Corage of heye Empryse
Allas hoo shalle me helpe to endite
Fals fortune ⁊and poysen to dispise
The which too of al this woo I wyte
By wysdom manhode ⁊and by laboure
Fro humblehede ⁊and fro riall mageste
Vp ros Iulius / þe noble Conqueroure
That all the Occident by londe ⁊and by see
By strenght of honde or ellꝭes by trete
And vn to Rome made hem tributarie
And seþens of Rome þe Emꝑperoʳur was he
Til that fortune / waxe his Adủersarye
¶ De Cesare
O Myȝti Cesare that in tessalye
A yenst pompeus fadyr thyn in lawe
That of the oryente hadde Alle þe Chevalrye
As fer as the day bryngeth to dawe
Thorow thi knythode / hast him take ⁊and slawe
Save A fewe folke that wᵗith pompeus fledde
For the which þow puttist alle þe oryent in Awe
Thonke fortune þat þe so wele spedde
BVt now A litle while I wolle be wayle
This pompeus þis noble goủernoure
Of Rome which that fleye at this bataiƚƚlle
I sey one of his men a fals traytour
His hede of smote to wynne him favoure
Of Iulius ⁊and him the hede brouȝte
Allas pompeous of the orient conquerour͗e
That fortune vn to suche A fyne brouȝte
TOo Rome A yene repayrith Iulius
Wᵗith his tryvmphe lauriat ful hyȝe
But on A tyme Brutus Casseus
That oủer hadde of his estate envye
Ful prevely had made conspiratory
A yenst this Iulius in subtylwyse
And caste þe place on whiche he shulde dye
Wᵗith boydkyns ⁊and I shall yow devis
This Iulius to the Capitole went
Vp on A day as he was wonte to gone
And in the Capitole A none hīm hente
This fals brutus ⁊and his fals foon
Han stikid hīm / wᵗith boydkyns a none
Wᵗith many A wounde ⁊and þus þei lete hīm lye
But neủer grunte he att noo stroke but one
Or ellꝭes at too but yf his story lye
SO manly was this Iulius of herte
And so welle loved estatly honeste
Þat Þouȝe his dedely wondes so sore smerte
His mantell oủer his hepes cast hee
For no man shulde see his p̉revitee
And as he lay in dyenge on A traunce
And wist verraly þᵗat dede was he
Of heneste yit hadde he remembraunce
LVcane to this storye I recomende
And to sweton ⁊and to valerious Also
Þᵗat of this story writethe worde ⁊and ende
How that these grete cōnqueroures too
Fortune was hir frende ⁊and Aftir hir foo
No man trust vpon his fauour͗e longe
But have here in A wayte eủer moo
Wytnesse of All þes conquerous stronge
¶ De Gresus
This rich gresus whilom kynge of lyde
Of whiche gresus sequnis sord hīm dradde
Yit was he Cauȝte amonges all this pryde
And to be brente men to the fuyre hīm ladde
But suche arayne doun fro the walken shadde
Þat slowe the fyre ⁊and made him to escape
But to be ware yitt no grace he hadde
Til fortune on the galous made hīm gape
Whanne he escaped was Can̄ne he not stynte
For to be gynne A new regne A yene
He wend wele for that fortune hīm sent
Suche happe þᵗat he escaped þorouȝe þe rayne
That of his foos he myȝt not be slayne
A suche A sweven vpon A nyȝte he mette
Of whiche he was so proude ⁊and eke so fayne
That he in vengeaunce all his hert sette
Opon A tree he was as him thouȝte
Þer Iubit̉er him wysshe bothe hals ⁊and syde
And phebus eke a fayre to wayle hīm brouȝte
To drye hīm wᵗith ⁊and þ̉erfore waxe his pryde
And to his douȝt̉er that stode hym besyde
Which that he knewe in heye sentence abounde
He badde hir telle what hit signified
And she his dreme þus expounde
The tree quod she the galows is to mene
And Iubiter by tokenith snowe ⁊and rayne
And phebus wᵗith his towayle so clene
Tho bene the sonne stremes for to sayne
Þou shalt an honged be fadir Certeyne
Rayne shall the wasshe and sonne shalle þe drye
Þus warned she him ful platte ⁊and ful playne
His douȝt̉er þat callid was phavye
AN honged was gresus þe proude kynge
His Riall trone myȝt him noȝt avayle
Tregedys is non oþ̉er man̉er thinge
Ne canne in synnynge / crye ne be wayle
But that fortune alwey wolle assayle
Wᵗith vnware stroke þe reynes that ben proude
For whanne / men trustithe hir than wolle she fayle
And Coủer hir bryȝt face wᵗith a cloude
O noble o worthi petre glorie of Spayne
Whom fortune helde so highe in mageste
Wel oughten men this pitous dethe cōmpleyne
Out of thi lande thi broþ̉er made þe flee
And aftir at a sege be subtiliite
Þou were betraisshed ⁊and lad vn to his tente
Where as he wᵗith his owne honde slewe þe
Succeding in þi regne and in thi rente
The felde of snowe wᵗith þe Egle of blak þ̉erynne
Chaught wᵗith þe lymerod colourid al wᵗith glede
He brewe this tursidnesse ⁊and all this synne
Þe wiked nest was worker of this nede
Nought charles Olyuer that toke Ay hede
Of trowþe and honoʳur but of Armorike
Genylon Olyuer corupt for mede
Brought this worthi king / to such A brike
O worthi petre / king of Cipre Alsoo
Þat Alisaundir wan bi hygh mastrie
Ful many an hethen wroughtest þou woo
Of which tweyne oune liges hadde envie
And for no thing but for thi cheualrie
Thei in thi bed han slayne þe by þe morow
Þus can fortune hire wheel gouerne ⁊and gie
And oute of Ioye bryng men to sorowe
OF milayne gret Gernabo viscoıı̄unte
God of delite and scorge of lumbardie
Whi shulde I nowe þi in fortune acoıı̄unte
Syn in estate þou clomben were so hye
Thi broþers soone þat was thi double allye
For he thi nevew was ⁊and soone in lawe
Wiþ inne his p̉resoune made the to dye
But whi ne how not I / þat þou were slawe
OF the Erle hugelyn of pise þe langoʳur
Ther may no . tunge telle for pitee
But litle out of pize stant A toure
In which toure in pⁱrisoune put was he
And wᵗith him ben his litle childerin thre
Þe eldest scarsly fyve yere was of age
Allas fortune it was grete cruelte
Suche briddis to put in suche a cage
DAmpned was he to die in þᵗat preson
For Rogier whiche þat bisshop of pize
Had on him made a fals suggestion
Þurgh þe peple gan vp on him Arise
And put him in prison in suche wyse
As ye haue harde and mete ⁊and drinke he hadde
And þerwithal it was ful pore ⁊and badde
And on a day be fille þᵗat in þᵗat houre
When that his met wont was to be broute
Þe Gailoʳur shette þe dores of the toure
He harde it wel but he spake right nought
And in his herte a noon þ̉er fille a þought
Þat they for hung̉er wolde don hīm dien
Allas quod he allas þᵗat I was wrouȝ
Þer with þe teris fille from his eien
His yonge son þat þre yere was of age
Vn to him saide fadir fadir whi do ye wepe
When wil þe gailour bringe vs potage
Is þer no morcel brede þᵗat ye do kepe
I am so hungry / þat I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I myȝt slepe eủere
Þan̄ne shulde not hıı̄unger in my wombe crepe
Þere nys no thing but brede þᵗat me were leủer
Thus dai be dai this childe be gan to crie
Tyl in his fadris barme A doune it lay
And saide farewel fadir I mot dye
And kist his fadir and dide þe same daie
And whan the woful fadir this thing sai
Fo woo his armees too he gan to byte
And saide allas fortune and weilaway
Þi fals whele my wo al may I wite
His chelderin wende / that it for hung̉er was
Þat he his armes gnow and not for woo
And seiden fadir do not so Allas
But rather ete the flessh vpon vs too
Oure Flessh þᵘou gaff vs take oure Flessh vs froo
And ete I now þus thei to hīm saide
And aftir that wiþinne a day or too
Þei leyde hem in his lappe a doıı̄une ⁊and dide
Him selfe despeired eke for hunger starfe
Þus endid is this myȝti erle of pize
From hye estate fortune awey him carf
Of this tragedie it ought I nough suffise
Who so wolde here it in A leng̉er wyse
Redeþ the gret poete of Itayle
Þat hight daıı̄unt for he can it Al devise
From point to point nat a worde wol he fayle
¶ Here stintith þe knyȝt þe monk of his tale
¶ Here stintith þe knyȝt þe monk of his tale
O quod the knyȝt gode sir nomere of this
Þat ye haue saide is ryȝt I now I wis
And moche more for litle heuynesse
Is ryght I now for moch folke I gesse
Yoʳur talis Don vs no disport nor game
Þerfor sir monke . o daıı̄un pers by your name
I pray you hertli telle vs sumwhat eles
For sikirli nere for clynkyng of yoʳur bellis
Þat on yoʳur bridel hongen on eủery syde
Be hevene kyng that for vs Al dide
I shulde er this have falen doıı̄un for slepe
Al þow the snowe had neủere ben so depe
Þan had yoʳur tale al be tolde in veyne
For certayne as þat þes clerkes seien
Wher as a man may have noon audience
Nouȝt helpith to telle his sentence
And wel I wot þe substaunce is in me
Yf any thing shal wel reportid be
Sir seie sumwhat of huntyng I you praye
Nay quod this monke / I have no lust to plaie
Now late A noþ̉er telle as I have tolde
Þan spake our host with rude speche ⁊and bolde
And saide vn to nōnnys prest A noon
Come nere thow prest come hedir þᵘou sir Iohn̄an
Tel vs such thing as may oure hartꝭes glade
Be blithe þowe þou ride vp on A Iade
What thowe þi horse be boþe foule ⁊and lene
Yf he wil serue the rekke not a bene
Loke þat thi hartis be merye euer moo
Ȝis sir qduod he ȝis sir so mot I goo
But I be merie I wis I wil be blamed
And ryȝt a noon his tale he hathe a tamed
And þus he saide vnto vs eủerychone
This swete prest þis gooli man sir Iohn̄an

Here begynnith þe nōnne preste
of chauntclere ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~
A Pore wedow somdele steppid in Age
Was some tyme dwellyng in A narow cotage
Be syde a greue stonding in a dale
Þis widow of which I telle yow my tale
Syn that ilke day þat she was last awyf
In paciens ladde a ful simple lyf
For litle was hir Cataiƚƚlle / and hir rente
By husbondrye of suche as god hir sent
She fonde hir self ⁊and eke hir Doughtren too
Thre large sowes had she and nomoo
Thre keen and eke a shepe þat hight malle
Ful soti was hir boure and eke hir halle
In whiche she ete ful many A slender mele
Of poynaıı̄unt sauce she nedide neủer a dele
No deynte morcelle passed þurgh hir͗e þrote

And Rusel þe fox stert vp at ones
And bi þe gorget hent chauntclere
And on hys bak to the wode hīm ber͗e
For yitt þ̉er nene was noman that hīm suyd
O destene that mayst nat ben eschued
Allas that chauntclere flie from þe bemes
Allas his wyf ne rauȝt not of dremes
And on A friday fil al this myschaunse
O Venus þᵗat art goddesse of plesaunce
Syn þat þi ʆseruᵃaunt was þis chauntclere
And in thi seruice dede al his powere
More for delite þan worlde to multeplie
Why · woldest þu suffre him on þi dai to dye
O gaufride Dere master souerayne
Þat whan þi worthi kynge Richard was slayne
With shot compleynedist his deþe so sore
Whi ne had I not þi centense ⁊and þi lore
The fryday sothli slayne was he
Þan wolde I shewen how þat I coude pleyne
For chauntcleris drede / ⁊and for his peyne
Certis suche crie ne lamentacion
Was neủere of ladies made whan ylion
Was wonne and pirrus wᵗith his streit swerde
When he hadde hent kyng priame by þe berde
And slain hīm as seith vs Enidos
As maden alle þe hēnnes in the clos
Whan thei had of chauntclere þe syȝte
But soueraynely dame ꝑpertelot shriht
Ful louder þan dede hasturbalis wyf
Whan that hir husbonde had I lost his lyf
And that the romaynes had brent cartage
She was so ful of turnement ⁊and of rage
Þat wilfulli in to the fere she starte
And brent hir selfe wᵗith a stedfast harte
O wofull hennes ryȝt so criden yee
As whan that nero brende þe Citee
Of Rome criden Senatoʳurs wyfes
For that hir husbondes losten al hir lyfes
Wᵗith outen gylte this Nero hathe hēm slayne
Now wolle I turne to my tale a gayne
The sele wedow and eke hir dougtren too
Harden þies hēnnys crie and maken woo
And oute at þe dores sterte þei a noon
And seen the fox toward the grove goon
And bare vpōn his bak / þe cokke A wai
And cride out harow and wellaway
Ha · ha · þe fox / and aftir hīm they ran
And eke wᵗith stoues many A noþir man
Ran colle our Dogge ⁊and talbot and Garlond
And malkyn wᵗith a distaff in hir hande
Ran cowe ⁊and calf / and eke þe verrye hoggꝭes
For ferd for barkyng of þe doggꝭes
And shoutyng of the men and women eke
Þei ronne so þei þouȝt hire herte breke
Þey yelleden as fendes done in helle
Þe dokis criden as men wolde hēm quelle
Þe geis for fere flouen oủere þe trees
Out of þe hive cōm the swarme of bees
So hydous was þe noise · a benedicite
Certis ȝe Iacke straw ⁊and his meyne
Ne made neủere shoutis halfe so shirle
Whan that thei wolde any flemyngis gille
As þilke day was made vp on þe fo
Of bras thei brought bemys ⁊and of box
Of horne ⁊and boone in wiche þei blewe ⁊and poupid
And þ̉erwᵗith alle þei scrikid ⁊and þei houpid
Hit semid as that heuene shulde falle
Now godemen herkenith I pray yow alle
Lo how fortune turnithe sodenly
The hope / and pride eke of hir enmy
Þis cok that lay vp on this foxis bak
In al his Drede vn to þe fox he spake
And saide sir yf that I were as ye
Yitt wolde seien as wis god helpe me
Turnithe a geyne ȝe proude cherlis alle
A verray pestelens vppon you falle
Now I am come vn to þe wode syde
Maugre yoʳur hede the cok shal her͗e A byde
I wol him in feith ⁊and that a noon
Þe fox answerd in feiþe it shalle be done
And as he spake that word al sodeinly
Þe cok brak from his mouþe deliủerly
And high vpon a tree he flie a noon
And whan the fox saw that he was gon
Allas qduod he . O . chauntclere Allas
I have to you qduod he IIdone trespas
In as muche as makid you A ferde
Whan I you hent ⁊and brouȝt in to this ȝerde
But sir I dede it in no wikke entente
Come doune ⁊and I shaƚƚ telle you what I ment
I shaƚƚ sai sothe to you god helpe me so
Nay þan qduod he I sherue vs bothe too
And first I shrew my selfe boþe blode ⁊and bonis
Yf þᵘou be gyle me eny ofter than onys
Þou shalt nomore þoughe þi flaterie
Do me to synge ⁊and wynk wᵗith myn Ie
For he that wynkith whanne he shulde se
Al wylfully god lete him neủer thee
Nay qduod the fox but god geve hīm myschaunce
That is so vndiscret of goủernaıı̄unce
Þat Iangelithe while he shulde holde his pes
Lo suche it is for to ben recheles
And necligent and trust on flaterie
But ye that holden this tale a folie /
As of A fox or A cok and henne
Takith þe moralite good menne
For seint paule seithe al þᵗat wretyn is
To oure doctrine it is I wrete I wys
Takithe the frute / and let þe chaf be stille
Now gode god yf that it be thi wille
As sey myn lord / so make vs al gode men
And bringe vs to his hie blisse amen
Here Endithe þe nōnne prestꝭes tale
The mery wordes of / þe hoste to þe cook of londoıı̄un
Wot ye not wher þ̉er stant A litle toune
Whiche that I clepid is bobbe vp ⁊and doıı̄un
Vndir the ble in Caunt̉erburie weie
Þ̉ere gan oure host for to iape ⁊and pleie
And saide siris what doıı̄un is in miere
Is þ̉er noman for prayere ne for hire
Þat wolle awake oure felow here be hinde
A thef myȝte ful liȝghtly hīm robbe ⁊and bynde
Se how he nappith se how for cokkis bonis
Þat he wolle falle from his hors at onys
Is that a cook of london wᵗith myschaunce
Do him Come forthe he knowith his penaunce
For he shaƚƚ telle atale be my feye
Al þou it be not worthe A boteƚƚ heye
A wake thou cook qduod he god yeue þe sorowe
What eylith þe to slepe by þe morow
Hast þou had flen al nyȝt or art þᵘou dronke
Or hast þᵘou wᵗith some quene Al nyȝte I swonke
So þat þᵘou maist not holde vp thi hede
Þis cook that was ful pale ⁊and nothing rede
Seide to oure hoste so god me blisse
As þer is fallyn on me suche heuinesse
Not I not whi þat me were leủere to slepe
Than þe best galon wyne in chepe
Wel qduod þe maıı̄unciple yf it may don ese
To the sir cook ⁊and to no wyȝt displese
Which that here rideþe in þis cūmpanye
And that oure host wil of his curtesie
I wol as now excuse the of thi tale
For in gode feiþe þi visage is ful pale
Þin ien daswe eke as that me thinkith
And wel I wote þi brethe ful soule stinkiþ
Þat shewith wel þᵘou art not wele disposid
Of me certeyne thow shalt not be I glosid
Se how he gamith loo this dronkin wyght
As þowe he wolde swelwe vs a noon right
Holde clos thi mouthe man be thi fadir kyn
Þe devil of helle sette his fote þerin
Þi cursid brethe wil enfecte vs alle
Fy stynkyng swyne fie foule mot thow be falle
A takiþ hede sirs of this lusty man
Now swete siris wol ye Iust at fanne
Þ̉er to me thinkith ye ben ryght wel I shape
I trowe þat ye dronken han wyn of ape
And that is whan men pleien wᵗith a straue
And wᵗith his speche the cook wex wroth ⁊and wraue
And on þe maıı̄unciple / he gan nodde fast
For lakke of spech adoune þe horse him caste
Wher as he lay til that they him vp toke
This was a faire chaunce of A cook
Allas ne hadde he holde him be his ladil
And ar that he agayne were in his sadil
Þ̉er was a gret showyng / boþe too ⁊and froo
To lyfte him vp and muche care ⁊and woo
So vnweli was þis sori pallis gost
And to the maıı̄unciple þan spake oure hoste
Be cause drinke hath dominacion
Vpon this man bi my saluacion
I trowe lewdeli he wold tel his tale
For were it wyn or old and mosti ale
Þat he haþ dronken he spekithe in his nose
And fnseþ faste and eke he hathe þe pose
He hathe also to done more þan̄ne I nowe
To kepe him ⁊and his caple oute of the slowhe
And yf he falle from his caple eft sone
Þan shall we aƚƚ han I now to done
To lyften his heuy dronken cors
Telle on þi tale of him make no forse
But ȝitt in feyth maıı̄unciple þᵘou arte nyce
Þvs opinly repreue him of his vice
A noþ̉er day he wolle ꝑparauenture
Reclayme þe ⁊and brynge the to lure
I mene he speke wolle of smale thinges
As for to pinche at þīn Rekenyngꝭes
Þat were not honest yf that it come to pref
No quod the maıı̄unciple þᵗat were A gret myschef
So myȝt he lightly bringe me in the snare
Ȝitt had I leủere paien for þe Mare
Whiche that he rit on þan he shulde wᵗith me stryve
I wolle not wrathe him Also mut I thryve
Þat þat I spake I seide but in borde
And wite ye welle I have here in A gorde
A drauȝte of wyne ȝa of A ripe grape
And ryght a noon ȝe shul se A good Iape
Þis cook shaƚƚ drinke þer of yf I may
Vp peyne of dethe he wil not sey me nay
And Certeinli to tellin as it was
Of this vessel þis cook drank fast allas
What nedithe hīm he drank / I now be forne
And whan he had poupid in this horne
To the Maıı̄unciple he took / þe gord A gayne
And of that drynke þe cook was wondir fayne
And thankid him in such wyse as he coude
Þan gan oure host to lawhe wondir loude
And seide I se wel it is necessarie
Wher that we gone we good drinke wᵗith vs carie
For that wil turne rancoʳur ⁊and dissese
To accorde ⁊and loue and many a wronge Appese
O bacus / I blessid be thi name
Þᵗat so canst turne ernist in to game
Worshipe and thanke be to þi deite
Of that matiere / ye gete namore of me
Tel on thi tale Maıı̄unciple I þe pray
Wel sir quod he harkenith what I shaƚƚ say
Her begynnyth þe Mānciple tale
Whan phebus duellid here in þis erthe adoıı̄un
As olde bokes maken mencion
He was the most lusty bachelere
In aƚƚ this worlde ⁊and eke the best Archere
He slow phiton the serpent as he lay
Sleping A gein the sonne vpon a day
And many anoþ̉er noble worthi dede
He wᵗith his bowe wrought as ye may rede
Pleien he Coude on eủerye mynstralsye
And syngen þat it was A melodye
To herin of his clere vois þe soune
Certis the kynge / of thebes Amphion
Þat wᵗith his singing wallid þe Citee
Coude neủer sing half so wel as he
Ther to he was þe semliest man
Þat is or was sithe that þe worlde began
What nedithe it his fetures to discriue
For in this worlde was noon so faire on lyve
He was þ̉erwᵗith fulfillid of gentillesse
Of honoʳur ⁊and of ꝑparfite worthinesse
Þis phebus that was flour͗e of bachelerie
As wel in fredom as in chevalrie
For his disporte in signe eke of victorie
Of phiton so as telliþe vs þe storie
Was wonte to beren in his honde a bowe
Now had this phebꝫus in his house A crowe
Whiche in a cage he fosterde mony A day
And taught it speke as men teche a iaie
White was this crowe as a snowe white swan
And coıı̄unt̉erfetid the speche of eủerye man
He / coude whan he shuld telle A tale
Þer wᵗith in al this worlde no nightingale
Ne coude bi an hndirde þousand dele
Syngen so wondir mereli and wel
Now had þis phebus in his house A wyf
Which that he louid more than his lyf
And night and dai dede al his deligens
Hir for to plece and done hir reủerence
Saff onli þe soþe þᵗat I shaƚƚ seyn
Ialous he was and wolde have kepte hire fayne
For him were lothe be iapid for to be
And so is eủery wyȝt in suche degre
But al in Idel for it Avaylith nouȝte
A good wyf þat is clene in werke and þought
Shulde not be kepte in noon await certeyn
And truli þe labour is in vayne
To kepe a shrewe for it wil not be
Þis holde I for a verray vanyte
To spil labour for to kepe wyves
Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyves
But now to pʳurpos as I first be gan̄
Þis worthi phebus doþ al that he can
To plesen hire wenyng þᵗat such plesaunce
And for his manhed ⁊and his goủernaunce
Þat noman shulde have put hir from hir gᵃrace
But god it wot þer mai noman enbrace
As to descryve a thing which þat nature
Hath naturelli set in a Creature
Take any þing and put it in A cage
And do al þi entent and þi corage
To foster it tendirli wᵗith mete ⁊and drinke
Of alle deynteis þᵗat þᵘou canst be thinke
And kepe it Also clenli as þou may
And þow his cage of golde be neủere so gay
Yitt hath this bird be þoused folde
Leủere in A forest þᵗat is rude ⁊and colde
Go ete wormys ⁊and suche wrecchidnesse
For eủere this bird wol done his busines
To escape oute of his cage yf he may
His liberte this bird desirith aye
Lete take a cat ⁊and forster hīm wel wᵗith mylke
And tendre flesshe ⁊and make his couch of sylke
And late him se A mouse go bi the walle
Anoon he levith mylke ⁊and flesshe and al
And eủery deynte þat is in that hous
Suche appetit haþ he to ete A mous
Lo here haþ lust his d̄omnacion
And appetit flemith discrecion
A she wolf hath Also A diủerse kynde
Þe lewdest wolfe that she mai fynde
Or lest of reputacion that wolle she take
In tyme whan hir lust to han A make
Alle thes ensamples speke I bi þise men
Þat ben vntrue and no þing bi women
For men haue eủere A likerous Apetite
On lower thing to ꝑparforme hir delite
Þat on hir wyfes be thei neủer so faire
Ne neủere so trewe ne neủer so debonayre
Flessh is so newfangil wᵗith myschaunce
Þat we ne cānne in no thing have plesaunce
Þat sounyth into vertu ony while
Þis phebus which þᵗat thought on no gyle
Desceyuid was for al hir Iolyte
For vndir him a noþ̉er had she
A man of litle reputacion
Not worþ to phebus in cōmꝑparisoıı̄un
Þe more harme is it oft happithe s
Of whiche þ̉er comyth moch harme ⁊and woo
And so by fille þat phebus was absent
His wyf a noon haþ forþ his leman sent
Hir leman Certꝭes this is A knavishe speche
For yeueþ it me and þat I yow be seche
The wyse plato seith as ye may rede
Þe worde mot accorde nede wᵗith þe dede
Yf men shal telle propirly a þinge
Þe worde mot Cosin be to the werkynge
I am a boistus man ryȝt þus sei y
Þer is no dyfferens truly
Be twyxte A wyf of hie degree
If of hir body dishonest she be
But þat þe gentil in state aboue
She shalle be Clepid his lady as in loue
And for that oþ̉er is a pore woman
She shalle be clepid his wenche or his leman
And god it wote mȳn owne dere broþir
Men leyn þat on as low as þᵗat oþir
Right so betwixt a titleles teraunt
And an outlawe or A thef erraıı̄unt
Þe same I seye þ̉er is no dyfference
To Alisaundir was tolde þis sentence
That for the tiraunt is of grett̉er myght
Be force of meyne for to sle don right
And brenne hous and home ⁊and make al pleyne
Lo þ̉erfore is he clepid a capteyne
And for the outlawe hath but smal meyne
And may not done as grete an harme as he
Ne bringe a contre to so grete a myschef
Men clepe him an outlawe or a thef
But for I am a man not textuel
I wol not telle of textis neuer a dele
I wol go to my tale as I be gan
Whan phebus wyf hath sent for hir lēmmān
Anoon thei wroughten Al hir lust volage
The white crow that henge aie in þe cage
Bihelde hir werke and saide neủere A worde
And whan þat home comen was phebus þe lorde
Þis crow song cokkow / Cokkow cokkow
What birde qduod phebus song singist þou
Ne were þou wone so mereli to synge
That to my hert is was a reioisinge
To hir þi vois / allas wat ioie is þis
By god qduod he I syng not A mys
Phebus qduod he for al thi worthines
For al thi beute and al thi gentilles
For al thi songe / and al þi mynstralsye
For al thi wayting blerid is þin ye
Wᵗith one of litle Reputacion
Not worth to the in cōmputacion
Þe moıı̄untaıı̄unce of A gnat so mut I þrive
For on thi bedde thi wyfe I sawe hīm swive
What wol ye more þe crowe a noon him tolde
By sadde tokeins and bi wordes bolde
How þat his wyf had don hir͗e lecherie
Him to grete shame ⁊and to grete velany
And tolde hīm often he saw it with his ien
This phebꝫus aweyward gan to wrien
And þought his sorowful harte gan to brast a too
His bow he bent and sett þ̉erin A flo
And in his yre his wyf þan haþe he slayne
This is þefecte þ̉er is nomore to seyne
For sorow of which he brake his mynstralsie
Bothe harpe and lute and geteryn ⁊and sautrie
And he brake eke his arowis ⁊and his bowe
And aftir that þus spake he to þe crowe
Traytoʳur qduod he wᵗith tonge of scorpione
Thou hast me brought to my cōnfusion
Allas þat I was wrought whi nere I ded
O dere wyf o gem of lustihed
Þat were to me so sad ⁊and eke so trewe
Now list þou ded wᵗith face pale of heve
Ful giltles þat durst I swere I wysse
O racle hande to do so foule A mys
O trowble wit O Ire recheles
Þat vnauysid smytest gyltles
O wantrust ful of fals suspecion
Wher was thi witte and þⁱ discrecion
O eủery man be ware of rakilnesse
Ne trow no thing wᵗithouten gret wytnesse
Smyte not to sore er than ye weten whie
And bethe Avisid wel ⁊and sobirly
Er ye done any execucion
Vpon yoʳur Ire for suspecion
Allas A þousand folke / han rakil Ire
Fully fordon hathe brought hēm in þe myr͗e
Allas for sorow I wol my seluen slee
And to þe Crouue o fals thef qduod he
I wolle the quite A noon þⁱ fals tale
Thou songe whilom lich A nyghtingale
Now shalt þou fals þef thi songe for gone
And eke thi whight feþeris eủerychone
Neủer in al thi lyf ne shalt þow speke
Thus shalle men on a traytoʳur ben I wreke
Þou and þin of spring shul be blake
Ne neủer swete noyse shul ye make
But eủere Crie ayene tempest ⁊and Rayne
In tokyn þat þorgh þe my wyf is slayne
And to þe crou he starte ⁊and þᵗat A noon
And pullid his white fetheris eủerych
And maked hīm blak ⁊and Rafte hīm al his songe
And eke his spech and oute at dore hīm slong
Vn to the devil whiche I him be take
And for þis Cas ben al crouis blake
Lordingꝭes bi this exaıı̄unpil I yow pray
Bethe ware and takithe kepe what I seye
Ne lete neủer noman in youre lyf
How that Anoþir man hathe dight his wyf
He wille yow haten mortalli Certeyn
Daıı̄un salamon as wise clerkes seine
Techith A man to kepe his tonge weƚƚ
But as I saide I am not textuel
But natheles this taught me my dame
Mi sone þinke on þe crowe A goddis nake
My sone kepe wel þi tunge ⁊and kepe þi frend
A wikid tunge is werse þan A fende
Mi sone from A fend men may hem blisse
Mi sone god of his endles godnes
Wallid A tonge wᵗith tethe ⁊and lippis eke
For man shulde A vise hīm what he spekith
My sone ful ofte for to moch speche
Hathe many man ben spilte as clerkꝭes teche
But for litle spech aviseli
I noman shent to speke genralli
My sone thi tong shuldest þᵘou restreyne
Att alle tymes but whan þᵘou doist þi peyne
To speke of god in honoʳur and praier͗e
Þe first vertu sone yf þᵘou wolt lere
Is to restreyne and kepe wel þi tonge
Þus lerne Childern whan that þei be yonge
My sone of mekyƚƚ spekyng / il Avisi
Þer lasse speking / I now suffisid
Comithe muche harme it was me tolde ⁊and tauȝt

div.l: In / michel speche synne wantith nought
Wist þou wher of rakil tonge seruith
Ryght as a swerd for kittiþ and for kervith
On arme or to my dere sone right so
A tunge kittith frendshipe alle a too
A Iangeler is to god abhominable
Rede Salamon so wis ⁊and honoʳurable
Rede Dauith in his psalme rede seneke
Mi sone speke not but wᵗith þi hede þᵘou bek
Dissimile as þᵘou were def yf þᵗat þᵘou her͗e
A / Iangeler speke of ꝑperlious mater͗e
Þe flemyng seith ⁊and lerne it yf þe lyst
Þat litle Iangelyng Causithe moch rest
My sone yf thou no wikid word hast saide
Þe þarnot drede þe for to be bevraide
But he that hath myssayde I dar wel sain
He may be nowey Cleple his worde agayne
Thing þᵗat is saide is saide ⁊and forthe it goþe
Þow him repente or be hīm lefe or loth
He is his þral to whom that he hath saide
A tale of which he is now eviƚƚ Apayde
Mi sone be ware and be none auctoʳur newe
Of tidingꝭes wheþ̉er þei ben fals or trewe
Wher so that thow Come A mongꝭes hie or lowe
Kepe wel thi tonge ⁊and think vpon þe crowe
¶ Here Endithe þe Manciple
